Ticket #233: Dan Simmons - Hyperion 01 - Hyperion.TXT

1	PROLOGUE
2	
3	The Hegemony Consul sat on the balcony of his ebony spaceship and played
4	Rachmaninoff's Prelude in C-sharp Minor on an ancient but
5	well-maintained Steinway while great, green, saurian things surged and
6	bellowed in the swamps below. A thunderstorm was brewing to the north.
7	Bruise-black clouds silhouetted a forest of giant gymnosperms while
8	stratocumulus towered nine kilometers high in a violent sky. Lightning
9	rippled along the horizon. Closer to the ship, occasional vague,
10	reptilian shapes would blunder into the interdiction field, cry out, and
11	then crash away through indigo mists. The Consul concentrated on a
12	difficult section of the Prelude and ignored the approach of storm and
13	nightfall.
14	The fatline receiver chimed.
15	The Consul stopped, fingers hovering above the keyboard, and listened.
16	Thunder rumbled through the heavy air. From the direction of the
17	gymnosperm forest there came the mournful ululation of a carrion-breed
18	pack. Somewhere in the darkness below, a small-brained beast trumpeted
19	its answering challenge and fell quiet.
20	The interdiction field added its sonic undertones to the sudden silence.
21	The fatline chimed again.
22	'Damn,' said the Consul and went in to answer it.
23	While the computer took a few seconds to convert and decode the burst of
24	decaying tachyons, the Consul poured himself a glass of Scotch. He
25	settled into the cushions of the projection pit just as the diskey
26	blinked green. 'Play,' he said.
27	'You have been chosen to return to Hyperion,' came a woman's husky
28	voice. Full visuals had not yet formed; the air remained empty except
29	for the pulse of transmission
30	codes which told the Consul that this fatline squirt had originated on
31	the Hegemony administrative world of Tau Ceti Center. The Consul did
32	not need the transmission coordinates to know this. The aged but still
33	beautiful voice of Meina Gladstone was unmistakable.
34	'You have been chosen to return to Hyperion as a member of the Shrike
35	Pilgrimage,' continued the voice.
36	The hell you say, thought the Consul and rose to leave the pit.
37	'You and six others have been selected by the Church of the Shrike and
38	confirmed by the All Thing,' said Meina Gladstone. 'It is in the
39	interest of the Hegemony that you accept."
40	The Consul stood motionless in the pit, his back to the flickering
41	transmission codes. Without turning, he raised his glass and drained
42	the last of the Scotch.
43	'The situation is very confused,' said Meina Gladstone. Her voice was
44	weary. 'The consulate and Home Rule Council fatlined us three standard
45	weeks ago with the news that the Time Tombs showed signs of opening. The
46	anti-entropic fields around them were expanding rapidly and the Shrike
47	has begun ranging as far south as the Bridle Range."
48	The Consul turned and dropped into the cushions. A hoio had formed of
49	Meina Gladstone's ancient face. Her eyes looked as tired as her voice
50	sounded.
51	'A FORCE:space task force was immediately dispatched from Parvati to
52	evacuate the Hegemony citizens on Hyperion before the Time Tombs open.
53	Their time-debt will be a little more than three Hyperion years." Meina
54	Gladstone paused. The Consul thought he had never seen the Senate CEO
55	look so grim. 'We do not know if the evacuation fleet will arrive in
56	time,' she said, 'but the situation is even more complicated. An Ouster
57	migration cluster of at least four thousand... units...
58	has been detected approaching the Hyperion system.
59	Our evacuation task force should arrive only a short while before the
60	Ousters."
61	The Consul understood Gladstone's hesitation. An Ouster migration
62	cluster might consist of ships ranging in size from single-person
63	ramscouts to can cities and comet forts holding tens of thousands of the
64	interstellar barbarians.
65	'The FORCE joint chiefs believe that this is the Ousters' big push,'
66	said Meina Gladstone. The ship's computer had positioned the holo so
67	that the woman's sad brown eyes seemed to be staring directly at the
68	Consul.
69	'Whether they seek to control just Hyperion for the Time Tombs or
70	whether this is an all-out attack on the Worldweb remains to be seen. In
71	the meantime, a full FORCE:space battle fleet complete with a fareaster
72	construction battalion has spun up from the Camn System to join the
73	evacuation task force, but this fleet may be recalled depending upon
74	circumstances."
75	The Consul nodded and absently raised the Scotch to his lips. He
76	frowned at the empty glass and dropped it onto the thick carpeting of
77	the holopit. Even with no military training he understood the difficult
78	tactical decision Gladstone and the joint chiefs were faced with.
79	Unless a military fareaster were hurriedly constructed in the Hyperion
80	system- at staggering expense- there would be no way to resist the
81	Ouster invasion. Whatever secrets the Time Tombs might hold would go to
82	the Hegemony's enemy. If the fleet did construct a farcaster in time
83	and the Hegemony committed the total resources of FORCE to defending the
84	single, distant, colonial world of Hyperion, the Worldweb ran the
85	terrible risk of suffering an Ouster attack elsewhere on the perimeter,
86	or- in a worst-case scenario- having the barbarians actually seizing the
87	farcaster and penetrating the Web itself. The Consul tried to imagine
88	the reality of armored Ouster troops stepping through farcaster portals
89	into the undefended home cities on a hundred worlds.
90	The Consul walked through the holo of Meina Gladstone, retrieved his
91	glass, and went to pour another Scotch.
92	'You have been chosen to join the pilgrimage to the Shrike,' said the
93	image of the old CEO whom the press loved to compare to Lincoln or
94	Churchill or Alvarez-Temp or whatever other pre-Hegira legend was in
95	historical vogue at the time. 'The Templars are sending their treeship
96	Yggdrasil!,' said Gladstone, 'and the
97	evacuation task force commander has instructions to let it pass. With a
98	three-week time-debt, you can rendezvous with the Yggdrasill before it
99	goes quantum from the Parvati system. The six other pilgrims chosen by
100	the Shrike Church will be aboard the treeship. Our intelligence reports
101	suggest that at least one of the seven pilgrims is an agent of the
102	Ousters. We do not... at this time... have any way of knowing which
103	one it is."
104	The Consul had to smile. Among all the other risks Gladstone was
105	taking, the old woman had to consider the possibility that he was the
106	spy and that she was fatlining crucial information to an Ouster agent.
107	Or had she given him any crucial information? The fleet movements were
108	detectable as soon as the ships used their Hawking drives, and if the
109	Consul were the spy, the CEO's revelation might be a way to scare him
110	off. The Consul's smile faded and he drank his Scotch.
111	'Sol Weintraub and Fedmahn Kassad are among the seven pilgrims chosen,'
112	said Gladstone.
113	The Consul's frown deepened. He stared at the cloud of digits
114	flickering like dust motes around the old woman's image. Fifteen
115	seconds of fatline transmission time remained.
116	'We need your help,' said Meina Gladstone. 'It is essential that the
117	secrets of the Time Tombs and Shrike be uncovered. This pilgrimage may
118	be our last chance. If the Ousters conquer Hyperion, their agent must
119	be eliminated and the Time Tombs sealed at all cost. The fate of the
120	Hegemony may depend upon it."
121	The transmission ended except for the pulse of rendezvous coordinates.
122	'Response?" asked the ship's computer.
123	Despite the tremendous energies involved, the spacecraft was capable of
124	placing a brief, coded squirt into the incessant babble of FTL bursts
125	which tied the human portions of the galaxy together.
126	'No,' said the Consul and went outside to lean on the balcony railing.
127	Night had fallen and the clouds were low. No stars were visible. The
128	darkness would have been absolute except for the intermittent flash of
129	lightning to the north and a soft phosphorescence rising from the
130	marshes. The Consul was suddenly very aware that he was, at that
131	second, the only sentient being on an unnamed world. He listened to the
132	antediluvian night sounds rising from the swamps and he thought about
133	morning, about setting out in the Vikken EMV at first light, about
134	spending the day in sunshine, about hunting big game in the fern forests
135	to the south and then returning to the ship in the evening for a good
136	steak and a cold beer. The Consul thought about the sharp pleasure of
137	the hunt and the equally sharp solace of solitude: solitude he had
138	earned through the pain and nightmare he had
139	already suffered on Hyperion.
140	Hyperion.
141	The Consul went inside, brought the balcony in, and sealed the ship just
142	as the first heavy raindrops began to fall. He climbed the spiral
143	staircase to his sleeping cabin at the apex of the ship. The circular
144	room was dark except for silent explosions of lightning which outlined
145	rivulets of rain coursing the skylight. The Consul stripped, lay back
146	on the firm mattress, and switched on the sound system and external
147	audio pickups. He listened as the fury of the storm blended with the
148	violence of Wagner's 'Flight of the Valkyries." Hurricane winds buffeted
149	the ship. The sound of thunderclaps filled the room as the skylight
150	flashed white, leaving afterimages burning in the Consul's retinas.
151	Wagner is good only for thunderstorms, he thought.
152	He closed his eyes but the lightning was visible through closed eyelids.
153	He remembered the glint of ice crystals blowing through the tumbled
154	ruins on the low hills near the Time Tombs and the colder gleam of steel
155	on the Shrike's impossible tree of metal thorns. He remembered screams
156	in the night and the hundred-facet, ruby and-blood gaze of the Shrike
157	itself.
158	Hyperion.
159	The Consul silently commanded the computer to shut off all speakers and
160	raised his wrist to cover his eyes. In the sudden silence he lay
161	thinking about how insane it would be to return to Hyperion. During his
162	eleven years as Consul on that distant and enigmatic world, the
163	mysterious Church of the Shrike had allowed a dozen barges of offworld
164	pilgrims to depart for the windswept barrens
165	around the Time Tombs, north of the mountains. No one had returned. And
166	that had been in normal times, when the Shrike had been prisoner to the
167	tides of time and forces no one understood, and the anti-entropic fields
168	had been contained to a few dozen meters around the Time Tombs. And
169	there had been no threat of an Ouster invasion.
170	The Consul thought of the Shrike, free to wander everywhere on Hyperion,
171	of the millions of indigenies and thousands of Hegemony citizens
172	helpless before a creature which defied physical laws and which
173	communicated only through death, and he shivered despite the
174	warmth of the cabin.
175	Hyperion.
176	The night and storm passed. Another stormfront raced ahead of the
177	approaching dawn. Gymnosperms two hundred meters tall bent and whipped
178	before the coming torrent. Just before first light, the Consul's ebony
179	spaceship rose on a tail of blue plasma and punched through thickening
180	clouds as it climbed toward space and rendezvous.
181	ONE
182	The Consul awoke with the peculiar headache, dry throat, and sense of
183	having forgotten a thousand dreams which only periods in cryogenic fugue
184	could bring. He blinked, sat upright on a low couch, and groggily
185	pushed away the last sensor tapes clinging to his skin. There were two
186	very short crew clones and one very tall, hooded Templar with him in the
187	windowless ovoid of a room. One of the clones offered the Consul the
188	traditional post-thaw glass of orange juice. He accepted it and drank
189	greedily.
190	'The Tree is two light-minutes and five hours of travel from Hyperion,'
191	said the Templar, and the Consul realized that he was being addressed by
192	Het Masteen, captain of the Templar treeship and True Voice of the Tree.
193	The Consul vaguely realized that it was a great honor to be awakened by
194	the Captain, but he was too groggy and disoriented from fugue to
195	appreciate it.
196	'The others have been awake for some hours,' said Het Masteen and
197	gestured for the clones to leave them.
198	'They have assembled on the foremost dining platform."
199	'Hhrghn,' said the Consul and took a drink. He cleared his throat and
200	tried again. 'Thank you, Het Masteen,' he managed. Looking around at
201	the egg-shaped room with its carpet of dark grass, translucent walls,
202	and support ribs of continuous, curved weirwood, the Consul realized
203	that he must be in one of the smaller environment pods. Closing his
204	eyes, he tried to recall his memories of rendezvous just before the
205	Templar ship went quantum.
206	The Consul remembered his first glimpse of the kilometer-long treeship
207	as he closed for rendezvous, the treeship's details blurred by the
208	redundant machine and
209	erg-generated containment fields which surrounded it like a spherical
210	mist, but its leafy bulk clearly ablaze with thousands of lights which
211	shone softly through leaves and thin-walled environment pods, or along
212	countless platforms, bridges, command decks, stairways, and bowers.
213	Around the base of the treeship, engineering and cargo spheres clustered
214	like oversized galls while blue and violet drive streamers trailed
215	behind like ten-kilometer-long roots.
216	'The others await,' Her Masteen said softly and nodded toward low
217	cushions where the Consul's luggage lay ready to open upon his command.
218	The Templar gazed thoughtfully at the weirwood rafters while the Consul
219	dressed in semiformal evening wear of loose black trousers, polished
220	ship boots, a white silk blouse which ballooned at waist and elbows,
221	topaz collar cinch, black demi-coat complete with slashes of Hegemony
222	crimson on the epaulets, and a soft gold tricorne. A section of curved
223	wall became a mirror and the Consul stared at the image there: a more
224	than middle-aged man in semi-formal evening wear, sunburned skin but
225	oddly pale under the sad eyes. The Consul frowned, nodded, and turned
226	away.
227	Het Masteen gestured and the Consul followed the tall, robed figure
228	through a dilation in the pod onto an ascending walkway which curved up
229	and out of sight around the massive bark wall of the treeship's trunk.
230	The Consul paused, moved to the edge of the walkway, and took a quick
231	step back. It was at least six hundred meters down- down being created
232	by the one-sixth standard gravity being generated by the singularities
233	imprisoned at the base of the tree - and there were no railings.
234	They resumed their silent ascent, turning off from the main trunk
235	walkway thirty meters and half a trunk-spiral later to cross a flimsy
236	suspension bridge to a five-meter-wide branch. They followed this
237	outward to where the riot of leaves caught the glare of Hyperion's sun.
238	'Has my ship been brought out of storage?" asked the Consul.
239	'It is fueled and ready in sphere eleven,' said Her Masteen. They
240	passed into the shadow of the trunk and stars became visible in the
241	black patches between the dark latticework of leaves. 'The other
242	pilgrims have agreed to ferry down in your ship if the FORCE authorities
243	give permission,' added the Templar.
244	The Consul rubbed his eyes and wished that he had been allowed more time
245	to retrieve his wits from the cold grip of cryonic fugue. 'You've been
246	in touch with the task force?"
247	'Oh, yes, we were challenged the moment we tunneled down from quantum
248	leap. A Hegemony warship is...
249	escorting us.. · this very moment." Het Masteen gestured toward a patch
250	of sky above them.
251	The Consul squinted upward but at that second segments of the upper
252	tiers of branches revolved out of the treeship's shadow and acres of
253	leaves ignited in sunset hues. Even in the still shadowed places,
254	glowbirds nestled like Japanese lanterns above lighted walkways, glowing
255	swingvines, and illuminated hanging bridges, while fireflies from Old
256	Earth and radiant gossamers from Maul-Covenant blinked and coded their
257	way through labyrinths of leaves, mixing with constellations
258	sufficiently to fool even the most starwise traveler.
259	Het Masteen stepped into a basket lift hanging from a whiskered-carbon
260	cable which disappeared into the three hundred meters of tree above
261	them. The Consul followed and they were borne silently upward. He
262	noted that the walkways, pods, and platforms were conspicuously empty
263	except for a few Templars and their diminutive crew clone counterparts.
264	The Consul could recall seeing no other passengers during his rushed
265	hour between rendezvous and fugue, but he had put that down to the
266	imminence of the treeship going quantum, assuming then that the
267	passengers were safe in their fugue couches. Now, however, the treeship
268	was traveling far below relativistic velocities and its branches should
269	be crowded with gawking passengers. He mentioned his observation to the
270	Templar.
271	'The six of you are our only passengers,' said Het Masteen. The basket
272	stopped in a maze of foliage and
273	the treeship captain led the way up a wooden escalator worn with age.
274	The Consul blinked in surprise. A Templar treeship normally carried
275	between two and five thousand passengers; it was easily the most
276	desirable way to travel between the stars. Treeships rarely accrued
277	more than a four- or five-month time-debt, making short, scenic
278	crossings where star systems were a very few light-years apart, thus
279	allowing their affluent passengers to spend as little time as necessary
280	in fugue. For the treeship to make the trip to Hyperion and back,
281	accumulating six years of Web time with no paying passengers would mean
282	a staggering financial loss to the Templars.
283	Then the Consul realized, belatedly, that the treeship would be ideal
284	for the upcoming evacuation, its expenses ultimately to be reimbursed by
285	the Hegemony.
286	Still, the Consul knew, to bring a ship as beautiful and vulnerable as
287	the Yggdrasill - one of only five of its kind - into a war zone was a
288	terrible risk for the Templar Brotherhood.
289	'Your fellow pilgrims,' announced Het Masteen as he and the Consul
290	emerged onto a broad platform where a small group waited at one end of a
291	long wooden table.
292	Above them the stars burned, rotating occasionally as the treeship
293	changed its pitch or yaw, while to either side a solid sphere of foliage
294	curved away like the green skin of some great fruit. The Consul
295	immediately recognized the setting as the Captain's dining platform,
296	even before the five other passengers rose to let Her Masteen take his
297	place at the head of the table. The Consul found an empty chair waiting
298	for him to the left of the Captain.
299	When everyone was seated and quiet, Het Masteen made formal
300	introductions. Although the Consul knew none of the others from
301	personal experience, several of the names were familiar and he used his
302	diplomat's long training to file away identities and impressions.
303	To the Consul's left sat Father Lenar Hoyt, a priest of the old-style
304	Christian sect known as Catholic. For a second the Consul had forgotten
305	the significance of the black clothing and Roman collar, but then he
306	remembered St Francis Hospital on Hebron where he had
307	received alcohol trauma therapy after his disastrous first diplomatic
308	assignment there almost four standard decades earlier. And at the
309	mention of Hoyt's name he remembered another priest, one who had
310	disappeared on Hyperion halfway through his own tenure there.
311	Lenar Hoyt was a young man by the Consul's reckoning - no more than his
312	early thirties - but it appeared that something had aged the man
313	terribly in the not too distant past. The Consul looked at the thin
314	face, cheekbones pressing against sallow flesh, eyes large but hooded in
315	deep hollows, thin lips set in a permanent twitch of muscle too
316	downturned to be called even a cynical smile, the hairline not so much
317	receding as ravaged by radiation, and he felt he was looking at a man
318	who had been ill for years. Still, the Consul was surprised that behind
319	that mask of concealed pain there remained the physical echo of the boy
320	in the man - the faintest remnants of the round face, fair skin, and
321	soft mouth which had belonged to a younger, healthier, less cynical
322	Lenar Hoyt.
323	Next to the priest sat a man whose image had been familiar to most
324	citizens of the Hegemony some years before. The Consul wondered if the
325	collective attention span in the Worldweb was as short now as it had
326	been when he had lived there. Shorter, probably. If so, then Colonel
327	Fedmahn Kassad, the so-called Butcher of South Bressia, was probably no
328	longer either infamous or famous. To the Consul's generation and to all
329	those who lived in the slow, expatriate fringe of things, Kassad was not
330	someone one was likely to forget.
331	Colonel Fedmahn Kassad was tall- almost tall enough to look the
332	two-meter Her Masteen in the eye - and dressed in FORCE black with no
333	rank insignia or citations showing. The black uniform was oddly similar
334	to Father Hoyt's garb, but there was no real resemblance between the two
335	men. In lieu of Hoyt's wasted appearance, Kassad was brown, obviously
336	fit, and whip-handle lean, with strands of muscle showing in shoulder,
337	wrist, and throat. The Colonel's eyes were small, dark, and as
338	all-encompassing as the lenses of some primitive video camera. His face
339	was all angles: shadows, planes, and facets. Not gaunt like Father
340	Hoyt's, merely carved from cold stone. A thin line of beard along his
341	jawline served to accent the sharpness of his countenance as surely as
342	blood on a knife blade.
343	The Colonel's intense, slow movements reminded the Consul of an
344	Earth-bred jaguar he had seen in a private seedship zoo on Lusus many
345	years before. Kassad's voice was soft but the Consul did not fail to
346	notice that even the Colonel's silences commanded attention.
347	Most of the long table was empty, the group clustered at one end. Across
348	from Fedmahn Kassad sat a man introduced as the poet Martin Silenus.
349	Silenus appeared to be quite the opposite of the military *****man
350	across from him. Where Kassad was lean and tall, Martin Silenus was
351	short and visibly out of shape.
352	Countering Kassad's stone-cut features, the poet's face was as mobile
353	and expressive as an Earth primate's. His voice was a loud, profane
354	rasp. There was something, thought the Consul, almost pleasantly
355	demonic about Martin Silenus, with his ruddy cheeks, broad mouth,
356	pitched eyebrows, sharp ears, and constantly moving hands sporting
357	fingers long enough to serve a concert pianist.
358	Or a strangler. The poet' s silver hair had been cropped into
359	rough-hewn bangs.
360	Martin Silenus seemed to be in his late fifties, but the Consul noticed
361	the telltale blue tinge to throat and palms and suspected that the man
362	had been through more than a few Poulsen treatments. Silenus's true age
363	might be anywhere from ninetytoa hundred and fiftystandard years. I f
364	he were close to the latter age, the Consul knew, the odds were that the
365	poet was quite mad.
366	As boisterous and animated as Martin Silenus seemed upon first
367	encounter, so the next guest at the table exuded an immediate and
368	equally impressive sense of intelligent reticence. Sol Weintranb looked
369	up upon introduction and the Consul noted the short gray beard, lined
370	forehead, and sad, luminous eyes of the weli-known scholar. The Consul
371	had heard tales of the Wandering Jew and his hopeless quest, but he was
372	shocked to realize that the old man now held the infant in his arms -
373	his daughter Rachel, no more than a few weeks old. The Consul looked
374	away.
375	The sixth pilgrim and only woman at the table was Brawne Lamia. When
376	introduced, the detective stared at the Consul with such intensity that
377	he could feel the pressure of her gaze even after she looked away.
378	A former citizen of the I.3-g world of Lusus, Brawne Lamia was no taller
379	than the poet two chairs to her right, but even her loose corduroy
380	shipsuit did not conceal the heavy layers of muscle on her compact form.
381	Black curls reached to her shoulders, her eyebrows were two dark lines
382	dabbed horizontally across a wide brow, and her nose was solid and
383	sharp, intensifying the aquiline quality of her stare. Lamia's mouth
384	was wide and expressive to the point of being sensuous, curled slightly
385	at the coruers in a slight smile which might be cruel or merely playful.
386	The woman's dark eyes seemed to dare the observer to discover which was
387	the case.
388	It occurred to the Consul that Brawne Lamia might well be considered
389	beautiful.
390	Introductions completed, the Consul cleared his throat and turned toward
391	the Templar. 'Het Masteen, you said that there were seven pilgrims. Is
392	M.
393	Weintraub's child the seventh?"
394	Het Masteen's hood moved slowly from side to side.
395	'No. Only those who make a conscious decision to seek the Shrike may be
396	counted among the pilgrims."
397	The group at the table stirred slightly. Each must know what the Consul
398	knew; only a group comprising a prime number of pilgrims might make the
399	Shrike Church-sponsored trip north.
400	'I am the seventh,' said Het Masteen, captain of the Templar treeship
401	ggdrasill and the True Voice of the Tree. In the silence which followed
402	the announcement, Her Masteen gestured and a group of crew clones began
403	serving the pilgrims their last meal before planetfall.
404	'So the Ousters are not in-system yet?" asked Brawne Lamia. Her voice
405	had a husky, throaty quality which strangely stirred the Consul.
406	'No,' said Het Masteen. 'But we cannot be more than a few standard days
407	ahead of them. Our instruments
408	have detected fusion skirmishes within the system's OOrt cloud."
409	'Will there be war."?" asked Father Hoyt. His voice seemed as fatigued
410	as his expression. When no one volunteered a response, the priest
411	turned to his right as if retroactively directing the question to the
412	Consul.
413	The Consul sighed. The crew clones had served wine; he wished it had
414	been whiskey. 'Who knows what the Ousters will do?" he said. 'They no
415	longer appear to be motivated by human logic."
416	Martin Silenus laughed loudly, spilling his wine as he gestured. 'As if
417	we fucking humans were ever motivated by human logic!" He took a deep
418	drink, wiped his mouth, and laughed again.
419	Brawne Lamia frowned. 'If the serious fighting starts too soon,' she
420	said, 'perhaps the authorities will not allow us to land."
421	'We will be allowed to pass,; said Her Masteen. Sunlight found its way
422	past folds in his cowl to fall on yellowish skin.
423	'Saved from certain death in war to be delivered to certain death at the
424	hands of the Shrike,' murmured Father Hoyt.
425	'There is no death in all the Universe!" intoned Martin Silenus in a
426	voice which the Consul felt sure could have awakened someone deep in
427	cryogenic fugue. The poet drained the last of his wine and' raised the
428	empty goblet in an apparent toast to the stars:
429	'No smellof death = there shall be no death, moan, moan; Moan, Cybele,
430	moan;for t hy pernicious Babes
431	Have changed a god into a shaking palsy.
432	Moan, brethren, moan, for l have no strength left;
433	Freak as the reed - weak - feeble as my voice- Oh, oh, thepain, thepain
434	of feebleness.
435	Moan, moan, for still l thaw..."
436	.Silenus abruptly broke off and poured more wine, belching once into
437	the silence which had followed his recitation.
438	The other six looked at one another. The Consul noticed that Sol
439	Weintraub was smiling slightly until the baby in his arms stirred and
440	distracted him.
441	'Well,' said Father Hoyt hesitantly, as if trying to retrieve an earlier
442	strand of thought, 'if the Hegemony convoy leaves and the Ousters take
443	Hyperion, perhaps the occupation will be bloodless and they'll let us go
444	about our business."
445	Colonel Fedmahn Kassad laughed softly. 'The Ousters don't want to
446	occupy Hyperion,' he said. 'If they take the planet they'll loot what
447	they want and then do what they do best. They'll burn the cities into

744	And he bigan with right a myrie cheere
745	His tale anon, and seyde as ye may heere. '
746	THE PRIEST'S TALE: 'The Man Who Cried God'
747	'Sometimes there is a thin line separating orthodox zeal from apostasy,'
748	said Father Lenar Hoyt.
749	So began the priest's story. Later, dictating the tale into his
750	cornlog, the Consul remembered it as a seamless whole, minus the pauses,
751	hoarse voice, false starts, and small redundancies which were the
752	timeless failings of human speech.
753	Lenar Hoyt had been a young priest, born, raised, and only recently
754	ordained on the Catholic world of Pacem, when he was given his first
755	offworld assignment: he was ordered to escort the respected Jesuit
756	Father Paul Dur into quiet exile on the colony world of Hyperion.
757	In another time, Father Paul Dur certainly would have become a bishop
758	and perhaps a pope. Tall, thin, ascetic, with white hair receding from
759	a noble brow and eyes too filled with the sharp edge 'of experience to
760	hide their pain, Paul Dur was a follower of St Tellhard as well as an
761	archaeologist, ethnologist, and eminent Jesuit theologian. Despite the
762	decline of the Catholic Church into what amounted to a half-forgotten
763	cult tolerated because of its quaintness and isolation from the
764	mainstream of Hegemony life, Jesuit logic had not lost its bite. Nor
765	had Father Dur lost his conviction that the Holy Catholic Apostolic
766	Church continued to be humankind's last, best hope for immortality.
767	To Lenar Hoyt as a boy, Father Dur had been a somewhat godlike figure
768	when glimpsed during his rare visits to the preseminary schools, or on
769	the would-be seminarian's even rarer visits to the New Vatican. Then,
770	during the years of Hoyt's study in seminary, Dur had been on an
771	important Church-sponsored archaeological dig on the nearby world of
772	Armaghast. When the Jesuit returned, a few weeks after Hoyt's
773	ordination, it had been under a cloud. No one outside the highest
774	circles of the New Vatican knew precisely what had happened, but there
775	were whispers of excommunication and even of a hearing before the Holy
776	Office of the Inquisition, dormant the four centuries since the
777	confusion following the death of Earth.
778	Instead, Father Dur had asked for a posting to Hyperion, a world most
779	people knew of only because of the bizarre Shrike cult which had
780	originated there, and Father Hoyt had been chosen to accompany him. It
781	would be a thankless job, traveling in a role which combined the worst
782	aspects of apprentice, escort, and spy without even the satisfaction of
783	seeing a new world; Hoyt was under orders to see Father Dur down to the
784	Hyperion spaceport and then reboard the same spinship for its return
785	voyage to the Worldweb. What the bishopric was offering Lenar Hoyt was
786	twenty months in cryogenic fugue, a few weeks of in-system travel at
787	either end of the voyage, and a time-debt which would return him to
788	Pacem eight years behind his former classmates in the quest for Vatican
789	careers and missionary postings.
790	Bound by obedience and schooled in discipline, Lenar Hoyt accepted
791	without question.
792	Their transport, the aging spinship HS Nadia Oleg, was a pockmarked
793	metal tub with no artificial gravity of any sort when it was not under
794	drive, no viewports for the passengers, and no on-board recreation
795	except for the stimsims piped into the datalink to keep passengers in
796	their hammocks and fugue couches. After awakening from fugue, the
797	passengers - mostly offworld workers and economy-rate tourists with a
798	few cult mystics and would-be Shrike suicides thrown in for good measure
799	-slept in those same hammocks and fugue couches, ate recycled food in
800	featureless mess decks, and generally tried to cope with spacesickness
801	and boredom during their twelve-day, zero-g glide from their spinout
802	point to Hyperion.
803	Father Hoyt learned little from Father Dur during those days of forced
804	intimacy, nothing at all about the events on Armaghast which had sent
805	the senior priest into exile. The younger man had keyed his comlog
806	implant to seek out as much data as it could on Hyperion and, by the
807	time they were three days out from planet fall,
808	Father Hoyt considered himself somewhat of an expert on the world.
809	'There are records of Catholics coming to Hyperion but no mention of a
810	diocese there,' said Hoyt one evening as they hung talking in their
811	zero-g hammocks while most of their fellow passengers lay tuned into
812	erotic stimsims. 'I presume you're going down to do some mission work?"
813	'Not at all,' replied Father Dur. 'The good people of Hyperion have
814	done nothing to foist their religious opinions on me, so I see no reason
815	to offend them with my proselytizing. Actually, I hope to travel to the
816	southern continent- Aquila- and then find a way inland from the city of
817	Port Romance. But not in the guise of a missionary. I plan to set up
818	an ethnological research station along the Cleft."
819	'Research?" Father Hoyt had echoed in surprise. He closed his eyes to
820	key his implant. Looking again at Father Dur, he said, 'That section of
821	the Pinion Plateau isn't inhabited, Father. The flame forests make it
822	totally inaccessible most of the year."
823	Father Dur smiled and nodded. He carried no implant and his ancient
824	condog had been in his luggage for the duration of the trip. 'Not quite
825	inaccessible,' he said softly. 'And not quite uninhabited. The Bikura
826	live there."
827	'Bikura,' Father Hoyt said and closed his eyes. 'But they're just a
828	legend,' he said at last.
829	'Hmmm,' said Father Dur. 'Try cross-indexing through Mamet Spedling."
830	Father Hoyt closed his eyes again. General Index told him that Mamet
831	Spedling had been a minor explorer affiliated with the Shackleton
832	Institute on Renaissance Minor who, almost a standard century and a half
833	earlier, had filed a short report with the Institute in which he told of
834	hacking his way inland from the then newly settled Port Romance, through
835	swamplands which had since been reclaimed for fiberplastic plantations,
836	passing through the flame forests during a period of rare quietude, and
837	climbing high enough on the Pinion Plateau to encounter the Cleft and a
838	small tribe of humans who fit the profile of the legendary Bikura.
839	Spedling's brief notes hypothesized that the humans were survivors of a
840	missing seedship colony from three centuries earlier and clearly
841	described a group suffering all of the classic retrograde cultural
842	effects of extreme isolation, inhreeding, and overadaptation. In
843	Spedling's blunt words, '. · even after less than two days here it is
844	obvious that the Bikura are too stupid, lethargic, and dull to waste
845	time describing." As it turned out, the flame forests then began to show
846	some signs of becoming active and Spedling had not wasted any more time
847	observing his discovery but had rushed to reach the coast, losing four
848	indigenie bearers, all of his equipment and records, and his left arm to
849	the 'quiet' forest in the three months it took him to escape.
850	'My God,' Father Hoyt had said as he lay in his hammock on the Nadia
851	Oleg, 'why the Bikura?"
852	'Why not?" had been Father Dur's mild reply. 'Very little is known
853	about them."
854	'Very little is known about most of Hyperion,' said the younger priest,
855	becoming somewhat agitated. 'What about the Time Tombs and the
856	legendary Shrike north of the Bridle Range on Equus?" he said. 'They're
857	famous!'
858	'Precisely,' said Father Dur6. 'Lenar, how many learned papers have
859	been written on the Tombs and the Shrike creature? Hundreds?
860	Thousands?" The aging priest had tamped in tobacco and now lighted his
861	pipe: no small feat in zero-g, Hoyt observed. 'Besides,' said Paul
862	Dur6, 'even if the Shrike-thing is real, it is not human. I am partial
863	to human beings."
864	'Yes,' said Hoyt, ransacking his mental arsenal for potent arguments,
865	'but the Bikura are such a small mystery. At the most you're going to
866	find a few dozen indigenies living in a region so cloudy and smoky and
867	... unimportant that even the colony's own mapsats haven't noticed
868	them. Why choose them when there are big mysteries to study on
869	Hyperion.. · like the labyrinths!' Hoyt had brightened. 'Did you know
870	that Hyperion is one of the nine labyrinthine worlds, Father?"
871	'Of course,' said Dur. A rough hemisphere of smoke expanded from him
872	until air currents broke it into tendrils and tributaries. 'But the
873	labyrinths have their researchers and admirers throughout the Web,
874	Lenar, and the tunnels have been there - on all nine worlds -for how
875	long? Half a million standard years? Closer to three quarters of a
876	million, I believe. Their secret will last. But how long will the
877	Bikura culture last before they're absorbed into modern colonial society
878	or, more likely, are simply wiped out by circumstances?"
879	Hoyt shrugged. 'Perhaps they're already gone. It's been a long time
880	since Spedling's encounter with them and there haven't been any other
881	confirmed reports. If they are extinct as a group, then all of your
882	time-debt and labor and pain of getting there will be for nothing."
883	'Precisely,' was all that Father Paul Dur had said and puffed calmly on
884	his pipe.
885	It was in their last hour together, during the dropship ride down, that
886	Father Hoyt had gained the slightest glimpse into his companion's
887	thoughts. The limb of Hyperion had been glowing white and green and
888	lapis above them for hours when suddenly the old dropship had cut into
889	the upper layers of atmosphere, flame had briefly filled the window, and
890	then they were flying silently some sixty kilometers above dark cloud
891	masses and starlit seas with the hurtling terminator of Hyperion's
892	sunrise rushing toward them like a spectral tidal wave of light.
893	'Marvelous,' Paul Dur had whispered, more to himself than to his young
894	companion. 'Marvelous. It is at times like this that I have the
895	sense... the slightest sense · . . of what a sacrifice it must have
896	been for the Son of God to condescend to become the Son of Man."
897	Hoyt had wanted to talk then, but Father Dur had continued to stare out
898	the window, lost in thought. Ten minutes later they had landed at Keats
899	Interstellar, Father Dur was soon swept into the whirlpool of customs
900	and luggage rituals, and twenty minutes after that a thoroughly
901	disappointed Lenar Hoyt was rising toward space and the Nadia Oleg once
902	again.
903	'Five weeks later of my time, I returned to Pacem,' said Father Hoyt. 'I
904	had mislaid eight years but for some reason my sense of loss randeeper
905	than that simple fact.
906	Immediately upon my return, the bishop informed me that there had been
907	no word from Paul Dur during the four years of his stay on Hyperion. The
908	New Vatican had spent a fortune on fatline inquiries, but neither the
909	colonial authorities nor the consulate in Keats had been able to locate
910	the missing priest."
911	Hoyt paused to sip from his water glass and the Consul said, 'I remember
912	the search. I never met Dur6, of course, but we did our best to trace
913	him. Theo, my aide, spent a lot of energy over the years trying to
914	solve the case of the missing cleric. Other than a few contra-dietory
915	reports of sightings in Port Romance, there was no trace of him. And
916	those sightings went back to the weeks right after his arrival, years
917	before. There were hundreds of plantations out there with no radios or
918	cornlines, primarily because they were harvesting bootleg drugs as well
919	as fiberplastic. I guess we never talked to the people at the right
920	plantation. At least I know Father Dur's file was still open when I
921	left."
922	Father Hoyt nodded. 'I landed in Keats a month after your replacement
923	had taken over at the consulate. The bishop had been astonished when I
924	volunteered to return. His Holiness himself granted me an audience. I
925	was on Hyperion less than seven of its local months. By the time I left
926	to return to the Web, I had discovered the fate of Father Dur6." Hoyt
927	tapped the two stained leather books on the table. 'If I am to complete
928	this,' he said, his voice thick, 'I must read excerpts from these."
929	The treeship Yggdrasill had turned so the bulk of the tree had blocked
930	the sun. The effect was to plunge the dining platform and the curved
931	canopy of leaves beneath it into night, but instead of a few thousand
932	stars dotting the sky, as would have been the case from a planet's
933	surface, literally a million suns blazed above, beside, and beneath the
934	group at the table. Hyperion was a distinct sphere now, hurtling
935	directly at them like some deadly missile.
936	'Read,' said Martin Silenus.
937	FROM THE JOURNAL OF FATHER PAUL DURI :
938	Day l:
939	So begins my exile.
940	I am somewhat at a loss as to how to date my new journal. By the
941	monastic calendar on Pacere, it is the seventeenth day of Thomasmonth in
942	the Year of Our Lord 2732. By Hegemony Standard, it is October I2, 589
943	p.c. By Hyperion reckoning, or so I am told by the wizened little clerk
944	in the old hotel where I am staying, it is the twentyzthird day of
945	Lycius (the last of their seven forty-day months), either 426 A.D.C.
946	(after dropship crash!) or the hundred and twenty-eighth year of the
947	reign of Sad King Billy, who has not reigned for at least a hundred of
948	those years.
949	To hell with it. I'll call it Day I of my exile.
950	Exhausting day. (Strange to be tired after months of sleep, but that is
951	said to be a common reaction after awakening from fugue. My cells feel
952	the fatigue of Ihese past months of travel even if I do not remember
953	them. I don't remember feeling this tired from travel when I was
954	younger.)
955	I felt bad about not getting to know young Hoyt better. He seems a
956	decent sort, all proper catechism and bright eyes. It's no fault of
957	youngsters like him that the Church is in its final days. It's just
958	that his brand of happy naivet6 can do nothing to arrest that slide into
959	oblivion which the Church seems destined for.
960	Well, my contributions have not helped either.
961	Brilliant view of my new world as the dropship brought us down. I was
962	able to make out two of the three continents- Equus and Aquila. The
963	third one, Ursa, was not visible.
964	Planetfall at Keats and hours of effort getting through customs and
965	taking ground transit into the city. Confused images: the mountain
966	range to the north with its shifting, blue haze, foothills forested with
967	orange and yellow trees, pale sky with its green-blue undercoating, the
968	sun too small but more brilliant than Pacem's.
969	Colors seem more vivid from a distance, dissolving and scattering as one
970	approaches, like a pointillist's palette.
971	The great sculpture of Sad King Billy which I had heard so much about
972	was oddly disappointing. Seen from the highway, it looked raw and
973	rough, a hasty sketch chiseled from the dark mountain, rather than the
974	regal figure I had expected. It does brood over this ramshackle city of
975	half a million people in a way that the neurotic poet-king probably
976	would have appreciated.
977	The town itself seems to be separated into the sprawling maze of slums
978	and saloons which the locals call Jacktown and Keats itself, the
979	so-called Old City although it dates back only four centuries, all
980	polished stone and studied sterility. I will take the tour soon.
981	I had scheduled a month in Keats but already I am eager to press on. Oh,
982	Monsignor Edouard, if you could see me now. Punished but still
983	unrepentant. More alone than ever but strangely satisfied with my new
984	exile. If my punishment for past excesses brought about by my zeal is
985	to be banishment to the seventh circle of desolation, then Hyperion was
986	well chosen. I could forget my self-appointed mission to the distant
987	Bikura (are they real? I think not this night) and content myself with
988	living out the remainder of my years in this provincial capital on this
989	godforsaken backwater world. My exile would be no less complete.
990	Ah, Edouard, boys together, classmates together (although I was not so
991	brilliant nor so orthodox as you), now old men together. But now you
992	are four years wiser and I am still the mischievous, unrepentant boy you
993	remember. I pray that you are alive and well and praying for me.
994	Tired. Will sleep. Tomorrow, take the tour of Keats, eat well, and
995	arrange transport to Aquila and points south.
996	Day $:
997	There is a cathedral in Keats. Or, rather, there was one. It has been
998	abandoned for at least two standard centuries. It lies in ruins with
999	its transept open to the green-blue skies, one of its western towers
1000	unfinished, and the other tower a skeletal framework of tumbled stone
1001	and rusted reinforcement rods.
1002	I stumbled upon it while wandering, lost, along the banks of the Hoolie
1003	River in the 'sparsely populated section of town where the Old City
1004	decays into Jacktown amid a jumble of tall warehouses which prevent even
1005	a glimpse of the ruined towers of the cathedral until one turns a corner
1006	onto a narrow cul-de-sac and there is the shell of the cathedral; its
1007	chapter house has half fallen away into the river, its facade is pocked
1008	with remnants of the mournful, apocalyptic statuary of the post-Hegira
1009	expansionist period.
1010	I wandered through the latticework of shadows and fallen blocks into the
1011	nave. The bishopric on Paccm had not mentioned any history of
1012	Catholicism on Hyperion, much less the presence of a cathedral. It is
1013	almost inconceivable that the scattered seedship colony of four
1014	centuries ago could have supported a large enough congregation to
1015	warrant the presence of a bishop, much less a cathedral. Yet there it
1016	was.
1017	I poked through the shadows of the sacristy. Dust and powdered plaster
1018	hung in the air like incense, outlining two shafts of sunlight streaming
1019	down from narrow windows high above. I stepped out into a broader patch
1020	of sunlight and approached an altar stripped of all decoration except
1021	for chips and cracks caused by falling masonry. The great cross which
1022	had hung on the east wall behind the altar had also fallen and now lay
1023	in ceramic splinters among the heap of stones there. Without conscious
1024	thought I stepped behind the altar, raised my arms, and began the
1025	celebration of the Eucharist.
1026	There was no sense of parody or melodrama in this act, no symbolism or
1027	hidden intention; it was merely the automatic reaction of a priest who
1028	had said Mass almost daily for more than forty-six years of his life and
1029	who
1030	now faced the prospect of never again participating in the reassuring
1031	ritual of that celebration.
1032	It was with some shock that I realized I had a congregation.
1033	The old woman was kneeling in the fourth row of pews. The black of her
1034	dress and scarf blended so perfectly with the shadows there that only
1035	the pale oval of her face was visible, lined and ancient, floating
1036	disembodied in the darkness. Startled, I stopped speaking the litany of
1037	consecration. She was looking at me but something about her eyes, even
1038	at a distance, instantly convinced me that she was blind. For a moment
1039	I could not speak and stood there mute, squinting in the dusty light
1040	bathing the altar, trying to explain this spectral image to myself while
1041	at the same time attempting to frame an explanation of my own presence
1042	and actions.
1043	When I did find my voice and called to her- the words echoing in the
1044	great hall - I realized that she had moved. I could hear her feet
1045	scraping on the stone floor.
1046	There was a rasping sound and then a brief flare of light illuminated
1047	her profile far to the right of the altar. I shielded my eyes from the
1048	shafts of sunlight and began picking my way over the detritus where the
1049	altar railing had once stood. I called to her again, offered
1050	reassurances, and told her not to be afraid, even though it was I who
1051	had chills coursing up my back. I moved quickly but when I reached the
1052	sheltered corner of the nave she was gone. A small door led to the
1053	crumbling chapter house and the riverbank. There was no sign of her. I
1054	returned to the dark interior and would have gladly attributed her
1055	appearance to my imagination, a waking dream after so many months of
1056	enforced cryogenic dreamlesshess, but for a single, tangible proof of
1057	her presence. There in the cool darkness burned a lone red votive
1058	candle, its tiny flame flickering to unseen drafts and currents.
1059	I am tired of this city. I am tired of its pagan pretensions and false
1060	histories. Hyperion is a poet's world devoid of poetry. Keats itself
1061	is a mixture of tawdry, false classicism and mindless, boomtown energy.
1062	There are three Zen Gnostic assemblies and four High Muslim mosques in
1063	the town, but the real houses
1064	of worship are the countless saloons and brothels, the huge marketplaces
1065	handling the fiberplastic shipments from the south, and the Shrike Cult
1066	temples where lost souls hide their suicidal hopelessness behind a
1067	shield of shallow mysticism. The whole planet reeks of mysticism
1068	without revelation.
1069	To hell with it.
1070	Tomorrow I head south. There are skimmers and other aircraft on this
1071	absurd world but, for the Common Folk, travel between these accursed
1072	island continents seems restricted to boat- which takes forever, I am
1073	told- or one of the huge passenger dirigibles which de!arts from Keats
1074	only once a week.
1075	I leave early tomorrow by dirigible.

1160	Day 28:
1161	I have been in Port Romance eight days and I have seen three dead men.
1162	The first was a beached corpse, a bloated, white parody of a man, that
1163	had washed up on the mud flats beyond the mooring tower my first evening
1164	in town.
1165	Children threw stones at it.
1166	The second man I watched being pulled from the burned wreckage of a
1167	methane-unit shop in the poor section of town near my hotel. His body
1168	was charred beyond recognition and shrunken by the heat, his arms and
1169	legs pulled tight in the prizefighter posture burning victims have been
1170	reduced to since time immemorial. I had been fasting all day and I
1171	confess with shame that I began to salivate when the air filled with the
1172	rich, frying-fat odor of burned flesh.
1173	The third man was murdered not three meters from me. I had just emerged
1174	from the hotel onto the maze of mud-splattered planks that serve as
1175	sidewalks in this miserable town when shots rang out and a man several
1176	paces ahead of me lurched as if his foot had slipped, spun toward me
1177	with a qui=ical look on his face, and fell sideways into the mud and
1178	sewage.
1179	He had been shot three times with some sort of projectile weapon. Two
1180	of the bullets had struck his chest, the third entered just below the
1181	left eye.
1182	Incredibly, he was still breathing when I reached him.
1183	Without thinking about it, I removed my stole from my carrying bag,
1184	fumbled for the vial of holy water I had carried for so long, and
1185	proceeded to perform the sac-rameut of Extreme Unction. No one in the
1186	gathering crowd objected. The fallen man stirred once, cleared his
1187	throat as if he were about to speak, and died. The crowd dispersed even
1188	before the body was removed.
1189	The man was middle-aged, sandy-haired, and slightly overweight. He
1190	carried no identification, not even a universal card or comlog. There
1191	were six silver coins in his pocket.
1192	For some reason, I elected to stay with the body the rest of that day.
1193	The doctor was a short and cynical man
1194	who allowed me to stay during the required autopsy. !
1195	suspect that he was starved for conversation.
1196	'This is what the whole thing's worth,' he said as he opened the poor
1197	man'd belly like a pink satchel, pulling the folds of skin and muscle
1198	back and pinning them down like tent flaps.
1199	'What thing?" I asked.
1200	'His life,' said the doctor and pulled the skin of the corpse's face up
1201	and back like a greasy mask. 'Your life.
1202	My life." The red and white stripes of overlapping muscle turned to blue
1203	bruise around the ragged hole just above the cheekbone.
1204	'There has to be more than this,' I said.
1205	The doctor looked up from his grim work with a bemused smile. 'Is
1206	there?" he said. 'Please show me." He lifted the man's heart and seemed
1207	to weigh it in one hand. 'In the Web worlds, this'd be worth some money
1208	on the open market. There're those too poor to keep vat-grown, cloned
1209	parts in store, but too well off to die just for want of a heart. But
1210	out here it's just offal."
1211	'There has to be more,' I said, although I felt little conviction. I
1212	remembered the funeral of His Holiness Pope Urban XV shortly before I
1213	left Pacem. As has been the custom since pre-Heglra days, the corpse
1214	was not embalmed. It waited in the anteroom off the main basilica to be
1215	fitted for the plain wooden coffin. As I helped Edouard and Monsignor
1216	Frey place the vestments on the stiffened corpse I noticed the browning
1217	skin and slackening mouth.
1218	The doctor shrugged and finished the perfunctory autopsy. There was the
1219	briefest of formal inquiries. No suspect was found, no motive put
1220	forward. A description of the murdered man was sent to Keats but the
1221	man himself was buried the next day in a pauper's field between the mud
1222	flats and the yellow jungle.
1223	Port Romance is a jumble of yellow, weirwood structures set on a maze of
1224	scaffolds and planks stretching far out onto the tidal mud flats at the
1225	mouth of the Kans.
1226	The river is almost two kilometers wide here where it spills out into
1227	Toschahai Bay, but only a few channels are navigable and the dredging
1228	goes on day and night. !
1229	lie awake each night in my cheap room with the window open to the
1230	pounding of the dredge-hammer sounding like the booming of this vile
1231	city's heart, the distant susurration of the surf its wet breathing.
1232	Tonight I listen to the city breathe and cannot help but give it the
1233	flayed face of the murdered man.
1234	The companies keep a skimmerport on the edge of town to ferry men and
1235	matriel inland to the larger plantations, but I do not have enough money
1236	to bribe my way aboard. Rather, I could get myself aboard but cannot
1237	afford to transport my three trunks of medical and scientific gear. I
1238	am still tempted. My service among the Bikura seems more absurd and
1239	irrational now than ever before. Only my strange need for a destination

1242	There is a riverboat departing up the Kans in two days. I have booked
1243	passage and will move my trunks onto it tomorrow. It will not be hard

1245	Day 4I:
1246	The Emporotic Girandole continues its slow progress upriver. No sight
1247	of human habitation since we left Melton's Landing two days ago. The
1248	jungle presses down to the riverbank like a solid wall now; more, it
1249	almost completely overhangs us in places where the river narrows to
1250	thirty or forty meterS. The light itself is yellow, rich as liquid
1251	butter, filtered as it is through foliage and fronds eighty meters above
1252	the brown surface of the Kans. I sit on the rusted tin roof of the
1253	center passenger barge and strain to make out my first glimpse of a
1254	tesla tree. Old Kady sitting nearby pauses in his whittling, spits over
1255	the side through a gap in his teeth, and laughs at me. 'Ain't going to
1256	be no flame trees this far down,' he says. 'If they was the forest sure
1257	all hell wouldn't look like this. You got to get up in the Pinions
1258	before you see a tesla. We ain't out of the rain forest yet, Padre."
1259	It rains every afternoon. Actually, rain is too gentle a term for the
1260	deluge that strikes us each day, obscuring the shore, pounding the tin
1261	roofs of the barges with a deafening roar, and slowing our upstream
1262	crawl until it seems we are standing still. It is ns if the river
1263	becomes a vertical torrent each afternoon, a waterfall which the ship
1264	must climb if we are to go on.
1265	The Oirandole is an ancient, flat-bottomed tow with five barges lashed
1266	around it like ragged children clinging to their tired motheris skins.
1267	Three of the two-level barges carry bales of goods to be traded or sold
1268	at the few plantations and settlements along the river. The other two
1269	offer a simulacrum of lodging for the indigenies traveling upriver,
1270	although I suspect that some of the barge's residents are permanent. My
1271	own berth boasts a stained mattress on the floor and lizard-like insects
1272	on the walls.
1273	After the rains everyone gathers on the decks to watch the evening mists
1274	rise from the cooling river. The air 'is very hot and supersaturated
1275	with moisture most of the day now. Old Kady tells me that I have come
1276	too late to make the climb through the rain and flame forests before the
1277	tesla trees become active. We shall see.
1278	Tonight the mists rise like the spirits of all the dead who sleep
1279	beneath the river's dark surface. The last tattered remnants of the
1280	afternoon's cloud cover dissipate through the treetops and color returns
1281	to the world. I watch ns the dense forest shifts from chrome yellow to
1282	a translucent saffron and then slowly fades through ocher to umber to
1283	gloom. Aboard the Girandole, Old Kady lights the lanterns and
1284	candle-globes hanging from the sagging second tier and, as if not to be
1285	outdone, the darkened jungle begins to glow with the faint
1286	phosphorescence of decay while glowbirds and multihued gossamers can be
1287	seen floating from branch to branch in the darker upper regions.
1288	Hyperion's small moon is not visible tonight but this world moves
1289	through more debris than is common for a planet so close to its sun and
1290	the night skies are illuminated by frequent meteor showers. Tonight the
1291	heavens are especially fertile and when we move onto wide sections of
1292	the river we can see a tracery of brilliant meteor trails weaving the
1293	stars together. Their images burn the retina after a while and I look
1294	down at the river only to see the same optic echo there in the dark
1295	waters.
1296	There is a bright glow on the eastern horizon and Old Kady tells me that
1297	this is from the orbital mirrors which give light to a few of the larger
1298	plantations.
1299	It is too warm to return to my cabin. I spread my thin mat on the
1300	rooftop of my barge and watch the celestial light show while clusters of
1301	indigenie families sing haunting songs in an argot I have. not even
1302	tried to learn. I wonder about the Bikura, still far away from here,

1356	Day 82:
1357	After a week on the trail - what trail? - after a week in the
1358	trackless, yellow rain forest, after a week of exhausting climb up the
1359	ever steeper shoulder of the.
1360	Pinion Plateau, we emerged this morning onto a rocky outcropping that
1361	allowed us a view back across an expanse of jungle toward the Beak and
1362	the Middle Sea.
1363	The plateau here is almost three thousand meters above sea level and the
1364	view was impressive. Heavy rain clouds spread out below us to the foot
1365	of the Pinion Hills, but through gaps in the white and gray carpet of
1366	cloud we caught glimpses of the Kans in its leisurely uncoiling toward
1367	Port R. and the sea, chrome-yellow swatches of the forest we had
1368	struggled through, and a hint of magenta far to the east that Tuk swore
1369	was the lower matrix of fiberplastic fields near Perecebo.
1370	We continued onward and upward late into the evening.
1371	Tuk is obviously worried that we will be caught in the flame forests
1372	when the tesla trees become active. I struggle to .keep up, tugging at
1373	the heavily laden 'brid and saying silent prayers to keep my mind off my
1374	aches, pains, and general misgivings.
1375	Day 83:
1376	Loaded and moving before dawn today. The air smells of smoke and ashes.
1377	The change in vegetation here on the Plateau is startling.
1378	No longer evident are the ubiquitous weirwood and leafy chalma. After
1379	passing through an intermediate zone of short evergreens and everblues,
1380	then after climbing again through dense strands of mutated lodgepole
1381	pines and triaspen, we came into the flame forest proper with its groves
1382	of tall prometheus, trailers of ever present phoenix, and round stands
1383	of amber !ambents. Occasionally we encountered impenetrable breaks of
1384	the white-fibrous, bifurcated bestos plants that Tuk picturesquely
1385	referred to as '... looking like de rotting cocks o' some dead giants
1386	what be buried shallow here, dat be sure." My guide has a way with
1387	words.
1388	It was late afternoon before we saw our first tesla tree. For half an
1389	hour we had been trudging over an ash-covered forest floor, trying not
1390	to tread on the tender shoots of phoenix and firewhip gamely pushing up
1391	through the sooty soil, when suddenly Tuk stopped and pointed.
1392	The tesla tree, still half a kilometer away, stood at least a hundred
1393	meters tall, half again as high as the tallest prometheus. Near its
1394	crown it bulged with the distinctive onion-shaped dome of its
1395	accumulator gall.
1396	The radial branches above the gall trailed dozens of nimbus vines, each
1397	looking silver and metallic against the clear green and lapis sky. The
1398	whole thing made me think of some elegant High Muslim mosque on New
1399	Mecca irreverently garlanded with tinsel.
1400	'We got to get de 'brids and our asses de hell out o' here,' grunted
1401	Tuk. He insisted that we change into flame forest gear right then and
1402	there. We spent the rest of the afternoon and evening trudging on in
1403	our osmosis masks and thick, rubber-soled boots, sweating under layers
1404	of leathery gamma-cloth. Both of the 'brids acted nervous, their long
1405	ears pricking at the slightest sound. Even through my mask i could
1406	smell the ozone; it reminded me of electric trains I had played with as
1407	a child oj lazy Christmas Day afternoons in Vi!!efranche-sur-Sa6ne.
1408	We are camping as close as we can to a bestos break this night. Tuk
1409	showed me how to set out the ring of arrestor rods, all the time
1410	clucking dire warnings to himself and searching the evening sky for
1411	clouds.
1412	I plan to sleep well in spite of everything.
1413	Day 84:
1414	0400 hours- Sweet Mother of Christ.
1415	For three hours we have been caught up in the middle of the end of the
1416	world.
1417	The explosions started shortly after midnight, mere lightning crashes at
1418	first, and against our better judgment Tuk and I slid our heads through
1419	the tent flap to watch the pyrotechnics. I am used to the Matthew-month
1420	monsoon storms on Pacem, so the first hour of lightning displays did not
1421	seem too unusual. Only the sight of distant tesla trees as the unerring
1422	focus of the aerial discharge was a bit unnerving. But soon the forest
1423	behemoths were glowing and spitting with their own accumulated energy
1424	and then - just as I was drifting off to sleep despite the continued
1425	noise - true Armageddon was unleashed.
1426	At least a hundred arcs of electricity must have been released in the
1427	first ten seconds of the tesla trees' opening spasms of violent energy.
1428	A prometheus less than thirty meters from us exploded, dropping flaming
1429	brands fifty meters to the forest floor. The arrestor rods glowed,
1430	hissed, and deflected arc after arc of blue-white death over and around
1431	our small campsite. Tuk screamed something but no mere human sound was
1432	audible over the onslaught of light and noise. A patch of trailing
1433	phoenix burst into flame near the tethered 'brids and one of the
1434	terrified animals - hobbled and blindfolded as it was - broke free and
1435	lunged through the circle of glowing arrestor rods. Instantly half a
1436	dozen bolts of lightning from the nearest tesla arced to the hapless
1437	animal. For a mad second l could have sworn !
1438	saw the beast's skeleton glowing through boiling flesh and then it
1439	spasreed high into the air and simply ceased to be.
1440	For three hours we have watched the end of the world.
1441	Two of the arrestor rods have fallen but the other eight continue to
1442	function. Tuk and I huddle in the hot cave of our tent, osmosis masks
1443	filtering enough cool oxygen out of the superheated, smoky air to allow
1444	us to breathe. Only the lack of undergrowth and Tuk's skill in placing
1445	our tent away from other targets and near the sheltering bestos plants
1446	have allowed us to survive. That and the eight whiskered-alloy rods
1447	that stand between us and eternity.
1448	'They seem to be holding up well!" I shout to Tuk over the hiss and
1449	crackle, crash and split of the storm.
1450	'Dey be made to stand de hour, mebbe two,' grunts my guide. 'Any time,
1451	mebbe sooner, dey fuse, we die."
1452	I nod and sip at lukewarm water through the slipstrip of my osmosis
1453	mask. If I survive this night, I shall always thank God for His
1454	generosity in allowing me to see this sight.
1455	Day 8 7:
1456	Tuk and I emerged from the smoldering northeastern edge of the flame
1457	forest at noon yesterday, promptly set up camp by the edge of a small
1458	stream, and slept for eighteen hours straight; making up for three
1459	nights of no sleep and two grueling days moving without rest through a
1460	nightmare of flame and ash. Everywhere we looked as we approached the
1461	hogback ridge that marked the terminus of the forest, we could see
1462	seedpods and cones burst open with new life for the various fire species
1463	that had died in the conflagration of the previous two nights. Five of
1464	our arrestor rods still functioned, although neither Tuk nor l was eager
1465	to test them another night. Our surviving packbrid collapsed and died
1466	the instant the heavy load was lifted off its back.
1467	I awoke this morning at dawn to the sound of running water. I followed
1468	the small stream a kilometer to the northeast, following a deepening in
1469	its sound, until suddenly it dropped from sight.
1470	The Cleft! I had almost forgotten our destination.
1471	This morning, stumbling through the fog, leaping from one wet rock to
1472	another alongside the widening stream, I took a leap to a final boulder,
1473	teetered there, regained my balance, and looked straight down above a
1474	waterfall that dropped almost three thousand meters to mist, rock, and
1475	river far below.
1476	The Cleft was not carved out of the rising plateau as was the legendary
1477	Grand Canyon on Old Earth or World Crack on Hebron. In spite of its
1478	active oceans and seemingly earthlike continents, Hyperion is
1479	tectonically quite dead; more like Mars, Lusus, or Armaghast in its
1480	total lack of continental drift. And like Mars and Lusus, HYperion is
1481	afflicted with its Deep Ice Ages, although here the periodicity is
1482	spread to thirty-seven million years by the long ellipse of the
1483	currently absent binary dwarf. The comlog compares the Cleft to the
1484	pre-tCrraformed Mariner Valley on Mars, both being caused by the
1485	weakening of crust through periodic freeze and thaw over the aeons,
1486	followed by the flow of subterranean rivers such as the Kans. Then the
1487	massive collapse, running like a long scar through the moun-tainons wing
1488	of the continent Aquila.
1489	Tuk joined me as I stood on the edge of the Cleft. I was naked, rinsing
1490	the ash smell from my traveling clothes and cassock. I splashed cold
1491	water over my pale flesh and laughed out loud as the echoes of Tuk's
1492	shouts came back from the North Wall two thirds of a kilometer away.
1493	Because of the nature of the crust collapse, Tuk and I stood far out on
1494	an overhang that hid the South Wall below us. Although perilously
1495	exposed, we assumed that the rocky cornice which had defied gravity for
1496	millions of years would last a few more hours as we bathed, relaxed,
1497	shouted echoing hallos until we were hoarse, and generally acted like
1498	children liberated from school. Tuk confessed that he had never
1499	penetrated the full width of the flame forest- nor known anyone who had
1500	in this season - and announced that, now that the tesla trees were
1501	becoming fully

1575	had first encountered the Cleft. From my vantage point far out over the
1576	river, the view was memorable. Mists rose from unseen waterfalls
1577	tumbling to the river far below, spray rising in shifting curtains of

1579	that many rainbows.
1580	I watched as each spectrum was born, rose toward the darkening dome of
1581	sky, and died. As the cooling air settled into the cracks and caverns
1582	of the plateau and the warm air rushed skyward, pulling leaves, twigs,
1583	and mist upward in a vertical gale, a sound ebbed up out of the Cleft as
1584	if the continent itself was calling with the voices of stone giants,
1585	gigantic bamboo flutes, church organs the size of palaces, the clear,
1586	perfect notes ranging from the shrillest soprano to the deepest bass. I
1587	speculated on wind vectors against the fluted rock wails, on caverns far
1588	below venting deep cracks in the motionless crust, and on the illusion
1589	of human voices that random harmonics can generate. But in the end l
