1591	hymn to the sun.
1592	I walked back to our tent and its circle of biolumi-nescent lantern
1593	light as the first fusillade of meteor showers burned the skies overhead
1594	and distant explosions from the flame forests rippled along the southern
1595	and western horizons like cannon fire from some ancient war on
1596	pre-Hegira Old Earth.
1597	Once in the tent I try the long-range comlog bands but there is nothing
1598	but static. I suspect that even if the primitive comsats that serve the
1599	fiberplastic plantations were ever to broadcast this far east, anything
1600	but the tightest laser or fatline beams would be masked by the mountains
1601	and tesla activity. On Pacem, few of us at the monastery wore or
1602	carried personal comlogs, but the datasphere was always there if we
1603	needed to tap into it. Here there is no choice.
1604	I sit and listen to the last notes from the canyon wind die, watch the
1605	skies simultaneously darken and blaze, smile at the sound of Tuk's
1606	snoring from his bedroll outside the tent, and I think to myself, If
1607	this is exile, so belt.
1608	Day 88:
1609	Tuk is dead. Murdered.
1610	I found his body when I left the tent at sunrise. He had been sleeping
1611	outside, not more than four meters from me. He had said that he wished
1612	to sleep under the stars.
1613	The murderers cut his throat while he slept. I heard no cry. I did
1614	dream, however: dreams of Semfa ministering to me during my fever.
1615	Dreams of cool hands touching my neck and chest, touching the crucifix I
1616	have worn since childhood. I stood over Tuk's body, staring at the
1617	wide, dark circle where his blood had soaked into Hyperion's uncaring
1618	soil, and I shivered at the thought that the dream had been more than a
1619	dream - that hands had touched me in the night.
1620	I confess that I reacted more like a frightened old fool than as a
1621	priest. I did administer Extreme Unction, but then the panic struck me
1622	and I left my poor guide's body, desperately searched through the
1623	supplies for a weapon, and took away the machete I had used in the rain
1624	forest and the low-voltage maser with which I had planned to hunt small
1625	game. Whether I would have used a weapon on a human being, even to save
1626	my own life, I do not know. But, in my panic, I carried the machete,
1627	the maser, and the powered binoculars to a high boulder near the Cleft
1628	and searched the region for any signs of the murderers. Nothing stirred
1629	except the tiny arboreais and gossamers we had seen flitting through the
1630	trees yesterday. The forest itself seemed
1631	abnormally thick and dark. The Cleft offered a hundred terraces,
1632	ledges, and rock balconies to the northeast for entire bands of savages.
1633	An army could have hidden there in the crags and ever present mists.
1634	After-thirty minutes of fruitless vigilance and foolish cowardice, I
1635	returned to the campsite and prepared Tuk's body for burial. It took me
1636	well over two hours to dig a proper grave in the rocky soil of the
1637	plateau.
1638	When it was filled and the formal service was finished, I could think of
1639	nothing personal to say about the rough, funny little man who had been
1640	my guide. 'Watch over him, Lord,' I said at last, disgusted at my own
1641	hypocrisy, sure in my heart that I was mouthing words only to myself.
1642	'Give him safe passage. Amen."
1643	This evening I have moved my camp half a kilometer north. My tent is
1644	pitched in an open area ten meters away but I am wedged with my back
1645	against the boulder, sleeping robes pulled around, the machete and maser
1646	nearby. After Tuk's funeral I went through the supplies and boxes of
1647	equipment. Nothing had been taken except for the few remaining'
1648	arrestor rods.
1649	Immediately I wondered if someone had followed us through the flame
1650	forest in order to kill Tuk and strand me here, but I could think of no
1651	motive for such an elaborate action. Anyone from the plantations could
1652	have killed us as we slept in the rain forest or - better yet from a
1653	murderer's point of view - deep in the flame forest where no one would
1654	wonder at two charred corpses. That left the Bikura. My primitive
1655	charges.
1656	I considered returning through the flame forest without the rods but
1657	soon abandoned the idea. It is probable death to stay and certain death
1658	to go.
1659	Three months before the teslas become dormant. One hundred twenty of
1660	the twenty-six-hour local days. An eternity.
1661	Dear Christ, why has this come to me.9 And why was I spared last night
1662	if I am merely to be offered up this night... or next?
1663	I sit here under the darkening crag and I listen to the suddenly ominous
1664	moaning rising with the night wind
1665	from the Cleft and I pray as the sky lights with the blood-red streaks
1666	of meteor trails.
1667	Mouthing words to myself.
1668	Day 9.5:
1669	The terrors of the past week have largely abated. I find that even fear
1670	fades and becomes commonplace after days of anticlimax.
1671	I used the machete to cut small trees for a lean-to, covering the roof
1672	and side with gamma-cloth and caulking between the logs with mud. The
1673	back wall is the solid stone of the boulder. I have sorted through my
1674	research gear and set some of it out, although I suspect that I will
1675	never use it now.
1676	I have begun foraging to supplement my quickly diminishing cache of
1677	freeze-dried food. By now, according to the absurd schedule drawn up so
1678	long ago on Pacem, I was to have been living with the Bikura for some
1679	weeks and trading small goods for local food. No matter. Besides my
1680	diet of bland but easily boiled chalma roots, I have found half a dozen
1681	varieties of berries and larger fruits that the comlog assures me are
1682	edible; so far only one has disagreed with me enough to keep me
1683	squatting all night near the edge of the nearest ravine.
1684	I pace the confines of the region as restlessly as one of those caged
1685	pelops that were so prized by the minor padishahs on Armaghast. A
1686	kilometer to the south and four to the west, the flame forests are in
1687	full form. In the morning, smoke vies with the shifting curtains of
1688	mist to hide the sky. Only the near-solid breaks of bestos, the rocky
1689	soil here on the summit plateau, and the hogback ridges running like
1690	armor-plated vertebrae northeast from here keep the teslas at bay.
1691	To the north, the plateau widens out and the undergrowth becomes denser
1692	near the Cleft for some fifteen kilometers until the way is blocked by a
1693	ravine a third as deep and half as wide as the Cleft itself. Yesterday
1694	I reached this northernmost point and stared across the
1695	gaping barrier with some frustration. I will try again someday,
1696	detouring to the east to find a crossing point, but from the telltale
1697	signs of phoenix across the chasm and the pall of smoke along the
1698	northeastern horizon, I suspect I will find only the chalma-fi!led
1699	canyons and steppes of flame forest that are roughed in on the orbital
1700	survey map I carry.
1701	Tonight I visited Tuk's rocky grave as the evening wind began to wail
1702	its aeolian dirge. I knelt there and tried to pray but nothing came.
1703	Edouard, nothing came. I am as empty as those fake sarcophagi that you
1704	and I unearthed by the score from the sterile desert sands near Tarum
1705	bel Wadi.
1706	The Zen Gnostics would say that this emptiness is a good sign; that it
1707	presages openness to a new level of
1708	awareness, new insights, new experience.
1709	Merde.
1710	My emptiness is only... emptiness.
1711	I have found the Bikura. Or, rather, they have found me. I will write
1712	what I can before they come to rouse me from my 'sleep."
1713	Today I was doing some detail mapping a mere four kilometers north of
1714	camp when the mists lifted in the midday warmth and I noticed a series
1715	of terraces on my side of the Cleft that had been hidden until then. I
1716	was using my powered glasses to inspect the terraces - actually a series
1717	of !addered ledges, spires, shelves, and tussocks extending far out onto
1718	the overhang - when i realized that I was staring at man-made
1719	habitations.
1720	The dozen or so huts were crude- rough hovels of heaped chalma fronds,
1721	stones, and spongeturf- but they were unmistakably of human origin.
1722	I was standing there irresolute, binoculars still lifted, trying to
1723	decide whether to climb down to the exposed ledges and confront the
1724	inhabitants or to retreat to my camp, when I felt that lifting chill
1725	along the back and neck that tells one with absolute certainty that he
1726	is no
1727	longer alone. I. lowered the binoculars and turned slowly. The Bikura
1728	were there, at least thirty of them, standing in a semi-circle that left
1729	me no retreat to the forest.
1730	I do not know what I expected; naked savages, perhaps, with fierce
1731	expressions and necklaces of teeth.
1732	Perhaps I had half expected to find the kind of bearded, wild-haired
1733	hermits that travelers sometimes encountered in the Mosh6 Mountains on
1734	Hebron. Whatever I had held in mind, the reality of the Bikura did not
1735	fit the template.
1736	The people who had approached me so silently were short - none came
1737	higher than my shoulder - and swathed in roughly woven dark robes that
1738	covered them from neck to toe. When they moved, as some did now, they
1739	seemed to glide over the rough ground like wraiths.
1740	From a distance, their appearance reminded me of nothing so much as a
1741	gaggle of diminutive Jesuits at a New Vatican enclave.
1742	I almost giggled then, but realized that such a response might well be a
1743	sign of rising panic. The Bikura showed no outward signs of aggression
1744	to cause such a panic; they carried no weapons, their small hands were
1745	empty. As empty as their expressions.
1746	Their physiognomy is hard to describe succinctly.
1747	They are bald. All of them. That baldness, the absence of any facial
1748	hair, and the loose robes that fell in a straight line to the ground,
1749	all conspired to make it very difficult to tell the men from the women.
1750	The group now confronting me- more than fifty by this time - looked to
1751	be all of roughly the same age: somewhere between forty and fifty
1752	standard years. Their faces were smooth, the skin tinged with a
1753	yellowish cast that I guessed might be associated with generations of
1754	ingesting trace minerals in the chalma and other local plant life.
1755	One might be tempted to describe the round faces of the Bikura as
1756	cherubic until, upon closer inspection, that impression of sweetness
1757	fades and is replaced by another interpretation- placid idiocy. As a
1758	priest, I have spent enough time on backward worlds to see the
1759	effects of an ancient genetic disorder variously called Down's syndrome,
1760	mongolism, or generation-ship legacy. This, then, was the overall
1761	impression created by the sixty or so dark-robed little people who had
1762	approached me - I was being greeted by a silent, smiling band of bald,
1763	retarded children.
1764	I reminded myself that these were almost certainly the same group of
1765	'smiling children' who had slit Tuk's throat while he slept and left him
1766	to die like a butchered pig.

1768	something in a soft monotone.

2629	But they did.
2630	Within thirty seconds I began to sense a roseate glow, dim at first,
2631	then ever richer until the cave was brighter than the canyon had been,
2632	brighter than Pacem under the glow of its triune moons. The light came
2633	from a hundred sources- a thousand sources. I was able to make out the
2634	nature of these sources just as the Bikura dropped reverently to their
2635	knees.
2636	The cave walls and ceiling were encrusted with crosses ranging in size
2637	from a few millimeters to almost a meter long. Each glowed with a deep,
2638	pink light of its own.
2639	Invisible in the torchlight, these glowing crosses now suffused the
2640	tunnel with light. I approached one embedded in the wall nearest me.
2641	Thirty or so centimeters across, it pulsed with a soft, organic flow.
2642	This was not something that had been carved out of stone or attached to
2643	the wall; it was definitely organic, definitely alive, resembling soft
2644	coral. It was slightly warm to the touch.
2645	There came the slightest whisper of sound - no, not sound, a disturbance
2646	in the cool air, perhaps - and I turned in time to see something enter
2647	the chamber.
2648	The Bikura were still kneeling, their heads down, eyes lowered. I
2649	remained standing. My gaze never left the thing which moved among the
2650	kneeling Bikura.
2651	It was vaguely man-shaped but in no way human. It stood at least three
2652	meters tall. Even when it was at rest, the silvered surface of the
2653	thing seemed to shift and flow like mercury suspended in midair. The
2654	reddish glow from the crosses set into the tunnel walls reflected from
2655	sharp surfaces and glinted on the curved metal blades protruding from
2656	the thing's forehead, four wrists, oddly jointed elbows, knees, armored
2657	back, and thorax. It flowed between the kneeling Bikura, and when it
2658	extended four long arms, hands extended but fingers clicking into place
2659	like chrome scalpels, I was absurdly reminded of His Holiness on Pacem
2660	offering a benediction to the faithful.
2661	I had no doubt that I was looking at the legendary Shrike.
2662	At that moment I must have moved or made a sound, for large red eyes
2663	turned my way and I found myself hypnotized by the dance of light within
2664	the multifaceted prisms there: not merely reflected light but a fierce,
2665	blood-bright glow which seemed to burn within the creature's barbed
2666	skull and pulse in the terrible gems set where God meant eyes to be.
2667	Then it moved ... or, rather, it did not move but ceased being there
2668	and was here, leaning less than a meter from me, its oddly jointed arms
2669	encircling me in a fence of body-blades and liquid silver steel. Panting
2670	hard but unable to take a breath, I saw my own reflection, face white
2671	and distorted, dancing across the surface of the thing's metallic shell
2672	and burning eyes.
2673	I confess that I felt something closer to exaltation than fear.
2674	Something inexplicable was happening. Forged in Jesuit logic and
2675	tempered in the cold bath of science, !
2676	nevertheless understood at that second the ancient obsession of the
2677	God-fearing for another kind of fear: the thrill of exorcism, the
2678	mindless whirl of Dervish possession, the puppet-dance ritual of Tarot,
2679	and the almost erotic surrender of sance, speaking in tongues, and Zen
2680	Gnostic trance. I realized at that instant just
2681	how surely the affirmation of demons or the summoning of Satan somehow
2682	can affirm the reality of their mystic antithesis - the God of Abraham.
2683	Thinking none of this but feeling all of it, I awaited the embrace of
2684	the Shrike with the imperceptible tremble of a virgin bride.
2685	It disappeared.
2686	There was no thunderclap, no sudden smell of brimstone, not even a
2687	scientifically sound inrush of air. One second the thing was there,
2688	surrounding me with its beautiful certainty of sharp-edged death, and
2689	the next instant it was gone.
2690	Numbed, I stood there and blinked as Alpha rose and approached me in the
2691	Bosch-tinted gloom. He stood where the Shrike had stood, his own arms
2692	extended in a pathetic imitation of the deadly perfection I had just
2693	witnessed, but there was no sign on Alpha's bland, Bikura face that he
2694	had seen the creature. He made an awkward, open-handed gesture which
2695	seemed to include the labyrinth, cave wall, and scores of glowing
2696	crosses embedded there.
2697	'Cruciform,' said Alpha. The Three Score and Ten rose, came closer, and
2698	knelt again. I looked at their placid faces in the soft light and I
2699	also knelt.
2700	'You will follow the cross all of your days,' said Alpha, and his voice
2701	carried the cadence of litany. The rest of the Bikura repeated the
2702	statement in a tone just short of a chant.
2703	'You wR! be of the cruciform all of your days,' said Alpha, and as the
2704	others repeated this he reached out and pulled a small cruciform away
2705	from the cave wall. It was not more than a dozen centimeters long and
2706	it came away from the wall with the faintest of snaps. Its glow faded
2707	even as I watched. Alpha removed a small thong from his robe, tied it
2708	around small knobs at the top of the cruciform, and held the cross above
2709	my head. 'You
2710	will be of the cruciform now and forever,' he said.
2711	'Now and forever,' echoed the Bikura.
2712	'Amen,' I whispered.
2713	Beta signaled that I should open the front of my robe.
2714	Alpha lowered the-small cross until it hung around my
2715	neck. It eit cool against my chest; the back of it was perfectly flat,
2716	perfectly smooth.
2717	The Bikura stood and wandered toward the cave entrance, apparently
2718	apathetic and indifferent once again. I watched them leave and then I
2719	gingerly touched the cross, lifted and inspected it. The cruciform was
2720	cool, inert. If it had truly been living a few seconds earlier, it
2721	showed no sign of it now. It continued to feel more like coral than
2722	crystal or rock; there was no sign of any adhesive material on the
2723	smooth back of it. I speculated on photochemical effects that would
2724	have created the luminescent quality. I speculated on natural phos-
2725	phors, bioluminescence, and on the chances that evolution would shape
2726	such things. I speculated on what, if anything, their presence here had
2727	to do with the labyrinth and on the aeons necessary to raise this
2728	plateau so the river and canyon could slice through one of the tunnels.
2729	I speculated on the basilica and its makers, on the Bikura, on the
2730	Shrike, and on myself. Eventually I ceased speculating and closed my
2731	eyes to pray.
2732	When I emerged from the cave, the cruciform cool against my chest under
2733	the robe, the Three Score and Ten were .obviously ready to begin the
2734	three-kilometer climb up the staircase. I looked up to'see a pale slash
2735	of morning sky between the walls of the Cleft.
2736	'No!" I shouted, my voice almost lost against the roar of the river. 'I
2737	need rest. Rest!" I sank to my knees on the sand but half a dozen of
2738	the Bikura approached, pulled me gently to my feet, and moved me toward
2739	the staircase.
2740	I tried, the Lord knows that I tried, but two or three hours into the
2741	climb I felt my legs give way and I collapsed, sliding across the rock,
2742	unable to stop my six-hundred-meter fall to the rocks and river. I
2743	remember grasping at the cruciform under the thick robe and then half a
2744	dozen hands stopped my slide, lifted me, carried me. Then I remember no
2745	more.
2746	Until this morning. I woke to a sunrise pouring light through the
2747	opening of my hut. I wore only the robe and a touch assured me that the
2748	cruciform was still hanging from its fibrous thong. As I watched the
2749	sun lift over the
2750	forest, I realized that I had lost a day, that somehow I had slept
2751	through not only my ascent up that endless staircase (how could these
2752	little people carry me two and a half vertical kilometers?) but through
2753	the next day and night as well·
2754	I looked around my hut. My comlog and other recording devices were
2755	gone. Only my medscanner and a few packets of anthropological software
2756	made useless by the destruction of my other equipment remained. I shook
2757	my head and went up to the stream to wash.
2758	The Bikura appeared to be sleeping. Now that I had participated in
2759	their ritual and 'become of the cruciform,' they seemed to have lost
2760	interest in me. As I stripped to bathe, I decided to take no interest
2761	in them. I decided that I would leave as soon as I was strong enough. I
2762	would find a way around the flame forests if necessary. I could descend
2763	the staircase and follow the Kans if I had to. I knew more than ever
2764	that word of these miraculous artifacts had to be brought to the outside
2765	world.
2766	I pulled off the heavy robe, stood pale and shivering in the morning
2767	light, and went to lift the small cruciform from my chest.
2768	It did not come off.
2769	It lay there as if it were part of my flesh. I pulled, scraped, and
2770	tore at the thong until it snapped and fell away. I clawed at the
2771	cross-shaped lump on my chest. It did not come off. It was as if my
2772	flesh had sealed itself around the edges of the cruciform. Except for
2773	the scratches from my fingernails, there was no pain or physical
2774	sensation in the cruciform or surrounding flesh, only sheer terror in my
2775	soul at the thought of this thing attached to me. After the first rush
2776	of panic subsided, I sat a minute and then hastily pulled on my robe and
2777	ran back to the village.
2778	My knife was gone, my maser, scissors, razor - everything that might
2779	have helped me peel back the growth on my chest. My nails left bloody
2780	tracks across the red welt and my chest. Then I remembered the
2781	medscanner. I passed the transceiver over my chest, read the diskey
2782	display, shook my head in disbelief, and then ran an entire body scan.
2783	After a while I keyed in a request for hard copies of the scan results
2784	and sat motionless for a very long time..
2785	I sit here now holding the image wafers. The cruciform is quite visible
2786	on both the sonic and k-cross images ·.. as are the internal fibers
2787	that spread like thin tentacles, like roots, throughout my body.
2788	Excess ganglia radiate from a thick nucleus above my sternum to
2789	filaments everywhere- a nightmare of nematodes. As well as I can tell
2790	with my simple field scanner, the nematodes terminate in the amygdala
2791	and other basal ganglia in each cerebral hemisphere. My temperature,
2792	metabolism, and !ymphocyte level are normal.
2793	There has been no invasion of foreign tissue.
2794	According to the scanner, the nematodic filaments are the result of
2795	extensive but simple metastasis. According to the scanner, the
2796	cruciform itself is composed of familiar tissue... the DNA is mine.
2797	I am of the cruciform.
2798	Day II6:

2804	At first I could not believe this. I had resolved to enter the flame

2831	Day liT:
2832	The Bikura are sexless. Not celibate or herma-phroditic or undeveloped
2833	- sexless. They are as devoid of external or internal genitalia as a
2834	child's flowfoam doll. There is no evidence that the penis or testes or
2835	comparable female organs have atrophied or been surgically altered.
2836	There is no sign that they ever existed.
2837	Urine is conducted through a primitive urethra terminating in a small
2838	chamber contiguous with the anus - a sort of crude cloaca.
2839	Beta allowed the examination. The reedscanner confirmed what my eyes
2840	would not believe. Del and Theta also agreed to be scanned. I have
2841	absolutely no doubt that the rest of the Three Score and Ten are equally
2842	sexless. There is no sign that they have been... altered.
2843	i would suggest that they had all been born that way but from what kind

2850	Day I33:
2851	Alpha is dead.
2852	I was with him three mornings ago when he fell. We were about three
2853	kilometers east, hunting for chalma tubers in the large boulders near
2854	the edge of the Cleft. It had been raining most of the past two days
2855	and the rocks were quite slippery. I looked up from my own scrambling
2856	just in time to see Alpha lose his footing and go sliding down a broad
2857	slab of stone, over the edge. He did not shout. The only sound was the
2858	rasp of his robe against the rock, followed several seconds later by the
2859	sickening dropped-melon sound of his body striking a ledge eighty meters
2860	below.
2861	It took me an hour to find a route down to him. Even before I began the
2862	treacherous descent I knew it was too late to help. But it was my duty.
2863	Alpha's body was half wedged between two large rocks. He must have died
2864	instantly; his arms and legs were splintered and the right side of his
2865	skull had been crushed. Blood and brain tissue clung to the wet rock

2867	body. I do not know why I wept, but I did. And as l wept I
2868	administered Extreme Unction and prayed that God would accept the soul
2869	of this poor, sexless little person. Later I wrapped the body in vines,
2870	laboriously climbed the eighty meters of cliff, and - pausing frequently

2872	There was little interest as I carried the body of Alpha into the Bikura
2873	village. Eventually Beta and half a dozen
2874	others wandered over to stare down indifferently at the corpse. No one

2882	'Burying him." I was too tired to say more. I leaned against a thick

2901	quickly pulled. my hand
2902	away. The cruciform was warm.
2903	'Stand away."

2937	Once, years ago in school, I saw a time-lapse holo showing the
2938	decomposition of a kangaroo mouse. A week's slow work of nature's
2939	recycling had been accelerated to thirty seconds of horror. There was

3044	Day 2I4:
3045	The last ten pages should have covered all of my field notes and

3048	There is no doubt that I have discovered the ultimate in stagnant human

3051	Edouard, I have spent-so many hours wrestling with my faith - my lack of

3061	world, like the too small
3062	sun or the green and lapis sky. Pain has become my ally, my guardian
3063	angel, my remaining link with humanity.
3064	The cruciform does not like pain. Nor do I but, like the cruciform, I
3065	am willing to use it to serve my purposes.
3066	And I will do so consciously, not instinctively like the mindless mass
3067	of alien tissue embedded in me. This thing only seeks a mindless
3068	avoidance of death by any means.
3069	I do not wish to die, but I welcome pain and death rather than an
3070	eternity of mindless life. Life is sacred - I still 'hold to that as a
3071	core element of the Church's thought and teachings these past
3072	twenty-eight hundred years when life has been so cheap - but even more
3073	sacred is the soul.
3074	I realize now that what I was trying to do with the Armaghast data was
3075	offer the Church not a rebirth but only a transition to a false life
3076	such as these poor walking corpses inhabit. If the Church is meant to
3077	die, it must do so - but do so gloriously, in the full knowledge of its
3078	rebirth in Christ. It must go into the darkness not willingly but well
3079	- bravely and firm of faith - like the millions who have gone before us,
3080	keeping faith with all those generations facing death in the isolated
3081	silence of death camps and nuclear fireballs and cancer wards and
3082	pogroms, going into the darkness, if not hopefully, then prayerfully
3083	that there is some reason for it all, something worth the price of all
3084	that pain, all those sacrifices.
3085	All those before us have gone into the darkness without assurance of
3086	logic or fact or persuasive theory, with only a slender thread of hope
3087	or the all too shakable conviction of faith. And if they have been able
3088	to sustain that slim hope in the face of darkness, then so must I... and
3089	so must the Church.
3090	! no longer believe that any surgery or treatment can cure me of this
3091	thing that infests me, but if someone can separate it and study it and
3092	destroy it, even at the cost of my death, l will be well satisfied.
3093	The flame forests are as quiet as they will ever be. To bed now. I
3094	leave before dawn.

3103	the Cleft. I would turn away, walk a kilometer, crawl fifty meters,

3109	There is no hope now unless someone comes looking for me.

4063	THE SOLDIER'S TALE: The War Lovers
4064	It was during the Battle of Agincourt that Fedmahn Kassad encountered
4065	the woman he would spend the rest of his life seeking.
4066	It was a wet and chilly late October morning in A.D.
4067	I4I5. Kassad had been inserted as an archer into the army of Henry V of
4068	England. The English force had been on French soil since August I4 and
4069	had been retreating from superior French forces since October 8.
4070	Henry had convinced his War Council that the army could bent the French
4071	in a forced march to the safety of Calais. They had failed. Now, as
4072	October 25 dawned gray and drizzly, seven thousand Englishmen, mostly
4073	bowmen, faced a force of some twenty-eight thousand French men-at-arms
4074	across a kilometer of muddy field. '
4075	Kassad was cold, tired sick, and scared. He and the other archers had
4076	been surviving on little more than scavenged berries for the past week
4077	of the march and almost every man on the line that morning was suffering
4078	from diarrhea. The air temperature was in the low fifties Fahrenheit
4079	and Kassad had spent a long night trying to sleep on damp ground. He
4080	was impressed with the unbelievable realism of the experience- the
4081	Olympus Command School Historical Tactical Network was as far beyond
4082	regular stimsims as full-form holos were beyond tintypes - but the
4083	physical sensations were so convincing, so real, that Kassad did not
4084	relish the thought of being wounded. There were tales of cadets
4085	receiving fatal wounds in the OCS:HTN sims and being pulled dead from
4086	their immersion creches.
4087	Kassad and the other bowmen on Henry's right flank had been staring at
4088	the larger French force for most of the morning when pennants waved, the
4089	fifteenth-century equivalent of sergeants brayed, and the archers obeyed
4090	the King's command and began marching against the
4091	enemy. The ragged English line, stretching about seven hundred meters
4092	across the field from treeline to treeline, consisted of clusters of
4093	archers like Kassad's troop interspersed with smaller groups of
4094	men-at-arms. The English had no formal cavalry and most of the horses
4095	Kassad could see on his end of the field were carrying men clustered
4096	near the King's command group three hundred meters toward the center, or
4097	huddled around the Duke of York's position much closer to where Kassad
4098	and the other archers stood near the right flank. These command groups
4099	reminded Kassad of a FORCE:ground mobile staff HQ, only instead of the
4100	inevitable forest of comm antennae giving away their position, bright
4101	banners and pennants hung limp on pikes. An obvious artillery target,
4102	thought Kassad, and then reminded himself that this particular military
4103	nuance did not yet exist.
4104	Kassad noticed that the French had plenty of horses.
4105	He estimated six or seven hundred mounted men formed in ranks on each of
4106	the French flanks and a long line of cavalry behind the main battle
4107	line. Kassad did not like horses. He had seen holos and pictures, of
4108	course, but he had not encountered the animals themselves until this
4109	exercise, and the size, smell, and sound of them tended to be unnerving
4110	- especially so when the damn quadrupeds were armored chest and head,
4111	shod in steel, and trained to carry armored men wielding four meters of
4112	lance.
4113	The English advance halted. Kassad estimated that his battle line was
4114	about two hundred and fifty meters from the French. He knew from the
4115	experience of the past week that this was within longbow range, but he
4116	also knew that he would have to pull his arm half out of its socket to
4117	hold the pull.
4118	The French were shouting what Kassad assumed were insults. He ignored
4119	them as he and his silent comrades stepped forward from where they had
4120	planted their long arrows and found soft ground in which to drive their
4121	stakes. The stakes were long and heavy and Kassad had been carrying his
4122	for a week. Almost a meter and a half long, the clumsy thing had been
4123	sharpened at both ends.
4124	When the order first came down for all archers to find saplings and cut
4125	stakes, somewhere in the deep woods
4126	just after they had crossed the Somme, Kassad had wondered idly what the
4127	things were for. Now he knew.
4128	Every third archer carried a heavy mallet nnd now they took tums driving
4129	their stakes in at a careful angle.
4130	Kassad pulled out his long knife, resharpened the end which, even
4131	leaning, rose almost to his chest, and stepped back through the hedgehog
4132	of sharpened stakes to await the French charge.
4133	The French did not charge.
4134	Kassad waited with the others. His bow was strung, forty-eight arrows
4135	were planted in two clusters at his
4136	feet, and his feet were set properly.
4137	The French did not charge.
4138	The rain had stopped but a cool breeze had come up and what little body
4139	heat Kassad had generated by the short march and the task of driving
4140	stakes had been lost quickly. The only sounds were the metallic
4141	shufflings of men and horses, occasional mutterings or nervous laughs,
4142	and the heavier thud of hooves as the French cavalry rearranged itself
4143	but still refused to charge.
4144	'Fuck this,' said a gri,.led yeoman a few feet from Kassad. 'Those
4145	bastards've wasted our whole bleeding morning. They'd better piss or
4146	get off the pot."
4147	Kassad nodded. He was not sure if he was hearing and understanding
4148	Middle English or if the sentence had been in simple Standard. He had
4149	no idea if the grizzled archer was another Command School cadet, an
4150	instructor, or merely an artifact of the sire. He could not guess if
4151	the slang had been correct. He did not care. His heart was pounding
4152	and his palms were sweaty. He wiped his hands on his jerkin.
4153	As if King Henry had taken his cue from the old man's muttering, command
4154	flags suddenly bobbed and rose, sergeants screamed, and row upon row of
4155	English archers raised their longbows, pulled when commands were
4156	shouted, released on the next command.
4157	Four waves of arrows comprised of more than six thousand meter-long,
4158	chisel-pointed, clothyard missiles rose, seemed to hang in a cloud
4159	thirty meters up, and fell on the French.
4160	There came the sound of horses screaming and a
4161	thousand demented children pounding on ten thousand tin pots as the
4162	French men-at-arms leaned into the rain of arrows to let their steel
4163	helmets and their chest and shoulder armor take the brunt of the
4164	downpour. Kassad knew that in military terms little real damage had
4165	been done, but this was small solace to the occasional French soldier
4166	with ten inches of arrow through his eye, or to the scores of horses
4167	leaping, tumbling, and crashing into one another while their riders
4168	struggled to remove wooden
4169	shafts from the creatures' backs and flanks.
4170	The French did not charge.
4171	More commands were shouted. Kassad raised, read-led, loosed his arrow.
4172	Again. And again. The sky darkened every ten seconds. Kassad's arm
4173	and back ached from the punishing rhythm. He found that he felt neither
4174	elation nor anger. He was doing his job. His forearm was raw. Again
4175	the arrows flew. And again. Fifteen of his first sheaf of twenty-four
4176	arrows were gone when a cry went up along the English line and Kassad
4177	paused and glanced down while holding full pull.
4178	The French were charging.
4179	A cavalry charge was something beyond Kassad's experience.
4180	Watching twelve hundred armored horses charging directly at him created
4181	internal sensations which Kassad found a bit unnerving. The charge took
4182	less than forty seconds but Kassad discovered that this was ample time
4183	for his mouth to go absolutely dry, his breathing to begin to have
4184	problems, and for his testicles to retreat completely into his body. If
4185	the rest of Kassad could have found a comparable hiding place, he would
4186	have seriously considered crawling into it.
4187	As it was, he was too busy to run.
4188	Firing on command, his line of archers got off five flat volleys at the
4189	attacking horsemen, managed one more shot in independent fire, and then
4190	they fell back five paces.
4191	Horses, it turned out, were too smart to willingly impale themselves
4192	upon stakes- no matter how hard their human riders implored them to do
4193	so- but the second and third waves of cavalry did not stop as
4194	abruptly as the first, and in a single mad moment horses were down and
4195	screaming, riders were thrown and screaming, and Kassad was out and
4196	screaming, rushing at every downed Frenchman he could see, wielding a
4197	mallet on the prostrate form when he could, slashing through gaps in
4198	armor with his long knife when it was too crowded to swing the mallet.
4199	Soon he and the grizzled archer and a younger man who had lost his cap
4200	became an efficient killing team, closing in on a downed rider from
4201	three sides, Kassad using the mallet to knock the pleading horseman off
4202	his knees, then all three moving in with their blades.
4203	Only one knight gained his feet and raised a sword to confront them. The
4204	Frenchman flipped up his visor and called out a clear request for honor
4205	and single combat.
4206	The old man and the youth circled like wolves. Kassad returned with his
4207	bow and put an arrow into the knight's left eye from ten paces.
4208	The battle continued in the deadly comic-opera vein common to all armed
4209	combat since the first rock and thighbone duels on Old Earth. The
4210	French cavalry managed to turn and flee just as the first wave of ten
4211	thousand men-at-arms charged the English center on foot.
4212	The melee broke up the rhythm of the attack and, by the time the French
4213	had regained their initiative, Henry's own men-at-arms had braced to
4214	hold them at pike length while Kassad and several thousand other archers
4215	poured volley fire into the massed French infantry at close range.
4216	That did not end the battle. It was not necessarily even the decisive
4217	moment. The turning point, when it came, was lost - as all such moments
4218	are - within the dust and turmoil of a thousand individual encounters
4219	where infantrymen faced infantrymen across the distance of their
4220	personal weapons. Before it was over some three hours later there would
4221	be minor variations on repeated themes, ineffective thrusts and clumsy
4222	counterthrusts, and a less than honorable moment when Henry would order
4223	prisoners killed rather than leave them in the rear when the English
4224	were confronted with a new threat. But the heralds and historians would
4225	later agree that the
4226	outcome had been sealed somewhere in the confusion during the first
4227	French infantry charge. The French died in their thousands. English
4228	dominion on that part of the Continent would continue for a while. The
4229	day of the armored man-at-arms, the knight, the embodiment of ·
4230	chivalry, was over - hammered into history's coffin by a few thousand
4231	ragtag peasant archers carrying longbows.
4232	The ultimate insult to the noble-born French dead - if the dead indeed
4233	could be further insulted - lay in the fact that the English archers
4234	were not only common men, common in the lowest, most flea-infested sense

4236	Grunts. AIPs. Spezzes. K-techs. Jump Rats.
4237	But all that was in the lesson Kassad was supposed to have learned
4238	during the OCS:HTN exercise. He learned none of it. He was too busy
4239	having an encounter which would change his life.
4240	The French man-at-arms went over the head of his falling horse, rolled
4241	once, and was up and running for the woods before the mud quit flying.
4242	Kassad followed. He was halfway to the tree line before he realized

4246	The man-at-arms, who had just been thrown to the ground from a horse
4247	moving at full gallop and who was wearing sixty pounds of clumsy armor,

4249	glanced back once, saw Kassad coming on a full run with a mallet in his

4253	gasped, and considered his position.
4254	Thuds, screams, and crashes from the battlefield behind him were muffled

4256	The trees were almost bare and still dripped from the rainstorm the
4257	night before; the floor of the forest was carpeted with a thick layer of

4259	a trail of
4260	broken branches and footprints for the first twenty meters or so, but
4261	now deer trails and overgrown paths made it difficult to see where he
4262	had passed.
4263	Kassad moved slowly, stepping deeper into the woods, trying to be alert
4264	for any noise above the sound of his own panting and the insane pounding

4266	not a brilliant move; the man-at-arms had been wearing full armor and

4269	and remember his years of combat training. Kassad also had been
4270	trained. He looked down at his cloth shirt and leather vest. The
4271	mallet was still in his hands, the knife in his broad belt. He had been

4294	never get inside the arc of sword blade. His only hope was in running,

4298	Nor from below as he climbed. Kassad did not wish to be cut down from
4299	any angle.

4779	thousand volunteers, a respectable oceangoing navy, and a store of
4780	nuclear weapons stockpiled purely for symbolic purposes.
4781	The Ouster Hawking wake had been noticed by Hegemony monitoring stations
4782	but was misinterpreted as merely another swarm migration which would
4783	pass no closer than half a light-year to the Bressian system.
4784	Instead, with a single course correction which was not detected until
4785	the swarm was within the O6rt cloud radius, the Ousters fell on Bressia

4789	fighting. The Ouster swarm then put more than three thousand ships into
4790	Bressia's cislunar space and began the systematic reduction of all
4791	planetary defenses.
4792	The world had been settled by no-nonsense Central Europeans in the first
4793	wave of the Hegira, and its two continents bore the prosaic names of
4794	North Bressia and
4795	South Bressia. North Bressia held desert, high tundra, and six major
4796	cities housing mostly burr-root harvesters and petroleum engineers.
4797	South Bressia, much more temperate in climate and geography, was the
4798	home for most of the world's four hundred million people and the huge
4799	coffee plantations.
4800	As if to demonstrate what war had once been about, the Ousters scoured
4801	North Bressia - first with several hundred fallout-free nuclear weapons
4802	and tactical plasma bombs, then with deathbeams, and finally with
4803	tailored viruses. Only a handful of the fourteen million residents
4804	escaped. South Bressia received no bombardment except for the lancing
4805	of specific military targets, airports, and the large harbor at Solno.
4806	FORCE doctrine held that, while a world could be reduced from orbit,
4807	actual military invasion of an industrialized planet was an
4808	impossibility; the problems with landing logistics, the immense area to
4809	be occupied, and the unwieldy size of the invading army were considered
4810	to be the ultimate arguments against invasion.
4811	The Ousters obviously had not read the FORCE doctrine books. On the
4812	twenty-third day of the investiture, more than two thousand dropships
4813	and assault boats fell on South Bressia. What was left of the Bressian
4814	air force was destroyed in those first hours of the invasion. Two
4815	nuclear' devices were actually detonated against Ouster staging areas:
4816	the first was deflected by energy fields and the second destroyed a
4817	single scoutship which may have been a decoy.
4818	Ousters, it turned out, had changed physically in three centuries. They
4819	did prefer zero-gravity environments.
4820	But their mobile infantry's powered exoskeletons served very well and it
4821	was only, a matter of days before the black-clad, Iong-limbed Ouster
4822	troops were swarming over South Bressia's cities like an infestation of
4823	giant spiders.
4824	The last organized resistance collapsed on the nineteenth day of the
4825	invasion. Buckminster, the capital, fell the same day. The last
4826	fatline message from Bressia to the Hegemony was cut off in
4827	mid-transmission an hour after Ouster troops entered the city.
4828	Colonel Fedmahn Kassad arrived with FORCE Fleet One twenty-nine standard

4830	farcaster-equipped JumpShip penetrated the system at high speed. The
4831	singularity sphere was activated three hours after spin-down and ten
4832	hours after that there were four hundred FORCE ships of the line in
4833	system. The counterinvasion began twenty-one hours later.
4834	Those were the mathematics of the first minutes of the Battle of

4855	was on.
4856	From his first minutes on South Bressia, Kassad realized that the New
4857	Bushido was dead. Eighty thousand superbly armed and trained
4858	FORCE:ground troops advanced from their staging areas, seeking battle in
4859	an unpopulated place. Ouster forces retreated behind a line

4870	What had been. forecast as a two-day battle ground on for thirty days,
4871	then sixty. Warfare had been thrown back to the twentieth or
4872	twenty-first century: long, grim campaigns fought through the brick dust

4881	Kassad had understood the change of tactics almost at once. His
4882	street-fighting instincts had risen to the forefront even before most of
4883	his division was wiped out in the Battle of the Stoneheap. While other
4884	FORCE commanders were all but ceasing to function, frozen into

4893	And Kassad dreamed of her with dreams that were more - and less - than

4990	Kassad pulled himself up just as the boom arm quit spinning and 'up'

5000	blocked the seal from closing. Kassad rolled through into the boom-arm
