6065	day and night. Now he asked, his voice as careful and unslurred as only
6066	a true alcoholic's can be, whose turn it was to tell a tale.
6067	'Mine,' said Martin Silenus. The poet also had been drinking steadily
6068	since early in the day. His voice was as carefully controlled as the
6069	Consul's but redness on his sharp cheeks and an almost manic brightness
6070	of eye gave the old poet away. 'At least I drew number three..." He
6071	held up his slip of paper. 'If you still want to hear the fucking
6072	thing."
6073	Brawne Lamia lifted her glass of wine, scowled, and set it down.
6074	'Perhaps we should talk about what we have learned from the first two
6075	stories and how it might relate to our current... situation."
6076	'Not yet,' said Colonel Kassad. 'We don't have enough information."
6077	'Let M. Silenus speak,' said Sol Weintruab. 'Then we
6078	can begin discussing what we have heard."
6079	'I agree,' said Lenar Hoyt.
6080	Het Mastcen and the Consul nodded.
6081	'Agreed!" cried Martin Silenus. 'I'II tell my story. Just let me
6082	finish my fucking glass of wine."
6083	THE POET'S TALE: 'Hyperion Cantos'
6084	In the beginning was the Word. Then came the fucking word processor.
6085	Then came the thought processor. Then came the death of literature. And
6086	so it goes.
6087	Francis Bacon once said, 'There arises from a bad and unapt formation of
6088	words a wonderful obstruction to the mind." We have all contributed our
6089	wonderful obstructions to the mind, have we not? I more than most. One
6090	of the twentieth century's better, forgotten writers- that is
6091	better-comma-forgotten, once bon
6092	rnoted: 'i love being a writer. It's the paperwork I can't stand." Get
6093	it? Well, amigos and amigette, I love being a
6094	poet. It's the goddamned words I can't stand.
6095	Where to start?
6096	Start with Hyperion perhaps?
6097	(Fade in) Almost two standard centuries ago.
6098	Sad King Billy's five seedships spin like gold dandelions above this all
6099	too familiar lapis sky. We land like conquistadors strutting to and
6100	fro; more than two thousand visual artists and writers and sculptors and
6101	poets and ARNists and vid makers and holie directors and composers and
6102	decomposers and God knows what all, supported by five times that many
6103	administrators and technicians and ecologists and supervisors and court
6104	chamberlains and professional ass kissers, not to mention the family of
6105	royal asses themselves, supported in turn by ten times that many
6106	androids willing to till the soil and stoke the reactors and raise the
6107	cities and lift that bale and tote that load... hell, you get the idea.
6108	We landed on a world already seeded by the poor buggers who'd gone
6109	indigenie two centuries before and were living hand to mouth and cudgel
6110	to brain wherever they could. Naturally the noble descendants of these
6111	brave pioneers greeted us like gods - especially after a few of our
6112	security folk slagged a few of their more aggressive leaders- and
6113	naturally we accepted their worship as our due and put them to work next
6114	to our blueskins, plowing the south forty and working to build our
6115	shining city on the hill.
6116	And it was a shining city on a hill. Seeing the ruins today can tell
6117	you nothing of the place. The desert had advanced in three centuries;
6118	the aqueducts from the mountains have fallen and shattered; the city
6119	itself is only bones. But in its day the City of Poets was fair indeed,
6120	a bit of Socrates's Athens with the intellectual excitement of
6121	Renaissance Venice, the artistic fervor of Paris in the days of the
6122	Impressionists, the true democracy of the first decade of Orbit City,
6123	and the unlimited future of Tau Ceti Center.
6124	But, in the end, it was none of these things, of course.
6125	It was only Hrothgar's claustrophobic mead hall with
6126	the monster waiting in the darkness without. We had our Grendel, to be
6127	sure. We even had our Hrothgar if one squints a bit at Sad King Billy's
6128	poor slouched profile.
6129	We lacked only our Geats; our great, broad-shouldered, small-brained
6130	Beowulf with his band of merry psycho-paths.
6131	So, lacking a Hero, we settled into the role of victims and composed our
6132	sonnets and rehearsed our ballets and unrolled our scrolls, while all
6133	the while our thorn-and-steel Grendel served the night with fear and
6134	harvested thighbones and gristle.
6135	And this was when I - a satyr then, formed in flesh as mirror to my soul
6136	- came as close to completing my Cantos, my life's work, as I have come
6137	in five sad centuries of
6138	stubborn continuance.
6139	(Fade to black)
6140	It occurs to me that the Grendel tale is premature. The players have
6141	not been brought upon the stage. Dislinear plotting and non-contiguous
6142	prose have their adherents, not the least of which am I, but in the end,
6143	my friends, it is character which wins or loses immortality upon the
6144	vellum. Haven't you ever harbored the secret thought that somewhere
6145	Huck and Jim are- at this instant-poling their raft down some river just
6146	beyond our reach, so much more real are they than the shoe clerk who
6147	fitted us just a forgotten day ago? At any rate, if this fucking
6148	story's to be told, you should know who's in it. So --as much as it
6149	pains me - VII back up to begin at the beginning.
6150	In the beginning was the Word. And the Word was programmed in classic
6151	binary. And the Word said, 'Let there be life!" And so, somewhere in
6152	the TechnoCore vaults of my mother's estate, frozen sperm from my
6153	long-dead daddy was defrosted, set in suspension, shaken like the
6154	vanilla malts of yore, loaded into something part squirt gun and part
6155	dildo, and - at the magic touch of a trigger - ejaculated into Mother at
6156	a time when the moon was full and the egg was ripe.
6157	Mother didn't have to be impregnated in this barbaric fashion, of
6158	course. She could have chosen ex utero fertilization, a male lover with
6159	a transplant of Daddy's
6160	DNA, a clonal surrogate, a gene-spliced virgin birth, you name it...
6161	but, as she told me later, she opened her legs
6162	to tradition. My guess is that she preferred it that way.
6163	Anyway, I was born.
6164	I was born on Earth... Old Earth... and fuck you, Lamia, if you don't
6165	believe it. We lived on Mother's estate on an island not far from the
6166	North American Preserve.
6167	Notes for sketch of home on Old Earth:
6168	Fragile twilights fading from violet to fuchsia to purple above the
6169	crepe-paper silhouettes of trees beyond the southwest sweep of lawn.
6170	Skies as delicate as translucent china, unscarred by cloud or contrail.
6171	The presymphony hush of first light followed by the cymbal crash of
6172	sunrise. Oranges and russets igniting to gold, the long, cool descent
6173	to green: leaf shadow, shade, tendrils of cypress and weeping willow,
6174	the hushed green velvet of the glade.
6175	Mother's estate - our estate - a thousand acres centered in a million
6176	more. Lawns the size of small prairies with grass so perfect it
6177	beckoned a body to lie on it, to nap on its soft perfection. Noble
6178	shade trees making sundials of the Earth, their shadows circling in
6179	stately procession; now mingling, now contracting to midday, finally
6180	stretching eastward with the dying of the day.
6181	Royal oak. Giant elms. Cottonwood and cypress and redwood and bonsai.
6182	Banyan trees lowering new trunks like smooth-sided columns in a temple
6183	roofed by sky.
6184	Willows lining carefully laid canals and haphazard streams, their
6185	hanging branches singing ancient dirges to the wind.
6186	Our house rises on a low hill where, in the winter, the browning curves
6187	of lawn look like the smooth flank of some female beast, all thigh
6188	muscle and meant for speed.
6189	The house shows its centuries of accretion: a jade tower on the east
6190	courtyard catching the first light of dawn, a series of gables on the
6191	south wing throwing triangles of shadow on the crystal conservatory at
6192	teatime, the balconies and maze of exterior stairways along the east
6193	porticoes playing Escher games with afternoon's shadows.
6194	It was after the Big Mistake but before everything grew uninhabitable.
6195	Mostly we occupied the estate during what we quaintly called 'periods of
6196	remission'-stretches of ten to eighteen quiet months between planet-wide
6197	spasms as the Kiev Team's goddamn little black hole digested bits of the
6198	Earth's center and waited for its next feast. During the 'Bad Times,'
6199	we vacationed at Uncle Kowa's place out beyond the moon, on a
6200	terra-formed asteroid brought there before the Ouster migration.
6201	You might already be able to tell that I was born with a silver spoon up
6202	my ass. I offer no apologies. After three thousand years of dabbling
6203	with democracy, the remaining Old Earth families had come to the
6204	realization that the only way to avoid such riffraff was not to allow
6205	them to breed. Or, rather, to sponsor seedship fleets; spinship
6206	explorations, new farcaster migrations ... all of the panicked urgency
6207	of the Hegira... as long as they bred out there and left Old Earth
6208	alone. The fact that the homeworld was a diseased old bitch, gone in
6209	the teeth, didn't hurt the riffraff's urge to pioneer. No fools they.
6210	And like the Buddha, I was almost grown before I saw my first hint of
6211	poverty. I was sixteen standard years old, on my Wanderjahr, and
6212	backpacking through India when I saw a beggar. The Hindu Old Families
6213	kept them around for religious reasons, but all I knew at the time was
6214	that here was a man in rags, ribs showing, holding out a wicker basket
6215	with an ancient credit diskey in it, begging for a touch of my universal
6216	card. My friends thought it was hysterical. I threw up. It was in
6217	Benares.
6218	My childhood was privileged but not obnoxiously so. I have pleasant
6219	memories of Grande Dame Sybil's famous parties (she was a great-aunt on
6220	my mother's side). I remember one three-day affair she threw in the
6221	Manhattan Archipelago, guests ferried in by dropship from Orbit City and
6222	from the European arcologies. I remember the Empire State Building
6223	rising from the water, its many lights reflecting on the lagoons and
6224	fern canals; the EMVs unloading passengers on the observation deck while
6225	cooking fires burned on the overgrown island mounds of lower buildings
6226	all around.
6227	The North American Preserve was our private playground in those days. It
6228	was said that about eight thousand people still resided in that
6229	mysterious continent, but half of these were rangers. The rest included
6230	the renegade ARNists who plied their trade by resurrecting species of
6231	plants and animals long absent from their antediluvian North American
6232	haunts, the ecology engineers, licensed primitives such as the Ogalalla
6233	Sioux or the He!l's Angel Guild, and the occasional tourist. I had a
6234	cousin who reportedly backpacked from one observation zone to the other
6235	in the Preserve, but he did so in the Midwest where the zones were
6236	relatively close together and where the dinosaur herds were much
6237	scarcer.
6238	In the first century after the Big Mistake, Gaea was mortally injured
6239	but slow in the dying. The devastation was great during the Bad Times -
6240	and these came more often in precisely plotted spasms, shorter
6241	remissions, more terrible consequences after each attack - but the Earth
6242	abided and repaired itself as best it could.
6243	The Preserve was, as I say, our playground but, in a real sense, so was
6244	all of the dying Earth. Mother let me have my own EMV when I was seven
6245	and there was no place on the globe farther than an hour's flight from
6246	home. My best friend, Amalfi Schwartz, lived in the Mount Erebus
6247	Estates in what had once been the Antarctic Republic. We saw each other
6248	daily. The fact that Old Earth law forbade farcasters did not bother us
6249	in the least; lying on some hillside at night looking up through the ten
6250	thousand Orbiting Lights and the twenty thousand beacons of the Ring, at
6251	the two or three thousand visible stars, we felt no jealousy, no urge to
6252	join the Hegira that even then was spinning the farcaster silk of the
6253	Worldweb. We were happy.
6254	My memories of Mother are oddly stylized, as if she were another
6255	fictional construct from one of my Dying Earth novels. Perhaps she was.
6256	Perhaps I was raised by robots in the automated cities of Europe,
6257	suckled by androids in the Amazon Desert, or simply grown in a vat like
6258	brewer's yeast. What I recall is Mother's white gown sliding ghostlike
6259	through the shadowed rooms of the estate; infinitely delicate blue veins
6260	on the back of her
6261	thin-fingered hand as she poured tea in the damask and dust light of the
6262	conservatory; candlelight caught like a gold fly in the spiderweb sheen
6263	of her hair, hair done up in a bun in the style of the Grandes Dames.
6264	Sometimes I dream that I remember her voice, the lilt and tone and
6265	turn-in-the-womb centerhess of it, but then I awake and it becomes only
6266	the wind moving lace curtains or the sound of some alien sea on stone.
6267	From my earliest sense of self, I knew that I would be - should be - a
6268	poet. It was not as if I had a choice; more like the dying beauty all
6269	about breathed its last breath in me and commanded that I be doomed to
6270	play with words the rest of my days, as if in expiation for our race's
6271	thoughtless slaughter of its crib world. So what the hell; I became a
6272	poet.
6273	I had a tutor whose name was Balthazar, human but ancient, a refugee
6274	from ancient Alexandria's flesh-scented alleys. Balthazar all but
6275	glowed blue-white from those crude, early Poulsen treatments; he was
6276	like an irradiated mummy of a man, sealed in liquid plastic.
6277	And randy as the proverbial goat. Centuries later, when I was in my
6278	satyr period, I felt that I finally understood poor don Balthazar's
6279	priapic compulsions, but in those days it was mostly a hindrance to
6280	keeping young girls on the estate's staff. Human or android, don
6281	Baitbazar did not discriminate - he poinked them all.
6282	Luckily for my education, there was nothing homosexual in don
6283	Balthazar's addiction to young flesh, so his escapades evidenced
6284	themselves either as absences from our tutorial sessions or an
6285	inordinate amount of attention lavished on memorizing verses from Ovid,
6286	Senesh, or Wu.
6287	He was an excellent tutor. We studied the ancients and the late
6288	classical period, took field trips to the ruins of Athens, Rome, London,
6289	and Hannibal, Missouri, and never once had a quiz or test. Don
6290	Balthazar expected me to learn everything by heart at first encounter
6291	and I did not disappoint him. He convinced my mother that the pitfalls
6292	of 'progressive education' were not for an Old Earth family, so ! never
6293	knew the mind-stunting shortcuts of RNA medication, datasphere
6294	immersion,
6295	systemic flashback training, stylized encounter groups, 'higher-level
6296	thinking skills' at the expense of facts, or preliterate programming. As
6297	a result of these deprivations, I was able to recite all of Fitzgerald's
6298	translation of the Odyssey by the time I was six, compose a sestina
6299	before I could dress myself, and think in spiral fugue-verse before I
6300	ever interfaced with an AI.
6301	My scientific education, on the other hand, was something less than
6302	stringent. Don Balthazar had little interest in what he referred to as
6303	'the mechanical side of the universe." I was twenty-two before I
6304	realized that computers, RMUs, and Uncle Kowa's asteroidal life-support
6305	devices were machines and not some benevolent manifestations of the
6306	animas around us. I believed in fairies, woodsprites, numerology,
6307	astrology, and the magic of Midsummer's Eve deep in the primitive
6308	forests of the NAP. Like Keats and Lamb in Haydon's studio, don
6309	Balthazar and I drank toasts to 'the confusion of mathematics' ancl
6310	mourned the destruction of' the poetry of the rainbow by M. Newton's
6311	prying prism.. The early distrust and actual hatred of all things
6312	scientific and clinical served me well in later life. It is not
6313	difficult, I have learned, to remain a pre-Copernican pagan in the
6314	postscientific Hegemony.
6315	My early poetry was execrable. As with most bad poets, I was unaware of
6316	this fact, secure in my arrogance that the very act of creating gave
6317	some worth to the worthless abortions I was spawning. My mother
6318	remained tolerant even as I left reeking little piles of doggerel lying
6319	around the house. She was indulgent of her only child even if he was as
6320	blithely incontinent as an unhousebroken llama.
6321	Don Balthazar never commented on my work; primarily, I assume, because I
6322	never showed him any of it. Don Baithazar thought that the venerable
6323	Daton was a fraud, that Salmud Brevy and Robert Frost should have hanged
6324	themselves with their own entrails, that Wordsworth was a fool, and that
6325	anything less than Shakespeare's sonnets was a profanation of the
6326	language. I saw no reason to bother don Baitbazar with my verse, rife
6327	with budding genius though I knew it to be.
6328	I published several of these little literary turds in the various
6329	hardcopy journals then in vogue in the various arcologies of the
6330	European Houses, the amateur editors of these crude journals being as
6331	indulgent of my mother as she was of me. Occasionally I would press
6332	Amalfi or one of my other playmates - less aristocratic than I and thus
6333	with access to the datasphere or fatline transmitters - to uplink some
6334	of my verses to the Ring or to Mars, and thus to the burgeoning
6335	farcaster colonies.
6336	They never replied. I assumed they were too busy.
6337	Belief in one's identity as a poet or writer prior to the acid test of
6338	publication is as naive and harmless as the youthful belief in one's
6339	immortality... and the inevitable disillusionment is just as painful.
6340	My mother died with Old Earth. About half the Old Families stayed
6341	during that last cataclysm; I was twenty years old then and had made my
6342	own romantic plans to die with the homeworld. Mother decided otherwise.
6343	What concerned her was not my premature demise - like me, she was far
6344	too self-centered to think of someone else at a time like that - nor
6345	even the fact that the death of my DNA would mark the end of a line of
6346	aristocrats which stretched back to the Mayflower;, no, what bothered
6347	Mother was that the family was going to die out in debt. Our last
6348	hundred years of extravagance, it seems, had been financed through
6349	massive loans from the Ring Bank and other discreet extraterrestrial
6350	institutions.
6351	Now that the continents of Earth were crashing under the impact of
6352	contraction, the great forests aflame, the oceans heaving and heating
6353	themselves into a lifeless soup, the very air transforming itself into
6354	something too hot and thick to break and too thin to plow, now the banks
6355	wanted their money back. I was collateral.
6356	Or, rather, Mother's plan was. She liquidated all available assets some
6357	weeks before that phrase became a literal reality, deposited a quarter
6358	of a million marks in long-term accounts in the fleeing Ring Bank, and
6359	dispatched me on a trip to the Rifkin Atmospheric Protectorate on
6360	Heaven's Gate, a minor world circling the star Vega. Even then, that
6361	poisonous world had a
6362	farcaster connection to Sol System, but I did not farcast.
6363	Nor was I a passenger on the single spinship with Hawking drive which
6364	put into Heaven's Gate each standard year. No, Mother sent me to this
6365	back end of the outback on a Phase Three ramship, slower than light,
6366	frozen with the cattle embryos and orange juice concentrate and feeder
6367	viruses, on a trip that took one hundred and twenty-nine shipboard
6368	years, with an objective time-debt of one hundred and sixty-seven
6369	standard years!
6370	Mother figured that the accrued interest on the long-term accounts would
6371	be enough to pay off our family debt and perhaps allow me to survive
6372	comfortably for a while. For the first and last time in her life,
6373	Mother figured wrong.
6374	Notes for a sketch of Heaven's Gate:
6375	Mud lanes which run back from the station's conversion docks like a
6376	pattern of sores on a leper's back.
6377	Sufrus-brown clouds which hang in tatters from a rotten burlap sky. A
6378	tangle of shapeless wooden structures half decayed before they were ever
6379	fully constructed, their paneless windows now staring sightlessly into
6380	the gaping mouths of their neighbors. lndigenies breeding like...
6381	like humans, I suppose ... eyeless cripples, lungs burned out with air
6382	rot, squiring a nest of a dozen offspring, the children's skin scabrous
6383	by age five-standard, their eyes watering incessantly from the sting of
6384	an atmosphere which will kill them before they're forty, their smiles
6385	carious, their oily hair rife with lice and the blood bags of dracula
6386	ticks. Proud parents beaming. Twenty million of these doomed schmucks,
6387	crowded into slums overflowing an island smaller than my family's west
6388	lawn on Old Earth, all of them fighting to breathe the only breathable
6389	air on a world where the standard is to inhale and die, crowding ever
6390	closer to the center of the sixty-mile radius of survivable atmosphere
6391	which the Atmospheric Generating Station had been
6392	able to provide before it began to malfunction.
6393	Heaven's Gate: my new home.
6394	Mother had not taken into account the possibility that all Old Earth
6395	accounts would be frozen- and then
6396	appropriated into the growing Worldweb economy. Nor had she remembered
6397	that the reason people had waited for the Hawking drive to see the
6398	spiral arm of the galaxy is that in long-term cryogenic sleep - as
6399	opposed to a few weeks or months of fugue - chances of terminal brain
6400	damage were one in six. I was lucky. When I was uncrated on Heaven's
6401	Gate and put to work digging out acid canals beyond the perimeter, I had
6402	suffered only a cerebral accident - a stroke. Physically, I was able to
6403	work in the mud pits within a few local weeks. Mentally, there was much
6404	left to be desired.
6405	The left side of my brain had been shut down like a damaged section of a
6406	spinship being sealed off, airtight doors leaving the doomed
6407	compartments open to vacuum. I could still think. Control of the right
6408	side of my body soon returned. Only the language centers had been
6409	damaged beyond simple repair. The marvelous organic computer wedged in
6410	my skull had dumped its language content like a flawed program. The
6411	right hemisphere was not without some language - but only the most
6412	emotionally charged units of communication could lodge in that affective
6413	hemisphere; my vocabulary was now down to nine words. (This, I learned
6414	later, was exceptional, many victims of CVAs retain only two or three.)
6415	For the record, here is my entire vocabulary of manageable words: fuck,
6416	shit, piss, cunt, goddamn, motherfucker, asshole, peepee, and poopoo.
6417	A quick analysis will show some redundancy here. I had at my disposal
6418	eight nouns, which stood for six things; five of the eight nouns could
6419	double as verbs. I retained one indisputable noun and a single
6420	adjective which also could be used as a verb or expletive. My new
6421	language universe was comprised of four monosyllables, three compound
6422	words, and two baby-talk repetitions.
6423	My arena of literal expression offered four avenues to the topic of
6424	elimination, two references to human anatomy, one request for divine
6425	imprecation, one standard description of or request for coitus, and a
6426	coital variation which was no longer an option for me since my mother
6427	was deeeased.
6428	All in all, it was enough.
6429	I will not say that I remember my three years in the mud pits and slime
6430	slums of Heaven's Gate with fondnexs, but it is true that these years
6431	were at least as formative as - and probably more so than - my previous
6432	two decades on Old Earth.
6433	I soon found that among my intimate acquaintances - Old Sludge, the
6434	scoop-shovel foreman; Unk, the slum-yard bully to whom I paid my
6435	protection bribes; Kiti, the lice-ridden crib doxy whom I slept with
6436	when I could afford it - my vocabulary served me well. 'Shit-fuck,' I
6437	would grunt, gesticulating. 'Asshole cunt peepec fuck."
6438	'Ah,' grinned Old Sludge, showing his one tooth, 'going to the company
6439	store to get some algae chewies, huh?"
6440	'Goddamn poopoo,' I would grin back at him.
6441	The life of a poet lies not merely in the finite language-dance of
6442	expression but in the nearly infinite combinations of perception and
6443	memory combined with the sensitivity to what is perceived and
6444	remembered. My three local years on Heaven's Gate, almost fifteen
6445	hundred standard days, allowed me to see, to feel, to hear -to remember,
6446	as if I literally had been born again. Little matter that I had been
6447	born again in hell; reworked experience is the stuff of all true poetry
6448	and raw experience was the birthing gift of my new life.
6449	There was no problem adapting to a brave new world a century and a half
6450	beyond my own. For all of our talk of expansion and pioneering spirit
6451	these past five centuries, we all know how stultified and static our
6452	human universe has become. We are in a comfortable Dark Ages of the
6453	inventive mind; institutions change but little, and that by gradual
6454	evolution rather than revolution; scientific research creeps crablike in
6455	a lateral shuffle, where once it leaped in great intuitive bounds;
6456	devices change even less, plateau technologies common to us would be
6457	instantly identifiable- and operable!- to our great-grandfathers.
6458	So while I slept the Hegemony became a formal entity, the Worldweb was
6459	spun to something close to its final shape, the All Thing took its
6460	democratic place among the list of humanity's benevolent despots, the
6461	TechnoCore seceded from human service and then offered its help as an
6462	ally rather than a slave, and the Ousters retreated to darkness and the
6463	role of Nemesis · . . but all these things had been creeping toward
6464	critical mass even before I was frozen into my ice coffin between the
6465	pork bellies and sherbet, and such obvious extensions of old trends took
6466	little effort to understand. Besides, history viewed from the inside is
6467	always a dark, digestive mess, far different from the easily
6468	recognizable cow viewed from afar by historians.
6469	My life was Heaven's Gate and the minute-to-minute demands of survival
6470	there. The sky was always an eternal yellow-brown sunset hanging like a
6471	collapsing ceiling mere meters above my shack. My shack was oddly
6472	comfortable: a table for eating, a cot for sleeping and fucking, a hole
6473	for pissing and shitting, and a window for silent staring. My
6474	environment mirrored my vocabulary.
6475	Prison always has been a good place for writers, killing, as it does,
6476	the twin demons of mobility and diversion, and Heaven's Gate was no
6477	exception. The Atmospheric Protectorate owned my body but my mind - or
6478	what was left of it - was mine.
6479	On Old Earth, my poetry was composed on a Sadu-Dekenar cornlog thought
6480	processor while I lounged in a padded chaise Iongue or floated in my EM
6481	barge above dark lagoons or walked pensively through scented bowers.
6482	The execrable, undisciplined, limp-wristed flatulent products of those
6483	reveries already have been described.
6484	On Heaven's Gate, I discovered what a mental stimulant physical labor
6485	could be; not mere physical labor, I should add, but absolutely
6486	spine-bending, lung-racking, gut-ripping, ligament-tearing, and
6487	ball-breaking physical labor. But as long as the task is both onerous
6488	and repetitive, I discovered, the mind is not only free to wander to
6489	more imaginative climes, it actually flees to higher planes.
6490	Thus, on Heaven's Gate, as I dredged bottom scum from the slop canals
6491	under the red gaze of Vega Primo or crawled on hands and knees through
6492	stalactites and
6493	stalagmites of rebreather bacteria in labyrinthine lungpipes, I became a
6494	poet.
6495	All I lacked were the words.
6496	the station's
6497	The twentieth century's most honored writer, William Gass, once said in
6498	an interview; 'Words are the supreme objects. They are minded things."
6499	And so they are. As pure and transcendent as any Idea which ever cast a
6500	shadow into Plato's dark cave of our perceptions. But they are also
6501	pitfalls of deceit and misperception. Words bend our thinking to
6502	infinite paths of self-delusion, and the fact that we spend most of our
6503	mental lives in brain mansions built of words means that we lack the
6504	objectivity necessary to see the terrible distortion of reality which
6505	language brings. Example: the Chinese pictogram for 'integrity' is a
6506	two-part symbol of a man literally standing next to his word. So far,
6507	so good. But what does the Late English word 'honesty' mean? Or
6508	'Motherland'? Or 'progress'7 Or 'democracy'?
6509	Or 'beauty'? But even in our self-deception, we become gods.
6510	A philosopher/mathematician named Bertrand Russell, who lived and died
6511	in the same century as Gass, once wrote: 'Language serves not only to
6512	express thought but to make possible thoughts which could not exist
6513	without it." Here is the essence of mankind's creative genius: not the
6514	edifices of civiliz.tion nor the bang-flash weapons which can end it,
6515	but the words which fertilize new concepts like spermatazoa attacking an
6516	ovum. It might be argued that the Siamese-twin infants of word/idea are
6517	the only contribution the human species can, will, or should make to the
6518	reveling cosmos.
6519	(Yes, our DNA is unique but so is a salamander's. Yes, we construct
6520	artifacts but so have species ranging from beavers to the architect ants
6521	whose crenellated towers are visible right now off the port bow. Yes,
6522	we weave real-fabric things from the dreamstuff of mathematics, but the
6523	universe is hardwired with arithmetic. Scratch a circle and :r peeps
6524	out. Enter a new solar system and Tycho Brahe's formulae lie waiting
6525	under the black velvet cloak of space/time. But where has the universe
6526	hidden a word
6527	under its outer layer of biology, geometry, or insensate rock?) Even the
6528	traces of other intelligent life we have found - the blimps on Jove II,
6529	the Labyrinth Builders, the Seneschai empaths on Hebron, the Stick
6530	People of Durulis, the architects of the Time Tombs, the Shrike itself -
6531	have left us mysteries and obscure artifacts but no language. No words.
6532	The poet John Keats once wrote to a friend of his named Bailey: 'I am
6533	certain of nothing but the holiness of the Heart's affections and the
6534	truth of Imagination - What the imagination seizes as Beauty must be
6535	truth - whether it existed before or not."
6536	The Chinese poet George Wu, who died in the Last Sino-Japanese War about
6537	three centuries before the Hegira, understood this when he recorded on
6538	his comlog: 'Poets are the mad midwives to reality. They see not what
6539	is, nor what can be, but what must become." Later, on his last disk to
6540	his lover the week before he died, Wu said: 'Words are the only bullets
6541	in truth's bandolier. And poets are the snipers."
6542	You see, in the beginning was the Word. And the Word was made flesh in
6543	the weave of the human universe.
6544	And only the poet can expand this universe, finding shortcuts to new
6545	realities the way the Hawking drive tunnels under the barriers of
6546	Einsteinian space/time.
6547	To be a poet, I realized, a true poet, was to become the Avatar of
6548	humanity incarnate; to accept the mantle of poet is to carry the cross
6549	of the Son of Man, to suffer the birth pangs of the Soul-Mother of
6550	Humanity.
6551	To be a true poet is to become God.
6552	I tried to explain this to my friends on Heaven's Gate.
6553	'Piss, shit,' I said. 'Asshole motherfucker, goddamn shit goddamn.
6554	Cunt. Peepee cunt. Goddamn!'
6555	They shook their heads and smiled, and walked away.
6556	Great poets are rarely understood in their own day.
6557	The yellow-brown clouds rained acid on me. I waded in mud up to my
6558	thighs and cleaned leechweed from the city sewer pipes. Old Sludge died
6559	during my second year there when we were all working on a project
6560	extending the First Avenue Canal to the Midsump Mudflats. An
6561	accident. He was climbing a slime dune to rescue a single sulfur-rose
6562	from the advancing grouter when there was a mudquake. Kiti married
6563	shortly after that. She still worked part time as a crib doxy, but I
6564	saw less and less of her. She died in childbirth shortly after the
6565	green tsunami carried away Mudflat City. I continued to write poetry.
6566	How is it, you might ask, that someone can write fine verse with a
6567	vocabulary of only nine right-hemisphere words?
6568	The answer is that I used no words at all. Poetry is only secondarily
6569	about words. Primarily, it is about tuth. I dealt with the Ding an
6570	$i¢h, the substance behind the shadow, weaving powerful concepts,
6571	similes, and connections the way an engineer would raise a skyscraper
6572	with the whiskered-alloy skeleton being constructed long before the
6573	glass and plastic and chromaluminum appears.
6574	And slowly the words returned. The brain retrains and retools itself
6575	amazingly well. What had been lost in the left hemisphere found a home
6576	elsewhere or reasserted their primacy in the damaged regions like
6577	pioneers returning to a fire-damaged plain made more fertile by the
6578	flames. Where before a simple word like 'salt' would leave me
6579	stuttering and. gasping, my mind probing emptiness like a tongue
6580	prodding the socket of a missing tooth, now the words and phrases flowed
6581	back slowly, like the names of forgotten playmates. During the day I
6582	labored in the slimefields, but at night I sat at my splintered table
6583	and wrote my Cantos by the light of a hissing ghee lamp. Mark Twain
6584	once opined in his homey way: 'The difference between the right word and
6585	the almost right word is the difference between lightning and the
6586	lightning bug." He was droll but incomplete.
6587	During those long months of beginning my Cantos on Heaven's Gate, I
6588	discovered that the difference between finding the right word as opposed
6589	to accepting the almost right word was the difference between being
6590	struck by lightning and merely watching a lightning display.
6591	So my Cantos began and grew. Written on the flimsy sheets of recycled
6592	leechweed fiber which they issued by
6593	the ton for use as toilet paper, scribbled by one of the cheap felt-tip
6594	pens sold at the Company Store, the Cantos took shape. As the words
6595	returned, slipping into place like once scattered pieces of a 3-D
6596	pu:,le, I needed a form. Returning to don Baithazar's teachings, I
6597	tried on the measured nobility of Milton's epic verse. Gaining
6598	confidence, I added the romantic sensuality of a Byron matured by a
6599	Keatsish celebration of the language. Stirring all this, I seasoned the
6600	mixture with a dash of Yeats's brilliant cynicism and a pinch of Pound's
6601	obscure, scholastic arrogance. I chopped, diced, and added such
6602	ingredients as Eliot's control of imagery, Dylan Thomas's feel for
6603	place, Delmore Schwartz's sense of doom, Steve Tem's touch of horror,
6604	Salmud Brevy's plea for innocence; Daton's love of the convoluted rhyme
6605	scheme, Wu's worship of the physical, and Edmond Ki Fererra's radical
6606	playfulness.
6607	In the end, of course, I threw this entire mixture out and wrote the
6608	Cantos in a style all my own.
6609	If it had not been for Unk the slumyard bully, I probably still would be
6610	on Heaven's Gate, digging acid canals by day and writing Cantos by
6611	night.
6612	It was my day off and I was carrying my Cantos - the only copy of my
6613	manuscript! - to the Company Library in the Common Hall to do some
6614	research when Unk and two of his cronies appeared from an alley and
6615	demanded immediate payment of the next month's protection money. We had
6616	no universal cards in the Heaven's Gate Atmospheric Protectorate; we
6617	paid our debts in company scrip or bootleg marks. I had neither. Unk
6618	demanded to see what was in my plastic shoulder bag.
6619	Without thinking, I refused. It was a mistake. If I'd shown Unk the
6620	manuscript, he most probably would have scattered it in the mud and
6621	slapped me around after making threats. As it was, my refusal angered
6622	him so he and his two Neanderthal companions tore open the bag,
6623	scattered the manuscript in the mud, and beat me within the proverbial
6624	inch of my life.
6625	It so happened that on this day an EMV belonging to a Protectorate air
6626	quality control manager was passing
6627	low above and the wife of the manager, traveling alone to the arc's
6628	Company Residential Store, ordered the EMV down, had her android servant
6629	retrieve me and what was left of my Cantos, and then personally drove me
6630	to the Company Hospital. Normally, the members of the bonded work force
6631	received medical aid, if any, at the walk-in Bio Clinic, but the
6632	hospital did not want to refuse the wife of a manager so I was admitted
6633	- still unconscious - and watched over by a human doctor and the
6634	manager's wife while I recovered in a healing tank.
6635	All right, to make a banal long story into a banal short story, I'll cut
6636	to the uplink. Helenda - that was the manager's wife - read my
6637	manuscript while I was floating in renewal nutrient. She liked it. On
6638	the same day I was being decanted in the Company Hospital, Helenda
6639	farcast to Renaissance where she showed my Cantos to her sister Felia,
6640	who had a friend whose lover knew an editor at Transline Publishing.
6641	When I awoke the next day, my broken ribs had been set, my shattered
6642	cheekbone had been healed, my bruises were gone, and I'd received five
6643	new teeth, a new cornea for my left eye, and a contract with Transline.
6644	My book came out five weeks later. A week after that, Helenda divorced
6645	her manager and married me. It was her seventh marriage, my first. We
6646	honeymooned on the Concourse and, when we returned a month later, my
6647	book had sold more than a billion copies - the first book of verse to
6648	hit the bestseller lists in four centuries - and I was a millionaire
6649	many times over.
6650	Tyrena Wingreen-Feif was my first editor at Transline. It was her idea
6651	to title the book The Dying Earth (a records search showed a novel by
6652	that name five hundred years earlier, but the copyright had lapsed and
6653	the book was out of print). It was her idea to publish just the
6654	sections of the Cantos which dealt with the nostalgic final days of Old
6655	Earth. And it was her idea to remove the sections which she thought
6656	would bore the readers - the philosophical passages, the descriptions of
6657	my mother, the sections which paid homage to earlier poets, the places
6658	where I played with experimental verse, the more personal
6659	passages - everything, in fact, except the descriptions of the idyllic
6660	final days which, emptied of all heavier freight, came across as
6661	sentimental and insipid. Four months after publication The Dying Earth
6662	had sold two and a half billion hardfax copies, an abridged and
6663	digitalized version was available on the See Thing datasphere, and it
6664	had been optioned for the holies.
6665	Tyrena pointed out that the timing had been perfect...
6666	that the original trauma shock of the death of Old Earth had meant a
6667	century of denial, almost as if Earth had never existed, followed by a
6668	period of revived interest culminating in the Old Earth nostalgia cults
6669	which could now be found on every world in the Web. A book - even a
6670	book of verse - dealing with the final days had struck at precisely the
6671	right moment.
6672	For me, the first few months of life as a celebrity in the Hegemony were
6673	far more disorienting than my earlier transition from spoiled son of Old
6674	Earth to enslaved stroke victim on Heaven's Gate. During those first
6675	months I did book and fax signing on more than a hundred worlds; I
6676	appeared on 'The AllNet Now!" show with Marmon Hamlit; I met CEO
6677	Senister Per6t and All Thing Speaker Drury Fein aswell as a score of
6678	senators; I spoke to the Interplanetary Society of PEN Women and to the
6679	Lusus Writers' Union; I was given honorary degrees at the University of
6680	New Earth and at Cambridge Two; I was feted, interviewed, imaged,
6681	reviewed (favorably), bioed (unauthorized), lionized, serialized, and
6682	swindled. It was a busy time.
6683	Notes for a sketch of life in the Hegemony:

7153	Notes for a sketch of Sad King Billy:
7154	His Royal Highness King William XXIII, sovereign lord of the Kingdom of

7658	Of course I had summoned the Shrike. I knew that. I had summoned it by
7659	beginning my epic poem about it. In the beginning was the Word.
7660	I retitled my poem The Hyperion Cantos. It was not about the planet but

7662	the unthinking hubris of a race which dared to murder its homeworld

7765	Time Tombs region in recent years. The machines arrived sans

7767	The little man in the rumpled cape shrugged. His uniform was meant to
7768	be brilliant and regal but merely made him look like an overweight
7769	Harlequin. 'I followed the last batch of pilgrims,' he said. 'And then
7770	c-c-came down from Keep Chronos to visit. I notice that you've written
7771	nothing in many months, M-M-Martin. Can you explain that?"
7772	I glowered in silence while sidling closer.
7773	'Perhaps I can explain it,' said King Billy. He looked at the last
7774	completed page of Hyperion Cantos as if it had the answer to a
7775	long-puzzled riddle. 'The last stanzas were written the same week last
7776	year that J.T. Telio disappeared."
7777	'So?" I had moved to the far edge of the table now.
7778	Feigning a casual attitude, I pulled a short stack of manuscript pages
7779	closer and moved them out of Billy's reach.
7780	'So that w-w-w-was... according to the SDF monitors ·.. the d-d-date
7781	of the death of the last remaining Poets' City dweller,' he said. 'The
7782	last except for y-y-you, that is, Martin."
7783	I shrugged and began moving around the table. I needed to get to Billy
7784	without getting the manuscript in the way.
7785	'You know, you haven't f-f-f-finished it, Martin,' he said in his deep,
7786	sad voice. 'There is still some hance that humanity s-s-s-survives the
7787	Fall."
7788	'No,' I said and sidled closer.
7789	'But you can't write it, can you, Martin? You can't c-c-c-compose this
7790	poetry unless your m-m-muse is shedding blood, can you?"
7791	'Bullshit,' I said.
7792	'Perhaps. But a fascinating coincidence. Have you ever wondered why
7793	you have been spared, Martin?"
7794	I shrugged again and slid another stack of papers out of his reach. I
7795	was taller, stronger, and meaner than Billy, but I had to be sure that
7796	none of the manuscript would be damaged if he struggled as I lifted him
7797	out of his seat and threw him out.
7798	'It's t-t-t-time we did something about this problem,' said my patron.
7799	'No,' I said, 'it's time you left." I shoved the last stacks of poetry
7800	aside and raised my arms, surprised to see a brass candlestick in one
7801	hand.
7802	'Stop right there, please,' King Billy said softly and lifted a neural
7803	stunner from his lap.
7804	I paused only a second. Then I laughed. 'You miserable little hangdog
7805	fraud,' I said. 'You couldn't use a fucking weapon if your life
7806	depended on it."
7807	I stepped forward to beat him up and throw him out.
7808	My cheek was against the stone of the courtyard but one eye was open
7809	enough for me to see that stars still shone through the broken
7810	latticework of the galleria dome. I could not blink. My limbs and
7811	torso tingled with the pinpricks of returning sensation, as if my entire
7812	body had fallen asleep and was now coming painfully awake. It made me
7813	want to scream, but my jaw and tongue refused to work. Suddenly I was
7814	lifted and propped against a stone bench so that I could see the
7815	courtyard and the dry fountain which Rithmet Corbet had designed. The
7816	bronze Laocon wrestled with bronze snakes in the flickering illumination
7817	of the predawn meteor showers.
7818	'I'm s-s-sorry, Martin,' came a familiar voice, 'b-b-but this
7819	m-m-madness has to end." King Billy came into my field of view carrying
7820	a tall stack of manuscript. Other heaps of pages lay on the shell of
7821	the fountain at t he foot of the metal Trojan. An open bucket of
7822	kerosene sat nearby.

7825	Billy. He reached into the fountain, raised a sheaf of manuscript, and
7826	ignited it with a flick of his cigarette lighter.

7829	fountain and lifted another stack of pages, rolling them into a
7830	cylinder. Tears glistened on lined cheeks illuminated by flame. 'You
7831	c-c-called it f-f-forth,' gasped the little man. 'It must be
7832	f-f-finished."
7833	I struggled to rise. My arms and legs jerked like a marionette's
7834	mishandled limbs. The pain was incredible.
7835	I screamed again and the agonized sound echoed from marble and granite.
7836	King Billy lifted a fat sheaf of papers and paused to read from the top
7837	page:
7838	· Without story or prop
7839	But my own weak mortality, I bore
7840	The load of this eternal quietude,
7841	The unchanging gloom, and th three fixed shapes Ponderous upon my senses

7843	For by my burning brain I measured sure Her silver seasons shedded on

7851	tried to steady myself with an arm ablaze with pinpricks, and fell on my

7867	twitches of random nerve impulses while leaning against the stone bench.

7869	The third figure did not actually appear so much as allow its presence
7870	to impinge upon my consciousness; it was as if it always had been there
7871	and King Billy and I had failed to notice it until the flames grew
7872	bright enough.
7873	Impossibly tall, four-armed, molded in chrome and cartilage, the Shrike
7874	turned its red gaze on us.
7875	King Billy gasped, stepped back, and then moved forward to feed more
7876	cantos to the fire. Embers rose on warm drafts. A flight of doves

7879	I moved forward in a motion more lurch than step. The Shrike did not
7880	move, did not shift its bloody gaze.
7881	'Go!" cried King Billy, stutter forgotten, voice exalted, a blazing mass
7882	of poetry in each hand. 'Return to the pit whence you came!'
7883	The Shrike seemed to incline its head ever so slightly.
7884	Red light gleamed on sharp surfaces.
7885	'My lord!" I cried, although to King Billy or the apparition from hell I
7886	did not know then and know not now. I staggered the last few paces and
7887	reached for Billy's arm.
7888	He was not there. One second the aging King was a hand's length from me
7889	and in the next instant he was ten meters away, raised high above the
7890	courtyard stones. Fingers like steel thorns pierced his arms and chest
7891	and thighs, but he still writhed and my Cantos burned in his fists.
7892	The Shrike held him out like a father offering his son for baptism.
7893	'Destroy it!" Billy cried, his pinned arms making pitiful gestures.
7894	'Destroy it!'
7895	I stopped at the fountain's edge, tottered weakly against the rim. At
7896	first I thought he meant destroy the Shrike... and then I thought he
7897	meant the poem...
7898	and then I realized that he meant both. A thousand pages and more of
7899	manuscript lay tumbled in the dry fountain.
7900	I picked up the bucket of kerosene.
7901	The Shrike did not move except to pull King' Billy slowly back against
7902	his chest in an oddly affectionate motion. Billy writhed and screamed
7903	silently as a long steel thorn emerged from his harlequin silk just
7904	above the breastbone. I stood there stupidly and thought of butterfly
7905	collections I had displayed as a child. Slowly, mechanically, I sloshed
7906	kerosene on the scattered pages.
7907	'End it!" gasped King Billy. 'Martin, for the love of God!'
7908	I picked up the lighter from where he had dropped it.
7909	The Shrike made no move. Blood soaked the black patches of Billy's
7910	tunic until they blended with the crimson squares already here. I
7911	thumbed the antique lighter once, twice, a third time; sparks only.
7912	Through my tears I could see my life's work lying in the dusty fountain.
7913	I dropped the lighter.
7914	Billy screamed. Dimly, I heard blades rubbing bone as he twisted in the
7915	Shrike's embrace. 'Finish it!" he cried.
7916	'Martin... oh, God!'
7917	I turned then, took five fast paces, and threw the half-full bucket of
7918	kerosene. Fumes blurred my already blurred vision. Billy and the
7919	impossible creature that held him were soaked like two comics in a
7920	slapstick holie.
7921	I saw Billy blink and splutter, I saw the slickness on the Shrike's
7922	chiseled muzzle reflect the meteor-brightened sky, and then the dying
7923	embers of burned pages in Billy's still clenched fists ignited the
7924	kerosene.
7925	I raised my hands to protect my face - too late, beard and eyebrows
7926	singed and smoldered- and staggered backward until the rim of the
7927	fountain stopped me.
7928	For a second the pyre was a perfect sculpture of flame, a blue and
7929	yellow Piet with a four-armed madonna holding a blazing Christ figure.
7930	Then the burning figure writhed and arched, still pinned by steel thorns
7931	and a score of scalpeled talons, and a cry went up which to this
7932	day I cannot believe emanated from the human half of that death-embraced
7933	pair. The scream knocked me to my knees, echoed from every hard surface
7934	in the city, and drove the pigeons into wheeling panic. And the scream
7935	continued for minutes after the flaming vision simply ceased to be,
7936	leaving behind neither ashes nor retinal image. It was another minute
7937	or two before I realized that the scream I now heard was mine.
7938	Anticlimax is, of course, the warp and way of things.
7939	Real life seldom structures a decent denouement.
7940	It took me several months, perhaps a year, to recopy the
7941	kerosene-damaged pages and to rewrite the burned Cantos. It will be no
7942	surprise to learn that I did not finish the poem. It was not by choice.
7943	My muse had fled.
7944	The City of Poets decayed in peace. I stayed another year or two -
7945	perhaps five, I do not know; I was quite mad by then. To this day
7946	records of early Shrike pilgrims tell of the gaunt figure, all hair and
7947	rags and bulging eyes, who would wake them from their Gethsemane sleep
7948	by screaming obscenities and shaking his fist at the silent Time Tombs,
7949	daring the coward within to show itself.
7950	Eventually the madness burned itself out - although the embers will
7951	always glow - and I hiked the fifteen hundred kilometers to
7952	civilization, my backpack weighted down with just manuscript, surviving
7953	on rock eels and snow and on nothing at all for the last ten days.
7954	The two and a half centuries since are not worth telling, much less
7955	reliving. The Pouisen treatments to keep the instrument alive and
7956	waiting. Two long, cold sleeps in illegal, sublight, cryogenic voyages;
7957	each swallowing a century or more; each taking its toll in brain cells
7958	and memory.
7959	I waited then. I will still. The poem must be finished. It will be
7960	finished.
7961	In the beginning was the Word.
7962	In the end... past honor, past life, past caring...
7963	In the end will be the Word.
7964	FOUR
7965	The Benares put into Edge a little after noon on the next day. One of
7966	the mantas had died in harness only twenty kilometers downriver from
7967	their destination and A. Bettik had cut it loose. The other had lasted
7968	until they tied up to the bleached pier and then it rolled over in total
7969	exhaustion, bubbles rising from its twin airholes. Bettik ordered this
7970	manta cut loose as well, explaining that it had a slim chance of
7971	surviving if it drifted along in the more rapid current.
7972	The pilgrims had been awake and watching the scenery roll by since
7973	before sunrise. They spoke little and none had found anything to say to
7974	Martin Silenus. The poet did not appear to mind... he drank wine with
7975	his breakfast and sang bawdy songs as the sun rose.
7976	The river had widened during the night and by morning it was a
7977	two-kilometer-wide highway of blue gray cutting through the low green
7978	hills south of the Sea of Grass. There were no trees this close to the
7979	Sea, and the browns and golds and heather tones of the Mane shrubs had
7980	gradually brightened to the bold greens of the two-meter-tall northern
7981	grasses. All morning the hills had been pressed lower until now they
7982	were compressed into low bands of grassy bluffs on either side of the
7983	river.
7984	An almost invisible darkening hung above the horizon to the north and
7985	east, and those pilgrims who had lived on ocean worlds and knew it as a
7986	promise of the approaching sea had to remind themselves that the only
7987	sea now near was comprised of several billion acres of grass.
7988	Edge never had been a large outpost and now it was totally deserted. The
7989	score of buildings lining the rutted lane from the dock had the vacant
7990	gaze of all abandoned
7991	structures and there were signs on the riverfront that the population
7992	had fled weeks earlier. The Pilgrims' Rest, a three-century-old inn
7993	just below the crest of the hill, had been burned.

7995	you do now?" Colonel Kassad asked the android.

7997	trip,' said Bettik. ' We shall leave the Benares here for your return

8000	'No." Bettik smiled. 'We have our own purposes and pilgrimages on

8379	THE SCHOLAR'S TALE:
8380	The River Lethe's Taste is Bitter
8381	Sol Weintraub and his wife Sarai had enjoyed their life even before the
8382	birth of their daughter; Rachel made things as close to perfect as the
8383	couple could imagine.
8384	Sarai was twenty-seven when the child was conceived, Sol was
8385	twenty-nine. Neither of them had considered Poulsen treatments because
8386	neither of them could afford it, but even without such care they looked
8387	forward to another fifty years of health.
8388	Both had lived their entire lives on Barnard's World, one of the oldest
8389	but least exciting members of the Hegemony. Barnard's was in the Web,
8390	but it made little difference to Sol and Sarai since they could not
8391	afford frequent farcaster travel and had little wish to go at any rate.
8392	Sol had recently celebrated his tenth year with Nightenhelser College,
8393	where he taught history and classical studies and did his own research
8394	on ethical evolution.
8395	Nightenhelser was a small school, fewer than three thousand students,
8396	but its academic reputation was outstanding and it attracted young
8397	people from all over the Web. The primary complaint of these students
8398	was that Nightenhelser and its surrounding community of Crawford
8399	constituted an island of civilization in an ocean of corn. It was true;
8400	the college was three thousand flat kilometers away from the capital of
8401	Bussard and the terraformed land in between was given over to farming.
8402	There had been no forests to fell, no hills to deal with, and no
8403	mountains to break the flat monotony of cornfields, bean-fields,
8404	cornfields, wheatfields, cornfields, rice paddies, and cornfields. The
8405	radical poet Salmud
8406	Brevy had taught briefly at Nightenhelser before the Glennon-Height
8407	Mutiny, had been fired, and upon far-casting to Renaissance Vector had
8408	told his friends that Crawford County on South Sinzer on Barnard's World
8409	constituted the Eighth Circle of Desolation on the smallest pimple on
8410	the absolute ass-end of Creation.
8411	Sol and Sarai Weintraub liked it. Crawford, a town of twenty-five
8412	thousand, might have been reconstructed from some nineteenth-century
8413	mid-American template.
8414	The streets were wide and over-arched with elms and oaks. (Barnard's
8415	had been the second extrasolar Earth colony, centuries before the
8416	Hawking drive and Hegira, and the seedships then had been huge.) Homes
8417	in Crawford reflected styles ranging from early Victorian to Canadian
8418	Revival, but they all seemed to be white and set far back on
8419	weil-trimmed lawns.
8420	The college itself was Georgian, an assemblage of red brick and white
8421	pillars surrounding the oval common.
8422	Sol's office was on the third floor of Placher Hall, the oldest building
8423	on campus, and in the winter he could look out on bare branches which
8424	carved the common into complex geometries. Sol loved the chalk-dust and
8425	old-wood smell of the place, a smell which had not changed since he was
8426	a freshman there, and each day climbing to his office he treasured the
8427	deeply worn grooves in the steps, a legacy of twenty generations of
8428	Nightenhelser students.
8429	Sarai had been born on a farm halfway between Bussard and Crawford and
8430	had received her PhD in music theory a year before Sol earned his
8431	doctorate. She had been a happy and energetic young woman, making up in
8432	personality what she lacked in accepted norms of physical beauty, and
8433	she carried this attractiveness of person into later life. Sarai had
8434	studied offworld for two years at the University of New Lyons on Deneb
8435	Drei, but she was homesick there: the sunsets were abrupt, the
8436	much-vaunted mountains slicing off the sunlight like a ragged scythe,
8437	and she longed for the hours-long sunsets of home where Barnard's Star
8438	hung on the horizon like a great, tethered, red balloon while the sky
8439	congealed to evening. She missed the perfect flatness where - peering
8440	from her third-floor room under the steep gables- a little girl could
8441	look fifty kilometers across tasseled fields to watch a storm approach
8442	like a bruise-black curtain lit within by lightning bolts. And Sarai
8443	missed her family.
8444	She and Sot met a week after she transferred to Night-enhelser; it was
8445	another three years before he proposed marriage and she accepted. At
8446	first she saw nothing in the short graduate student. She was still
8447	wearing Web fashions then, involved in Post-Destructionist music
8448	theories, reading Obit and Nihil and the most avant-garde magazines from
8449	Renaissance Vector and TC2, feigning sophisticated weariness with life
8450	and a rebel's vocabulary - and none of this jelled with the undersized
8451	.but earnest history major who spilled fruit cocktail on her at Dean
8452	Moore's honors party. Any exotic qualities which might have come from
8453	Sol Weintraub's Jewish legacy were instantly negated by his BW accent,
8454	his Crawford Squire Shop wardrobe, and the fact that he had come to the
8455	party with a copy of Detresque's Solitudes in Variance absentmindedly
8456	tucked under his arm.
8457	For Sol it was love at first sight. He stared at the laughing,
8458	red-cheeked girl and ignored the expensive dress and affected mandarin
8459	nails in favor of the personality which blazed like a beacon to the
8460	lonely junior. Sol had not known he was lonely until he met Sarai, but
8461	after the first time he shook her hand and spilled fruit salad down the
8462	front of her dress he knew that his life would be empty forever if they
8463	did not marry.
8464	They married the week after the announcement of Sol's teaching
8465	appointment at the college. Their honeymoon was on Maui-Covenant, his
8466	first farcast trip abroad, and for three weeks they rented a mobile isle
8467	and sailed alone on it through the wonders of the Equatorial
8468	Archipelago. Sol never forgot the images from those sun-drenched and
8469	wind-filled days, and the secret image he would always most cherish was
8470	of Sarai rising nude from a nighttime swim, the Core stars blazing above
8471	while her own body glowed constellations from the phosphorescence of the
8472	island's wake.
8473	They had wanted a child immediately but it was to be five years before
8474	nature agreed.
8475	Sol remembered cradling Sarai in his arms as she curled in pain, a
8476	difficult delivery, until finally, incredibly, Rachel Sarah Weintraub
8477	was born at 2:0I A.M. in Crawford County Med Center.
8478	The presence of an infant intruded upon Sol's solipsistic life as a
8479	serious academic and Sarai's profession as music critic for Barnard's
8480	datasphere, but neither minded. The first months were a blend of
8481	constant fatigue and joy. Late at night, between feedings, Sol would
8482	tiptoe into the nursery just to check on Rachel and to stand and gaze at
8483	the baby. More often than not he would find Sarai already there and the
8484	two would watch, arm in arm, at the miracle of a baby sleeping on its
8485	stomach, rump in the air, head burrowed into the bumper pad at the head
8486	of the crib.
8487	Rachel was one of those rare children who managed to be cute without
8488	becoming self-consciously precious; by the time she was two standard
8489	years old her appearance and personality were striking - her mother's
8490	light brown hair, red cheeks, and broad smile, her father's large brown
8491	eyes. Friends said that the child combined the best portions of Sarai's
8492	sensitivity and Sol's intellect.
8493	Another friend, a child psychologist from the college, once commented
8494	that Rachel at age five showed the most reliable indicators of true
8495	giftedness in a young person: structured curiosity, empathy for others,
8496	compassion, and a fierce sense of fair play.
8497	One day in his office, studying ancient files from Old Earth, Sol was
8498	reading about the effect of Beatrice on the world view of Dante
8499	Alighieri when he was struck by a passage written by a critic from the
8500	twentieth or twenty-first century:
8501	She [Beatrice] alone was still real for him, still implied meaning in
8502	the world, and beauty. Her nature became his landmark- what Melville
8503	would call, with more sobriety than we can now muster, his Greenwich
8504	Standard...
8505	Sol paused to access the definition of Greenwich Standard, and then he
8506	read on. The critic had added a personal note:
8507	Most of us, I hope, have had some child or spouse or friend like
8508	Beatrice, someone who by his very nature, his seemingly innate goodness
8509	and intelligence, makes us uncomfortably conscious of our lies when we
8510	lie.
8511	Sol had shut off the display and gazed out at the black geometries of
8512	branches above the common.
8513	Rachel was not insufferably perfect. When she was five standard, she
8514	carefully cut the hair of her five favorite dolls and then cut her own
8515	hair shortest of all. When she was seven, she decided that the migrant
8516	workers staying in their run-down houses on the south end of town lacked
8517	a nutritious diet, so she emptied the house's pantries, cold boxes,
8518	freezers, and synthesizer banks, talked three friends into accompanying
8519	her, and distributed several hundred marks' worth of the family's
8520	monthly food budget.
8521	When she was ten, Rachel responded to a dare from Stubby Berkowitz and
8522	tried to climb to the top of Crawford's oldest elm. She was forty
8523	meters up, less than five meters from the top, when a branch broke and
8524	she fell two thirds of the way to the ground. Sol was paged on his
8525	comlog while discussing the moral implications of Earth's first nuclear
8526	disarmament era and he left the class without a word and ran the twelve
8527	blocks to the Med Center.
8528	Rachel had broken her left leg, two ribs, punctured a lung, and
8529	fractured her jaw. She was floating in a bath of recovery nutrient when
8530	Sol burst in, but she managed to look over her mother's shoulder, smile
8531	slightly, and say through the wire cast on her jaw: 'Dad, I was fifteen
8532	feet from the top. Maybe closer. I'll make it next time."
8533	Rachel graduated with honors from secondary tutorials and received
8534	scholarship offers from corporate academies on five worlds and three
8535	universities, including Harvard on New Earth. She chose Nightenhelser.
8536	it was little surprise to Sol that his daughter chose
8537	archaeology as a major. One of his fondest memories of her was the long
8538	afternoons she had spent under the front porch when she was about two,
8539	digging in the loam, ignoring spiders and googlepeds, rushing into the
8540	house to show off every plastic plate and tarnished pfennig she had
8541	excavated, demanding to know where it had come from, what were the
8542	people like who had left it there?"
8543	Rachel received her undergraduate degree when she was nineteen standard,
8544	worked that summer on her grandmother's farm, and farcast away the next
8545	fall. She was at Reichs University on Freeholm for twenty-eight local
8546	months, and when she returned it was as if color had flowed back into
8547	Sol and Sarai's world.
8548	For two weeks their daughter - an adult now, self-aware and secure in
8549	some ways that grown-ups twice her age often failed to be - rested and
8550	reveled in being home.
8551	One evening, walking across the campus just after sunset, she pressed
8552	her father on details of his heritage.
8553	'Dad, do you still consider yourself a Jew?"
8554	Sol had run his hand over his thinning hair, surprised by the question.
8555	'A Jew? Yes, I suppose so. It doesn't mean what it once did, though."
8556	'Am I a Jew?" asked Rachel. Her cheeks glowed in the fragile light.
8557	'If you want to be,' said Sol. 'It doesn't have the same significance
8558	with Old Earth gone."
8559	'If l'd been a boy, would you have had me circumcised?"
8560	Sol had laughed, delighted and embarrassed by the question.
8561	'l'm serious,' said Rachel.
8562	Sol adjusted his glasses. 'I guess I would have, kiddo. I never
8563	thought about it."
8564	'Have you been to the synagogue in Bussard?"
8565	'Not since my bar mitzvah,' said Sol, thinking back to the day fifty
8566	years earlier when his father had borrowed Uncle Richard's Vikken and
8567	had flown the family to the capital for the ritual.
8568	'Dad, why do Jews feel that things are... less important now than
8569	before the Hegira?"
8570	Sol spread his hands - strong hands, more those of a stoneworker than an
8571	academic. 'That's a good question, Rachel. Probably because so much of
8572	the dream is dead.
8573	Israel is gone. The New Temple lasted less time than the first and
8574	second. God broke His word by destroying the Earth a second time in the
8575	way He did. And this Diaspora is... forever."
8576	'But Jews maintain their ethnic and religious identity in some places,'
8577	his daughter insisted.
8578	'Oh, sure. On Hebron and isolated areas of the Concourse you can find
8579	entire communities . . . Hasidic, Orthodox, Hasmonean, you name it...
8580	but they tend to
8581	be... nonvital, picturesque... tourist-oriented." 'Like a theme park?"
8582	'Yes."
8583	'Could you take me to Temple Beth-el tomorrow? I can borrow Khaki's
8584	strat."
8585	'No need,' said Sol. 'We'll use the co!lege's shuttle." He paused.
8586	'Yes,' he said at last, 'I would like to take you to the synagogue
8587	tomorrow."
8588	It was getting dark under the old elms. Streetlights came on up and
8589	down the wide lane which led to their home.
8590	'Dad,' said Rachel, 'l'm going to ask you a question l've asked about a
8591	million times since I was two. Do you believe in God?"
8592	Sol had not smiled. He had no choice but to give her the answer he had
8593	given her a million times. 'l'm waiting to,' he said.
8594	Rachel's postgraduate work dealt with alien and pre-Hegira artifacts.
8595	For three standard years Sol and Sarai would receive occasional visits
8596	followed by fatline flim-sies from exotic worlds near but not within the
8597	Web. They all knew that her field work in quest of dissertation would
8598	soon take her beyond the Web, into the Outback where time-debt ate away
8599	at the lives and memories of those left behind.
8600	'Where the hell is Hyperion?" Sarai had asked during Rachei's last
8601	vacation before the expedition left.
8602	'It sounds like a brand name' for some new household product."
8603	'It's a great place, Mom. There are more nonhuman artifacts there than
8604	any place except Armaghast."
8605	'Then why not go to Armaghast?" said Sarai. 'It's only a few months
8606	from the Web. Why settle for second best?"
8607	'Hyperion hasn't become the big tourist attraction yet,' said Rachel.
8608	'Although they're beginning to become a problem. People with money are
8609	more willing to travel outside the Web now."
8610	Sol had found his voice suddenly husky. 'Will you be going to the
8611	labyrinth or the artifacts called the Time Tombs?"
8612	'The Time Tombs, Dad. I'll be.working with Dr Melio Arundez and he
8613	knows more about the Tombs than anyone alive."
8614	'Aren't they dangerous?" asked Sol, framing the question as casually as
8615	he could but heating the edge in his voice.
8616	Rachel smiled. 'Because of the Shrike legend? No.
8617	Nobody's been bothered by that particular legend for two standard
8618	centuries."

8620	colonization..." began Sol.
8621	'Me too, Dad. But they didn't know about the big rock eels that came
8622	down into the desert to hunt. They probably lost a few people to those
8623	things and panicked. You know how legends begin. Besides, the rock
8624	eels have been hunted to extinction."
8625	'Spacecraft don't !and there,' persisted Sol. 'You have to sail to the

8627	Rachel laughed. 'In the early days, people flying in underestimated the
8628	effects of the anti-entropic fields and there were some accidents. But
