8630	Chronos at the north edge of the mountains where hundreds of tourists a
8631	year stay."
8632	'Will you be staying there?" asked Sarai.
8633	'Part of the time. It'll be exciting, Mom."
8634	'Not too exciting, I hope,' said Sarai and all of them had smiled.
8635	During the four years that Rachel was in transit - a few weeks of
8636	cryogenic fugue for her - Sol found that he missed his daughter much
8637	more than if she had been out of touch but busy somewhere in the Web.
8638	The thought that she was flying away from him faster than the speed of
8639	light, wrapped in the artificial quantum cocoon of the Hawking effect,
8640	seemed unnatural and ominous to him.
8641	They kept busy. Sarai retired from the critic business to devote more
8642	time to local environmental issues, but for Sol it was one of the most
8643	hectic times of his life.
8644	His second and third books came out and the second one - Moral Turning
8645	Points - caused such a stir that he was in constant demand at offworld
8646	conferences and symposia. He traveled to a few alone, to a few more
8647	with Sarai, but although both of them enjoyed the idea of traveling, the
8648	actual experience of facing strange foods, different gravities, and the
8649	light from strange suns all paled after a while and Sol found himself
8650	spending more time at home researching his next book, attending
8651	conferences, if he had to, via interactive holo from the college.
8652	It was almost five years after Rachel left on her expedition that Sol
8653	had a dream which would change his life.
8654	Sol dreamed that he was wandering through a great structure with columns
8655	the size of small redwood trees and a ceiling lost to sight far above
8656	him, through which red light fell in solid shafts. At times he caught
8657	glimpses of things far off in the gloom to his left or right: once he
8658	made out a pair of stone legs rising like massive buildings through the
8659	darkness; another time he spied what appeared to be a crystal scarab
8660	rotating far above him, its insides ablaze with cool lights.
8661	Finally Sol stopped to rest. Far behind him he could hear what sounded
8662	like a great conflagration, entire cities and forests burning. Ahead of
8663	him glowed the lights he had been walking toward, two ovals of deepest
8664	red.
8665	He was mopping sweat from his brow when an immense voice said to him:
8666	'Sol! Take your daughter, your only daughter Rachel, whom you love, and
8667	go to the world called Hyperion and offer her there as a burnt offering
8668	at one of the places of which I shall tell you."
8669	And in his dream Sol had stood and said, 'You can't be serious." And he
8670	had walked on through darkness, the red orbs glowing now like bloody
8671	moons hanging above an indistinct plain, and when he stopped to rest the
8672	immense voice said:
8673	'Sol! Take your daughter, your only daughter Rachel, whom you love, and
8674	go to the world called Hyperion and offer her there as a burnt offering
8675	at one of the places of which I shall tell you."
8676	And SOl had shrugged off the weight of the voice and had said distinctly
8677	into the darkness, 'I heard you the first time... the answer is still
8678	no."
8679	SO! knew he was dreaming then, and part of his mind enjoyed the irony
8680	of the script, but another part wanted only to waken. Instead, he found
8681	himself on a low balcony looking down on a room where Rachel lay naked
8682	on a broad block of stone. The scene was illuminated by the glow of the
8683	twin red orbs. Sol looked down at his right hand and found a long,
8684	curved knife there. The blade and handle appeared to be made of bone.
8685	The voice, sounding more than ever to Sol like some cut-rate holie
8686	director's shallow idea of what God's voice should sound like, came
8687	again:
8688	'SOl! You must listen well. The future of humankind depends upon your
8689	obedience in this matter.
8690	You must take your daughter, your daughter Rachel whom you love, and go
8691	to the world called Hyperion and offer her there as a burnt offering at
8692	one of the places of which I shall tell you."
8693	And Sol, sick of the whole dream yet somehow alarmed by it, had turned
8694	and thrown the knife far into the darkness.
8695	When he turned back to find his daughter, the
8696	scene had faded. The red orbs hung closer than ever, and now So! could
8697	see that they were multifaceted gems the size of small worlds.
8698	The amplified voice came again:
8699	'So? You have had your chance, SOl Weintraub.
8700	If you change your mind, you know where to find me."
8701	And SOl awakened half laughing, half chilled by the dream. Amused by
8702	the thought that the entire Talmud and the Old Testament might be
8703	nothing more than a cosmic shaggy-dog story.
8704	About the time Sol was having his dream, Rachel was on Hyperion
8705	finishing her first year of research there. The team of nine
8706	archaeologists and six physicists had found Keep Chronos fascinating but
8707	far too crowded with tourists and would-be Shrike pilgrims, so after the
8708	first month spent commuting from the hotel, they had set up a permanent
8709	camp between the ruined city and the small canyon holding the Time
8710	Tombs.
8711	While half the team excavated the more recent site of the unfinished
8712	city, two of Rachel's colleagues helped her catalogue every aspect of
8713	the Tombs. The physicists were finished with the anti-entropic fields
8714	and spent much of their time setting small flags of different colors to
8715	mark the limits of the so-called time tides.
8716	Rachel's team concentrated their work in the structure called the
8717	Sphinx, although the creature represented in stone was neither human nor
8718	lion; it may not have been a creature at all, although the smooth lines
8719	atop the stone monolith suggested curves of a living thing, and the
8720	sweeping appendages made everyone think of wings.
8721	Unlike the other Tombs, which lay open and were easily inspected, the
8722	Sphinx was a mass of heavy blocks honey-combed with narrow corridors,
8723	some of which tightened to impossibility, some of which widened to
8724	auditorium-sized proportions, but none of which led anywhere but back on
8725	themselves. There were no crypts, treasure rooms, plundered sarcophogi,
8726	wall murals, or secret
8727	passages, merely a maze of senseless corridors through sweating stone.
8728	Rachel and her lover, Melio Arundez, began mapping the Sphinx, using a
8729	method which had been in use for at least seven hundred years, having
8730	been pioneered in the Egyptian pyramids sometime in the twentieth
8731	century.
8732	Arranging sensitive radiation and cosmic ray detectors at the lowest
8733	point in the Sphinx, they recorded arrival times and deflection patterns
8734	of the particles passing through the mass of stone above them, watching
8735	for hidden rooms or passages which would not show up even on deep
8736	imaging radar. Because of the busy tourist season and the concern of
8737	the Hyperion Home Rule Council that the Tombs might be damaged by such
8738	research, Rachel and Melio went out to their site every night at
8739	midnight, making the half-hour walk and crawl through the corridor maze
8740	which they had rigged with blue glow-globes.
8741	There, sitting under hundreds of thousands of tons of stone, they would
8742	watch their instruments until morning, listening to their earphones ping
8743	with the sound of particles born in the belly of dying stars.
8744	The time tides had not been a problem with the Sphinx. Of all the
8745	Tombs, it seemed the least protected by the anti-entropic fields and the
8746	physicists had carefully mapped the times when the tide surges might
8747	pose a threat. High tide was at I000 hours, receding only twenty
8748	minutes later back toward the Jade Tomb half a kilometer to the south.
8749	Tourists were not allowed near the Sphinx until after I200 hours, and to
8750	leave a margin of safety, the site made sure they were out by 0900. The
8751	physics team had planted chronotropic sensors at various points along
8752	the paths and walkways between the Tombs, both to alert the monitors to
8753	variations of the tides and to warn the visitors.
8754	With only three weeks to go of her year of research on Hyperion, Rachel
8755	awoke one night, left her sleeping lover, and took a ground effect jeep
8756	from the camp to the Tombs. She and Melio had decided that it was
8757	foolish for both of them to monitor the equipment every night; now they
8758	alternated, one working at the site while the other collated data and
8759	prepared for the final project - a radar
8760	mapping of the dunes between the Jade Tomb and the Obelisk.
8761	The night was cool and beautiful. A profusion of stars stretched from
8762	horizon to horizon, four or five times the number Rachel had grown up
8763	looking at from Barnard's World. The low dunes whispered and shifted in
8764	the strong breeze blowing from the mountains in the south.
8765	Rachel found lights still burning at the site. The physics team was
8766	just calling it a day loading their own jeep.
8767	She chatted with them, had a cup of coffee as they drove away, and then
8768	took her backpack and made the twenty-five-minute trip into the basement
8769	of the Sphinx.
8770	For the hundredth time Rachel wondered who had built the Tombs and for
8771	what purpose. Dating of the construction materials had been useless
8772	because of the effect of the anti-entropic field. Only analysis of the
8773	Tombs in relation to the erosion of the canyon and other surrounding
8774	geological features had suggested an age of at least half a million
8775	years. The feeling was that the architects of the Time Tombs had been
8776	humanoid, even though nothing but the gross scale of the structures
8777	suggested such a thing. Certainly the passageways in the Sphinx
8778	revealed little: some were human enough in size and shape, but then
8779	meters farther along the same corridor might dwindle to a tube the size
8780	of a sewer pipe and then transform itself into something larger and more
8781	random than a natural cavern. Doorways, if they could be called such
8782	since they opened to nothing in particular, might be triangular or
8783	trapezoidal or ten-sided as commonly as rectangular.
8784	Rachel crawled the last twenty meters down a steep slope, sliding her
8785	backpack ahead of her. The heatless glow-globes gave the rock and her
8786	flesh a bluish, bloodless cast. The 'basement,' when she reached it,
8787	seemed a haven of human clutter and smells. Several folding chairs
8788	filled the center of the small space while detectors, oscilloscopes, and
8789	other paraphernalia lined the narrow table against the north wall. A
8790	plank on sawhorses along the opposite wall held coffee cups, a chess
8791	set, a half-eaten doughnut, two paperbacks, and a plastic toy of some
8792	sort of dog in a grass skirt.
8793	Rachel settled in, set her coffee therm next to the toy, and checked the
8794	cosmic ray detectors. The data appeared to be the same: no hidden rooms
8795	or passages, just a few niches even the deep radar had missed. In the
8796	morning Melio and Stefan would set a deep probe working, getting an
8797	imager filament in and sampling the air before digging further with a
8798	micro-manipulator. So far a dozen such niches had turned up nothing of
8799	interest. The joke at camp was that the next hole, no bigger than a
8800	fist, would reveal miniature sarcophagi, undersized urns, a petite
8801	mummy, or- as Melio put it- 'a teeny-tiny Tutankhamen."
8802	Out of habit, Rachel tried the comm links on her comlog. Nothing. Forty
8803	meters of stone tended to do that. They had talked of stringing
8804	telephone wire from the basement to the surface, but there had been no
8805	pressing need and now their time was almost up. Rachel adjusted the
8806	input channels on her cornlog to monitor the detector data and then
8807	settled back for a long, boring night.
8808	There. was the wonderful story of the Old Earth pharaoh- was it
8809	Cheops?- who authorized his huge pyramid, agreed to the burial chamber
8810	being deep under the center of the thing, and then lay awake nights for
8811	years in a claustrophobic panic, thinking of all those tons of stone
8812	above him for all eternity. Eventually the pharaoh ordered the burial
8813	chamber repositioned two thirds the way up the great pyramid. Most
8814	unorthodox.
8815	Rachel could understand the king's position. She hoped that - wherever
8816	he was - he slept better now.
8817	Rachel was almost dozing herself when - at 02I5 -her comlog chirped, the
8818	detectors screamed, and she jumped to her feet. According to the
8819	sensors, the Sphinx had suddenly grown a dozen new chambers, some larger
8820	than the total structure. Rachel keyed displays and the air misted with
8821	models that changed as she watched.
8822	Corridor schematics twisted back on themselves like rotating MObius
8823	strips. The external sensors indicated the upper structure twisting and
8824	bending like polyfiex in the wind - or like wings.
8825	Rachel knew that it was some type of multiple malfunction, but even as
8826	she tried to recalibrate she called data and impressions into her
8827	comlog. Then several things happened at once.
8828	She heard the drag of feet in the corridor above her.
8829	All of the displays went dead simultaneously.
8830	Somewhere in the maze of corridors a time-tide alarm began to blare.
8831	All of the lights went off.
8832	This final event made no sense. The instrument packages held their own
8833	power supplies and would have stayed lit through a nuclear attack. The
8834	lamp they used in the basement had a new ten-year power cell. The
8835	glow-globes in the corridors were bioluminescent and needed no power.
8836	Nonetheless, the lights were out. Rachel pulled a flashlight laser out
8837	of the knee pocket of her jumpsuit and triggered it. Nothing happened.
8838	For the first time in her life, terror closed on Rachel Weintraub like a
8839	hand on her heart. She could not breathe. For ten seconds she willed
8840	herself to be absolutely still, not even listening, merely waiting for
8841	the panic to recede. When it had subsided enough for her to breathe
8842	without gasping, she felt her way to the instruments and keyed them.
8843	They did not respond. She lifted her comlog and thumbed the diskey.
8844	Nothing... which was impossible, of course, given the solid-state
8845	invul-nerability and power-cell reliability of the thing. Still,
8846	nothing.
8847	Rachel could hear her pulse pounding now but she again fought back the
8848	panic and began feeling her way toward the only exit. The thought of
8849	finding her way through the maze in absolute darkness made her want to
8850	scream but she could think of no other alternatives.
8851	Wait. There had been old lights throughout the Sphinx maze but the
8852	research team had strung the glow-globes.
8853	Strung them. There was a perIon line connecting them all the way to the
8854	surface.
8855	Fine. Rachel groped her way toward the exit, feeling the cold stone
8856	under her fingers. Was it this cold before?
8857	There came the clear sound of something sharp scraping its way down the
8858	access shaft.
8859	'Melio?" called Rachel into the blackness. 'Tanya?
8860	Kurt?"
8861	The scraping sounded very close. Rachel backed away, knocking over an
8862	instrument and chair in the blackness. Something touched her hair and
8863	she gasped, raised her hand.
8864	The ceiling was lower. The solid block of stone, five meters square,
8865	slid lower even as she raised her other hand to touch it. The opening
8866	to the corridor was halfway up the wall. Rachel staggered toward it,
8867	swinging her hands in front of her like a blind person. She tripped
8868	over a folding chair, found the instrument table, followed it to the far
8869	wall, felt the bottom of the corridor shaft disappearing as the ceiling
8870	came lower. She pulled back her fingers a second before they were
8871	sliced off.
8872	Rachel sat down in the darkness. An oscilloscope scraped against the
8873	ceiling until the table cracked and collapsed under it. Rachel moved
8874	her head in short, desperate arcs. There was a metallic rasp - almost a
8875	breathing sound - less than a meter from her. She began to back away,
8876	sliding across a floor suddenly filled with broken equipment. The
8877	breathing grew louder.
8878	Something sharp and infinitely cold grasped her wrist.
8879	Rachel screamed at last.
8880	There was no fatline transmitter on Hyperion in those days. Nor did the
8881	spinship HS Farraux City have FTL-comm capability. So the first Sol and
8882	Sarai heard of their daughter's accident was when the Hegemony consulate

8886	The trip would take a little over ten days' shiptime with a five-month

11117	THE DETECTIVE'S TALE: The Long Good-Bye
11118	I knew the case was going to be special the minute that he walked into
11119	my office. He was beautiful. By that I don't mean effeminate or
11120	'pretty' in the male-model, HTV-star mode, merely... beautiful.
11121	He was a short man, no taller than I, and I was born and raised in
11122	Lusus's I.3-g field. It was apparent in a second that my visitor was
11123	not from Lusus - his compact form was well proportioned by Web
11124	standards, athletic but thin. His face was a study in purposeful
11125	energy: low brow, sharp cheekbones, compact nose, solid jaw, and a wide
11126	mouth that suggested both a sensuous side and a stubborn streak. His
11127	eyes were large and hazel-colored.
11128	He looked to be in his late twenties standard.
11129	Understand, I didn't itemize all this the moment he walked in. My first
11130	thought was, Is this a client? My
11131	second thought was, Shit, this guy'$ beautiful.
11132	'M. Lamia?" 'Yeah."
11133	'M. Brawne Lamia of AllWeb Investigations?" 'Yeah."
11134	He looked around as if he didn't quite believe it. I understood the
11135	look. My office is on the twenty-third level of an old industrial hive
11136	in the Old Digs section of Iron Pig on Lusus. I have three big windows
11137	that look
11138	out on Service Trench 9 where it's always dark and always drizzling
11139	thanks to a massive filter drip from the Hive above. The view is mostly
11140	of abandoned automated loading docks and rusted girders.
11141	What the hell, it's cheap. And most of my clients call rather than show
11142	up in person.
11143	'May I sit down?" he asked, evidently satisfied that a bona fide
11144	investigatory agency would operate out of such a slum.
11145	'Sure,' I said and waved him to a chair. 'M... ah?" 'Johnny,' he said.
11146	He didn't look like a first-name type to me. Something about him
11147	breathed money. It wasn't his clothes - common enough casuals in black
11148	and gray, although the fabric was better than average - it was just a
11149	sense that the guy had class. There was something about his accent.
11150	l'm good at placing dialects- it helps in this profession - but I
11151	couldn't place this guy's homeworld, much less local region.
11152	'How can I help you, Johnny?" I held out the bottle of Scotch I had been
11153	ready to put away as he entered.
11154	Johnny-boy shook his head. Maybe he thought I wanted him to drink from
11155	the bottle. Hell, I have more class than that. There are paper cups
11156	over by the water cooler. 'M. Lamia,' he said, the cultivated accent
11157	still
11158	bugging me by its elusiveness, 'I need an investigator." 'That's what I
11159	do."
11160	He paused. Shy. A lot of my clients are hesitant to tell me what the
11161	job is. No wonder, since ninety-five percent of my work is divorce and
11162	domestic stuff. I waited him out.
11163	'It's a somewhat sensitive matter,' he said at last.
11164	'Yeah, M . . . ah, Johnny, most of my work falls under that category.
11165	I'm bonded with UniWeb and everything having to do with a client falls
11166	under the Privacy Protection Act. Everything is confidential, even the
11167	fact that we're talking now. Even if you decide not to hire me." That
11168	was basic bullshit since the authorities could get at my files in a
11169	moment if they ever wanted to, but I sensed that I had to put this guy
11170	at ease somehow.
11171	God, he was beautiful.
11172	'Uh-huh,' he said and glanced around again. He leaned forward. 'M.
11173	Lamia, I would want you to investigate a murder."
11174	This got my attention. I'd been reclining with my feet on the desk; now
11175	I sat up and leaned forward. 'A mur der? Are you sure? What about the
11176	cops?"
11177	'They aren't involved."
11178	'That's not possible,' I said with the sinking feeling that I was
11179	dealing with a loony rather than a client. 'It's a crime to conceal a
11180	murder from the authorities." What I thought was: Are you the murderer,
11181	Johnny?
11182	He smiled and shook his head. 'Not in this case." 'What do you mean?"
11183	'I mean, M. Lamia, that a murder was committed but that the police-
11184	local and Hegemony- have neither knowledge of it nor jurisdiction over
11185	it."
11186	'Not possible,' I said again. Outside, sparks from an industrial
11187	welder's torch cascaded into the trench along with the rusty drizzle.
11188	'Explain."
11189	'A murder was committed outside of the Web. Outside of the
11190	Protectorate. There were no local authorities."
11191	That made sense. Sort of. For the life of me, though, I couldn't
11192	figure where he was talking about. Even the Outback settlements and
11193	colonial worlds have cops. On board some sort of spaceship? Uh-uh. The
11194	Interstellar Transit Authority has jurisdiction there.
11195	'I see,' I said. It'd been some weeks since l'd had a case. 'All
11196	right, tell me the details."
11197	'And the conversation will be confidential even if you
11198	do not take the case?"
11199	'Absolutely."
11200	'And if you do take the case, you will report only to me?"
11201	'Of course."
11202	My prospective client hesitated, rubbing his fingers against his chin.
11203	His hands were exquisite. 'All right,' he said at last.
11204	'Start at the beginning,' I said. 'Who was murdered?"
11205	Johnny sat up straight, an attentive schoolboy. There was no doubting
11206	his sincerity. He said, 'I was."
11207	It took ten minutes to get the story out of him. When he was finished,
11208	I no longer thought he was crazy. I was. Or I would be if I took the
11209	job.
11210	Johnny - his real name was a code of digits, letters, and cipher bands
11211	longer than my arm - was a cybrid.
11212	I'd heard about cybrids. Who hasn't? I once accused my first husband
11213	of being one. But I never expected to be sitting in the same room with
11214	one. Or to find it so damned attractive.
11215	Johnny was an AI. His consciousness or ego or whatever you want to call
11216	it floated somewhere in the megadatasphere datumplane of TechnoCore.
11217	Like everyone else except maybe the current Senate CEO or the Als'
11218	garbage removers, I had no idea where the TechnoCore was. The Als had
11219	peacefully seceded from human control more than three centuries ago -
11220	before my time- and while they continued to serve the Hegemony as allies
11221	by advising the All Thing, monitoring the dataspheres, occasionally
11222	using their predictive abilities to help us avoid major mistakes or
11223	natural disasters, the TechnoCore generally went about its own
11224	indecipherable and distinctly nonhuman business in privacy.
11225	Fair enough, it seemed to me.
11226	Usually Als do business with humans and human machines via the
11227	datasphere. They can manufacture an interactive holo if they need to -
11228	I remembered during the Maui-Covenant incorporation, the TechnoCore
11229	ambassadors at the treaty signing looked suspiciously like the old holo
11230	star Tyrone Bathwaite.
11231	Cybrids are a whole different matter. Tailored from human genetic
11232	stock, they are far more human in appearance and outward behavior than
11233	androids are allowed to be. Agreements between the TechnoCore and the
11234	Hegemony allow only a handful of cybrids to be in existence.
11235	I looked at Johnny. Fom an AI's perspective, the beautiful body and
11236	intriguing personality sitting across the desk from me must be merely
11237	another appendage, a remote, somewhat more complex but otherwise no more
11238	important than any one of ten thousand such sensors, manipulators,
11239	autonomous units, or other remotes that an AI might use in a day's work.
11240	Discarding 'Johnny' probably would create no more concern in an AI than
11241	clip ping a fingernail would bother me.
11242	What a waste, I thought.
11243	'A cybrid,' I said.
11244	'Yes. Licensed. I have a Worldweb user's visa."
11245	'Good,' I heard myself say. 'And someone... murdered your cybrid and
11246	you want me to f'md out who?"
11247	'No,' said the young man. He had brownish-red curls.
11248	Like his accent, the hairstyle eluded me. It seemed archaic somehow,
11249	but I had seen it somewhere. 'It was not merely
11250	this body that was murdered. My assailant murdered me." 'You?" 'Yes."
11251	'You as in the... ah... AI itself?."
11252	'Precisely."
11253	I didn't get it. Als can't die. Not as far as anyone in the Web knew.
11254	'I don't get it,' I said.
11255	Johnny nodded, 'Unlike a human personality which can . . . I believe
11256	the consensus is . . . be destroyed at death, my own consciousness
11257	cannot be terminated.
11258	There was, however, as a result of the assault, an...
11259	interruption. Although I possessed... ah... shall we say duplicate
11260	recordings of memories, personality, et cetera, there was a loss. Some
11261	data were destroyed in the attack. In that sense, the assailant
11262	committed murder."
11263	'I see,' I lied. I took a breath. 'What about the AI authorities ...
11264	if there are such things ... or the Hegemony cybercops? Wouldn't they
11265	be the ones to go tO?"
11266	'For personal reasons,' said the attractive young man whom I was trying
11267	to see as a cybrid, 'it is important - even necessary - that I do not
11268	consult these sources."
11269	I raised an eyebrow. This sounded more like one of my regular clients.
11270	'I assure you,' he said, 'it is nothing illegal. Nor unethical. Merely
11271	. . . embarrassing to me on a level which I cannot explain."
11272	I folded my arms across my chest. 'Look, Johnny.
11273	This is a pretty half-assed story. I mean, I only have your word that
11274	you're a cybrid. You might be a scam artist for all I know."
11275	He looked surprised. 'I had not thought of that. How would you like me

11277	I did not hesitate a second. 'Transfer a million marks to my checking

11279	Johnny smiled. At the same instant my phone rang and the image of a
11280	harried man with the TransWeb code block floating behind him said,

11284	'Later,' I said.
11285	The bank manager nodded and vanished.
11286	'That could've been a simulation,' I said.

13970	hear from the noise behind us that the crowd on the Concourse was very
13971	large. The bishop walked by my side as I went through the doors and
13972	into the dimness.
13973	I laid Johnny on the cool floor. Robes rustled around us. I pulled my
13974	own armor off where I could, then batted at Johnny's. It was fused to
13975	his flesh in several places.
13976	I touched his burned cheek with my good hand. 'I'm sorry..."
13977	Johnny's head stirred slightly and his eye opened. He lifted his bare
13978	left hand to touch my cheek, my hair, the back of my head. 'Fanny..."
13979	I felt him die then. I also felt the surge as his hand found the neural
13980	shunt, the white-light warmth of the surge to the Schrn loop as
13981	everything Johnny Keats ever was or would be exploded into me; almost,
13982	almost it was like his orgasm inside me two nights earlier, the surge
13983	and throb and sudden warmth and stillness after, with the echo of
13984	sensation there.
13985	I lowered him to the floor and let the acolytes remove the body, taking
13986	it out to show the crowd and the authorities and the ones who waited to
13987	know.
13988	I let them take me away.
13989	I spent two weeks in a Shrike Temple recovery crche.
13990	Burns healed, scars removed, alien metal extracted, skin grafted, flesh
13991	regrown, nerves rewoven. And still I hurt.
13992	Everyone except the Shrike priests lost interest in me.
13993	The Core made sure that Johnny was dead; that his presence in the Core
13994	had left no trace; that his cybrid was dead.
13995	The authorities took my statement, revoked my license, and covered
13996	things up as best they could. The Web press reported that a battle
13997	between Dregs' Level Hive gangs had erupted onto the Concourse Mail.
13998	Numerous gtng members and innocent bystanders were killed. The police
13999	contained it.
14000	A week before word came that the Hegemony would allow the Yggdrasill to
14001	sail with pilgrims for the war zone near Hyperion, I used a Temple
14002	farcaster to 'cast to Renaissance Vector where I spent an hour alone in
14003	the archives there.
14004	The papers were in vacuum-press so I could not touch them. The
14005	handwriting was Johnny's; I had seen his writing before. The parchment
14006	was yellow and brittle with age. There were two fragments. The first
14007	read:
14008	The day is gone, and all its sweets are gone!
14009	Sweet voice, sweet lips, soft hand, and softer breast, Warm breath,
14010	light whisper, tender semi-tone,
14011	Bright eyes, accomplished shape, and languorous waist.t
14012	Faded the flower and all its budded charms,
14013	Faded the sight of beauty from my eyes,
14014	Faded the shape of beauty from my arms,
14015	Faded the voice, warmth, whiteness, paradisem Vanished unseasonably at
14016	shut of eve,
14017	When the dusk holiday - or holinight- Of fragrant-curtained love begins
14018	to weave
14019	The woof of darkness thick, for hid delight;
14020	But, as I've read iove's missal through today,
14021	He'll let me sleep, seeing I fast and pray.
14022	The second fragment was in a wilder hand and on rougher paper, as if
14023	slashed across a notepad in haste:
14024	This living hand, now warm and capable
14025	Of earnest grasping, would, if it were cold
14026	And in the icy silence of the tomb,
14027	So haunt thy days and chill thy dreaming nights
14028	That thou wouldst wish thine own heart dry of blood
14029	So in my veins red life might stream again,
14030	And thou be conscience-calm'd - see here it is- I hoM it towards you
14031	I'm pregnant. I think that Johnny knew it. I don't know for sure.
14032	I'm pregnant twice. Once with Johnny's child and once with the
14033	Schr6n-loop memory of what he was. I don't know if the two are meant to
14034	be linked. It will be months before the child is born and only days
14035	before I face the Shrike.

14041	their voices echoed in Gothic vaults. And what they chanted went
14042	something like this:
14043	'BLESSED BE SHE
14044	BLESSED BE THE MOTHER OF OUR
14045	SALVATION
14046	BLESSED BE THE INSTRUMENT OF OUR
14047	ATONEMENT
14048	BLESSED BE THE BRIDE OF OUR CREATION BLESSED BE SHE'

14050	I don't understand it now.

14052	I will face it together.

14074	SIX
14075	Chronos Keep jutted from the easternmost rim of the great Bridle Range:
14076	a grim, baroque heap of sweating stones with three hundred rooms and
14077	halls, a maze of lightless corridors leading to deep halls, towers,
14078	turrets, balconies overlooking the northern moors, airshafts rising half
14079	a kilometer to light and rumored to drop to the world's labyrinth
14080	itself, parapets scoured by cold winds from the peaks above, stairways-
14081	inside and out-carved from the mountain stone and leading nowhere,
14082	stained-glass windows a hundred meters tall set to catch the first rays
14083	of solstice sun or the moon on midwinter night, paneless windows the
14084	size of a man's fist looking out on nothing in particular, an endless
14085	array of bas-relief, grotesque sculptures in half-hidden niches, and
14086	more than a thousand gargoyles staring down from eave and parapet,
14087	transept and sepulcher, peering down through wood rafters in the great
14088	halls and positioned so as to peer in the blood-tinted windows of the
14089	northeast face, their winged and hunchbacked shadows moving like grim
14090	sundial hours, cast by sunlight in the day and gas-fed torches at night.
14091	And everywhere in Chronos Keep, signs of the Shrike Church's long
14092	occupation -atonement altars draped in red velvet, hanging and
14093	free-standing sculptures of the Avatar with polychrome steel for blades
14094	and bloodgems for eyes, more statues of the Shrike carved from the stone
14095	of narrow stairways and dark halls so that nowhere in the night would
14096	one be free of the fear of touching hands emerging from rock, the sharp
14097	curve of blade descending from stone, four arms enveloping in a final
14098	embrace. As if in a last measure of ornamentation, a filigree of blood
14099	in many of the once occupied halls and rooms, arabesques
14100	of red spattered in almost recognizable patterns along walls and tunnel
14101	ceilings, bedclothes caked hard with rust-red substance, and a central
14102	dining hall filled with the stench of food rotting from a meal abandoned
14103	weeks earlier, the floor and table, chairs and wall adorned with blood,
14104	stained clothing and shredded robes lying in mute heaps. And everywhere
14105	the sound of flies.

14437	THE CONSUL'S TALE: Remembering Siri
14438	I climb the steep hill to Siri's tomb on the day the islands return to
14439	the shallow seas of the Equatorial Archipelago.
14440	The day is perfect and I hate it for being so. The sky is as tranquil
14441	as tales of Old Earth's seas, the shallows are dappled with ultramarine
14442	tints, and a warm breeze blows in from the sea to ripple the russet
14443	willowgrass on the hillside near me.
14444	Better low clouds and gray gloom on such a day. Better mist or a
14445	shrouding fog which sets the masts in First-site Harbor dripping and
14446	raises the lighthouse horn from its slumbers. Better one of the great
14447	sea-simoons blowing up out of the cold belly of the south, lashing
14448	before it the motile isles and their dolphin herders until they seek
14449	refuge in the lee of our atolls and stony peaks.
14450	Anything would be better than this warm spring day when the sun moves
14451	through a vault of sky so blue that it makes me want to run, to jump in
14452	great loping arcs, and to roll in the soft grass as Siri and I have done
14453	at just this spot.
14454	Just this spot. I pause to look around. The willowgrass bends and
14455	ripples like the fur of some great beast as the salt-tinged breeze gusts
14456	up out of the south. I shield my eyes and search the horizon but
14457	nothing moves there.
14458	Out beyond the lava reef, the sea begins to chop and lift itself in
14459	nervous strokes.
14460	'Siri,' I whisper. I say her name without meaning to do so. A hundred
14461	meters down the slope, the crowd pauses to watch me and to catch its
14462	collective breath. The procession of mourners and celebrants stretches
14463	for more than a kilometer to where the white buildings of the city
14464	begin. I can make out the gray and balding head of my younger son in
14465	the vanguard. He is wearing the blue and gold robes of the Hegemony. I
14466	know that I should wait for him, walk with him, but he and the other
14467	aging Council members cannot keep up with my young, ship-trained muscles
14468	and steady stride. But decorum dictates that I should walk with him and
14469	my granddaughter Lira and my nine-year-old grandson.
14470	To hell with it. And to hell with them.
14471	I turn and jog up the steep hillside. Sweat begins to soak my loose
14472	cotton shirt before I reach the curving
14473	summit of the ridge and catch sight of the tomb.
14474	Siri' s tomb.
14475	I stop. The wind chills me although the sunlight is warm enough as it

14477	is high near the sealed entrance to the crypt. Rows of faded festival
14478	pennants on ebony staffs line the narrow gravel path.

14480	meters beyond. The willowgrass is bent and trampled here where
14481	irreverent picnickers have laid their blankets. There are several fire
14482	rings formed from the perfectly round, perfectly white stones purloined
14483	from the border of the gravel path.
14484	I cannot stop a smile. I know the view from here: the great curve of
14485	the outer harbor with its natural seawall, the low, white buildings of

14487	anchorage.

14502	haunting cry

16096	technicians, and dropped down north of the Bridle Range, a few
16097	kilometers from the Tombs themselves.
16098	The Ousters did not have farcasters. They spent their lives on the long
16099	marches between the stars, watching life in the Web speed by like some
16100	film or holie set at a frenzied speed. They were obsessed with time.
16101	The TechnoCore had given the Hegemony the farcaster and continued to
16102	maintain it. No human scientists or team of human scientists had come
16103	close to understanding it. The Ousters tried. They failed. But even
16104	in their failures they made inroads into understanding the manipulation
16105	of space/time.
16106	They understood the time tides, the anti-entropic fields surrounding the
16107	Tombs. They could not generate such fields, but they could shield
16108	against them and-theoretically - collapse them. The Time Tombs and all
16109	their contents would cease to age backward. The Tombs would 'open. '
16110	The Shrike would slip its tether, no longer connected to the vicinity of
16111	the Tombs. Whatever else was inside would now be freed.
16112	The Ousters believed that the Time Tombs were artifacts from their
16113	future, the Shrike a weapon of redemption awaiting the proper hand to
16114	seize it. The Shrike Cult saw the monster as an avenging angel; the
16115	Ousters saw it as a tool of human devising, sent back through time to
16116	deliver humanity from the TechnoCore. Andil and the technicians were
16117	there to calibrate and experiment.
16118	'You won't use it now?" I asked. We were standing in the shadow of the
16119	structure called the Sphinx.
16120	'Not now,' said Andil. 'When the invasion is imminent."
16121	'But you said it would take months for the device to work,' I said, for
16122	the Tombs to open."
16123	Andil nodded. Her eyes were a dark green. She was very tall, and I
16124	could make out the subtle stripes of the powered exoskeleton on her
16125	skinsuit. 'Perhaps a year or longer,' she said. 'The device causes the
16126	anti-entropic field to decay slowly. But once begun, the process is
16127	irrevocable. But we will not activate it until the Ten Councils have
16128	decided that invasion of the Web is necessary. '
16129	'There are doubts?" I said.
16130	'Ethical debates,' said A ndii. A few meters from us, the three
16131	technicians were covering the device with chameleon cloth and a coded
16132	containment field. 'And interstellar war will cause the deaths of
16133	millions, perhaps
16134	billions. Releasing the Shrike into the Web will have unforeseen
16135	consequences. As much as we need to strike at the Core, there are
16136	debates as to which is the best way. '
16137	I nodded and looked at the device and the valley of the Tombs. 'But
16138	once this is activated,' I said, 'there is no turning back. The Shrike
16139	will be released, and you will
16140	have to have won the war to control it?"
16141	Andil smiled slightly. 'That is true."
16142	I shot her then, her and then the three technicians.
16143	Then I tossed Grandmother Siri's Steiner-Ginn laser far into the drift
16144	dunes and sat on an empty flowfoam crate and sobbed for several minutes.
16145	Then I walked over, used a techniciqn's cornlog to enter the containment
16146	field, threw off the chameleon cloth, and triggered the device.
16147	There was no immediate change. The air held the same rich, late-winter
16148	light. The Jade Tomb glowed softly while the Sphinx continued to stare
16149	down at nothing.
16150	The only sound was the rasp of sand across the crates and bodies. Only
16151	a glowing indicator on the Ouster device showed that it was working ...
16152	had already worked.
16153	I walked slowly back to the ship, half expecting the Shrike to appear,
16154	half hoping that it would. I sat on the balcony of my ship for more
16155	than an hour, watching the shadows filling the valley and the sand
16156	covering the distant corpses. There was no Shrike. No thorn tree.
16157	After a while I played a Bach Prelude on the Steinway, buttoned up the
16158	ship, and rose into space.
16159	I contacted the Ouster ship and said that there had been an accident.
16160	The Shrike had taken the others; the device had been activated
16161	prematurely. Even in their confusion and panic, the Ousters offered me
16162	refuge. I declined the offer and turned my ship toward the Web.
16163	The Ousters did not pursue.
16164	I used myfatline transmitter to contact Gladstone and to tell her that
16165	the Ouster agents had been eliminated. !
16166	told her that the invasion was very likely, that the trap would be
16167	sprung as planned. I did not tell her about the device. Gladstone
16168	congratulated me and called me home. I declined. I told her that I
16169	needed silence and solitude. I turned my ship toward the Outback world
16170	nearest the Hyperion system, knowing that travel itself would eat time
16171	until the next act commenced.
16172	Later, when the fatline call to pilgrimage came from Gladstone herself,
16173	I knew the role the Ousters had planned for me in these final days: the
16174	Ousters, or the Core, or Gladstone and her machinations. It no longer
16175	matters who consider themselves the masters of events.
16176	Events no longer obey their masters.
16177	The world as we know it is ending, my friends, no matter what happens to
16178	us. As for me, I have no request of the Shrike. I bring no final words
16179	for it or the universe.
16180	I have returned because I must, because this is my fate. I've known
16181	what I must do since I was a child, returning alone to Siri's tomb and
16182	swearing vengeance on the Hegemony. I've known what price I must pay,
16183	both in life and in history.
16184	But when the time comes to judge, to understand a betrayal which will
16185	spread like fame across the Web, which will end worlds, l ask you not to
16186	think of me - my name was not even writ on water as your lost poet's
16187	soul said - but to think of Old Earth dying for no reason, to think of
16188	the dolphins, their gray flesh drying and rotting in the sun, to see -
16189	as I have seen - the motile isles with no place to wander, their feeding
16190	grounds destroyed, the Equatorial Shallows scabbed with drilling
16191	platforms, the islands themselves burdened with shouting, trammeling
16192	tourists smelling of UV lotion and cannabis.
16193	Or better yet, think of none of that. Stand as l did after throwing the
16194	switch, a murderer, a betrayer, but still proud, feet firmly planted on
16195	Hyperion's shifting sand, head held high, fist raised against the sky,
16196	crying 'A plague on both your houses.t'
16197	For you see, I remember my grandmother's dream. I remember the way it
16198	could have been.
16199	I remember Siri.
16200	'Are you the spy?" asked Father Hoyt. 'The Ouster spy?"
16201	The Consul rubbed his cheeks and said nothing. He looked tired, spent.
16202	'Yeah,' said Martin Silenus. 'CEO Gladstone warned
16203	me when I was chosen for the pilgrimage. She said that there was a
16204	spy."
16205	'She told all of us,' snapped Brawne Lamia. She stared at the Consul.
16206	Her gaze seemed sad.
16207	'Our friend is a spy,' said Sol Weintraub, 'but not merely an Ouster
16208	spy." The baby had awakened.
16209	Weintraub lifted her to calm her crying. 'He is what they call in the
16210	thrillers a double agent, a triple agent in this case, an agent to
16211	infinite regression. In truth, an agent of retribution."
16212	The Consul looked at the old scholar.
16213	'He's still a spy,' said Silenus. 'Spies are executed, aren't they?" ,
16214	Colonel Kassad had the deathwand in his hand. It was not aimed in
16215	anyone's direction. 'Are you in touch with
16216	your ship?" he asked the Consul.
16217	'Yes." 'How?"
16218	'Through Siri's comlog. It was... modified."
16219	Kassad nodded slightly. 'And you've been in touch
16220	with the Ousters via the ship's fatline transmitter?" 'Yes."
16221	'Making reports on the pilgrimage as they expected?" 'Yes."
16222	'Have they replied?"
16223	'No."
16224	'How can we believe him?" cried the poet. 'He's a fucking spy."
16225	'Shut up,' Colonel Kassad said flatly, finally. His gaze never left the
16226	Consul. 'Did you attack Her Masteen?"
16227	'No,' said the Consul. 'But when the Yggdrasili
16228	burned, I knew that something was wrong."
16229	'What do you mean?" said Kassad.
16230	The Consul cleared his throat. 'I've spent time with Templar Voices of
16231	the Tree. Their connection to their treeships is almost telepathic.
16232	Masteen's reaction was far too subdued. Either he wasn't what he said
16233	he was, or he had known that the ship was to be destroyed and had
16234	severed contact with it. When I was on guard duty, I went below to
16235	confront him. He was gone. The cabin was as we found it, except for
16236	the fact that the MObius cube was in a neutral state. The erg could
16237	have escaped. I secured it and went above."
16238	'You did not harm Het Masteen?" Kassad asked again.
16239	'No."
16240	'I repeat, why the fuck should we believe you?" said Silenus. The poet
16241	was drinking Scotch from the last bottle he had brought along.
16242	The Consul looked at the bottle as he answered. 'You have no reason to
16243	believe me. It doesn't matter."
16244	Colonel Kassad's long fingers idly tapped the dull casing of the
16245	deathwand. 'What will you do with your fatline commlink now?"
16246	The Consul took a tired breath. 'Report when the Time Tombs open. If
16247	I'm still alive then."
16248	Brawne Lamia pointed at the antique comlog. 'We could destroy it."
16249	The Consul shrugged.
16250	'It could be of use,' said the Colonel. 'We can eavesdrop on military
16251	and civilian transmissions made in the clear. If we have to, we can
16252	call the Consul's ship."
16253	'No!" cried the Consul. It was the first time he had shown emotion in
16254	many minutes. 'We can't turn back now."
16255	'l believe we have no intention of turning back,' said Colonel Kassad.
16256	He looked around at pale faces. No one spoke for a moment.
16257	'There is a decision we have to make,' said Sol Weintraub. He rocked
16258	his infant and nodded in the direction of the Consul.
16259	Martin Silenus had been resting his forehead on the mouth of the empty
16260	bottle of Scotch. He looked up. 'The penalty for treason is death." He
16261	giggled. 'We're all going to die within a few hours anyway. Why not
16262	make our last act an execution?"
16263	Father Hoyt grimaced as a spasm of pain gripped him.
16264	He touched his cracked lips with a trembling finger.
16265	'We're not a court."
16266	'Yes,' said Colonel Kassad, 'we are."
16267	The Consul drew up his legs, rested his forearms on his knees, and laced
16268	his fingers. 'Decide then." There was no emotion in his voice.
16269	Brawne Lamia had brought out her father's automatic pistol. Now she set
16270	it on the floor near where she sat. Her eyes darted from the Consul to
16271	Kassad. 'We're talking treason here?" she said. 'Treason toward what?
16272	None of us except maybe the Colonel there is exactly a leading citizen.
16273	We've all been kicked around by forces beyond our control."
16274	Sol Weintraub spoke directly to the Consul. 'What you have ignored, my
16275	friend, is that if Meina Gladstone and elements of the Core chose you
16276	for the Ouster contact, they knew very well what you would do. Perhaps
16277	they could not have guessed that the Ousters had the means by which o
16278	open the Tombs - although with the Als of the Core one can never know -
16279	but they certainly knew that you would turn on both societies, both
16280	camps which have injured your family. It is all part of some bizarre
16281	plan. You were no more an instrument of your own will than was' - he
16282	held the baby up - 'this child."
16283	The Consul looked confused. He started to speak, shook his head
16284	instead.
16285	'That may be correct,' said Colonel Fedmahn Kassad, 'but however they
16286	may try to use all of us as pawns, we must attempt to choose our own
16287	actions." He glanced up at the wall where pulses of light from the

16289	war, thousands will die. Perhaps millions. If the Ousters or the
16290	Shrike gain access to the Web's farcaster system, billions of lives on
16291	hundreds of worlds are at risk."
16292	The Consul watched as Kassad raised the deathwand.
16293	'This would be faster for all of us,' said Kassad. 'The Shrike knows no
16294	mercy."
16295	No one spoke. The Consul seemed to be staring at something at a great
16296	distance.
16297	Kassad pressed on the safety and set the wand back in his belt. 'We've
16298	come this far,' he said. 'We will go the rest of the way together."
16299	Brawne Lamia put away her father's pistol, rose, crossed the small
16300	space, knelt next to the Consul, and put her arms around him. Startled,
16301	the Consul raised one arm. Light danced on the wall behind them.
16302	A moment later, Sol Weintraub came close and
16303	hugged them both with one arm around their shoulders.
16304	The baby wriggled in pleasure at the sudden warmth of bodies. The
16305	Consul smelled the talc-and-newborn scent of her.
16306	'I was wrong,' said the Consul. 'I will make a reqtlest of the Shrike.
16307	I will ask for her." He gently touched Rachel's head where the small
16308	skull curved in to neck.
16309	Martin Silenus made a noise which began as a laugh and died as a sob.
16310	'Our last requests,' he said. 'Does the muse grant requests? I have no
16311	request. I want only for the poem to be finished."
16312	Father Hoyt turned toward the poet. 'Is it so important?"
16313	'Oh, yes, yes, yes, yes,' gasped Silenus. He dropped the empty Scotch
16314	bottle, reached into his bag, and lifted out a handful of flimsies,
16315	holding them high as if offering them to the group. 'Do you want to
16316	read it? Do you want me to read it to you? It's flowing again. Read
16317	the old parts. Read the Cantos I wrote three centuries ago and never
16318	published. It's all here. We're all here. My name, yours, this trip.
16319	Don't you see... I'm not creating a poem, I'm creating the future!" He
16320	let the flimsies fall, raised the empty bottle, frowned, and held it
16321	like a chalice. 'I'm creating the future,' he repeated without looking
16322	up, 'but it's the past which must be changed.
16323	One instant. One decision."
16324	Martin Silenus raised his face. His eyes were red. 'This thing that is
16325	going to kill us tomorrow - my muse, our maker, our unmaker - it's
16326	traveled back through time.
16327	Well, let it. This time, let it take me and leave Billy alone.
16328	Let it take me and let the poem end there, unfinished for all time." He
16329	raised the bottle higher, closed his eyes, and threw it against the far
16330	wall. Glass shards reflected orange light from the silent explosions.
16331	Colonel Kassad stepped closer and laid long fingers on the poet's
16332	shoulder.
16333	For a few seconds the room seemed warmed by the mere fact of human
16334	contact. Father Lenar Hoyt stepped away from the wall where he had been
16335	leaning, raised his right hand with thumb and little finger touching,
16336	three fingers raised, the gesture somehow including himself as
16337	well as those before him, and said softly, 'Ego te absolvo. '
16338	Wind scraped at the outer walls and whistled around the gargoyles and
16339	balconies. Light from a battle a hundred million kilometers away
16340	painted the group in blood hues.
16341	Colonel Kassad walked to the doorway. The group moved apart.
16342	'Let's try to get some sleep,' said Brawne Lamia.
16343	Later, alone in his bedroll, listening to the wind shriek and howl, the
16344	Consul set his cheek against his pack and pulled the rough blanket
16345	higher. It had been years since he had been able to fall asleep easily.
16346	The Consul se[ his curled fist against his cheek, closed his eyes, and
16347	slept.
16348	EPILOGUE
16349	The Consul awoke to the sound 'of a balalaika being played so softly
16350	that at first he thought it was an undercurrent of his dream.
16351	The Consul rose, shivered in the cold air, wrapped his blanket around
16352	him, and went out onto the long balcony.
16353	It was not yet dawn. The skies still burned with the light of battle.
16354	'I'm sorry,' said Lenar Hoyt, looking up from his instrument. The
16355	priest was huddled deep in his cape.
16356	'It's all right,' said the Consul. 'I was ready to awaken." It was
16357	true. He could not remember feeling more rested. 'Please continue,' he
16358	said. The notes were sharp and clear but barely audible above the wind
16359	noise. It was as if Hoyt was playing a duet with the cold wind from the
16360	peaks above. The Consul found the clarity almost painful.
16361	Brawne Lamia and Colonel Kassad came out. A minute later Sol Weintraub
16362	joined them. Rachel twisted in his arms, reaching toward the night sky
16363	as if she could grasp the bright blossoms there.
16364	Hoyt played. The wind was rising in the hour before dawn, and the
16365	gargoyles and escarpments acted' like reeds to the Keep's cold bassoon.
16366	Martin Silenus emerged, holding his head. 'No fucking respect for a
16367	hangover,' he said. He leaned on the broad railing. 'If I barf from
16368	this height, it'll be half an hour before the vomitus lands."
16369	Father Hoyt did not look up. His fingers flew across the strings of the
16370	small instrument. The northwest wind grew stronger and colder and the
16371	balalaika played
16372	counterpart, its notes warm and alive. The Consul and the others
16373	huddled in blankets and capes as the breeze grew to a torrent and the
16374	unnamed music kept pace with it. It was the strangest and most
16375	beautiful symphony the Consul had ever heard.
16376	The wind gusted, roared, peaked, and died. Hoyt ended his tune.
16377	Brawne Lamia looked around. 'It's almost dawn." 'We have another hour,'
16378	said Colonel Kassad.
16379	Lamia shrugged. 'Why walt?"
16380	'Why indeed?" said Sol Weintraub. He looked to the east where the only
16381	hint of sunrise was the faintest of palings in constellations there. 'It
16382	looks like a good day is coming."
16383	'Let's get ready,' said Hoyt. 'Do we need our luggage?"
16384	The group looked at one another.
16385	'No, I think not,' said the Consul. 'The Colonel will bring the comlog
16386	with the fatline communicator.
16387	Bring anything necessary for your audience with the Shrike. We'll leave
16388	the rest of the stuff here."
16389	'All right,' said Brawne Lamia, turning back from the dark doorway,
16390	gesturing toward the others, 'let's do it."
16391	There were six hundred and sixty-one steps from the northeast portal of
16392	the Keep to the moor below. There were no railings. The group
16393	descended carefully, watching their step in the insecure light.
16394	Once onto the valley floor, they looked back at the outcrop of stone
16395	above. Chronos Keep looked like part of the mountain, its balconies and
16396	external stairways mere slashes in the rock. Occasionally a brighter
16397	explosion would illuminate a window or throw a gargoyle shadow, but
16398	except for those instances it was as if the Keep had vanished behind
16399	them.
16400	They crossed the low hills below the Keep, staying on grass and avoiding
16401	the sharp shrubs which extended thorns like claws. In ten minutes they
16402	had crossed to sand and were descending low dunes toward the valley.
16403	Brawne Lamia led the group. She wore her finest cape and a red silk
16404	suit with black trim. Her cornlog gleamed on her wrist. Colonel Kassad
16405	came next. He was in full battle armor, camouflage polymer not yet
16406	activated so the suit looked matte black, absorbing even the light from
16407	above. Kassad carried a standard-issue FORCE assault rifle. His visor
16408	gleamed like a black mirror.
16409	Father Hoyt wore his black cape, black suit, and clerical collar. The
16410	balalaika was cradled in his arms like a child. He continued to set his
16411	feet carefully, as if each step caused pain. The Consul followed. He
16412	was dressed in his diplomatic best, starched blouse, formal black
16413	trousers and demi-jacket, velvet cape, and the gold tricome he had worn
16414	the first day on the treeship.
16415	He had to keep a grip on the hat against the wind that had come up
16416	again, hurling grains of sand in his face and sliding across the dune
16417	tops like a serpent. Martin Silenus followed close behind in his coat
16418	of wind-rippled fur.
16419	So! Weintraub brought up the rear. Rachel rode in the infant carrier,
16420	nestled under the cape and coat against her father's chest. Weintraub
16421	was singing a low tune to her, the notes lost in the breeze.
16422	Forty minutes out and they had come even with the dead city. Marble and
16423	granite gleamed in the violet light. The peaks glowed behind them, the
16424	Keep indistinguishable from the other mountain-sides. The group crossed
16425	a sandy vale, climbed a low dune, and suddenly the head of the valley of
16426	the Time Tombs was visible for the first time. The Consul could make
16427	out the thrust of the Sphinx's wings and a glow of jade.
16428	A rumble and crash from far behind them made the Consul turn, startled,
16429	his heart pounding.
16430	'Isn't it beginning?" asked Lamia. 'The bombardment?" 'No, look,' said
16431	Kassad. He pointed to a point above
16432	the mountain peaks where blackness obliterated the stars. Lightning
16433	exploded along the false horizon, illuminating icefields and glaciers.
16434	'Only a storm,' he said.
16435	They resumed their trek across vermilion sands. The Consul found
16436	himself straining to make out the shape of a figure near the Tombs or at
16437	the head of the valley. He was certain beyond all certainty that
16438	something awaited them there . . . that it
16439	awaited.
16440	'Look at that,' said Brawne Lamia, her whisper almost lost in the wind.
16441	The Time Tombs were glowing. What the Consul had first taken to be
16442	light reflected from above was not.
16443	Each Tomb glowed a different hue and each was clearly visible now, the
16444	glow brightening, the Tombs receding far back into the darkness of the
16445	valley. The air smelled of ozone.
16446	'Is that a common phenomenon?" asked Father Hoyt, his voice thin.
16447	The Consul shook his head. 'l've never heard of it." 'It had never been
16448	reported at the time Rachel came to study the Tombs,' said Sol
16449	Weintraub. He began to hum the low tune as the group started forward
16450	again through shifting sands.
16451	They paused at the head of the valley. Soft dunes gave way to rock and
16452	ink-black shadows at the swale which led down to the glowing Tombs. No
16453	one led the way. No one pokc. The Consul felt his heart beating wildly
16454	against his ribs. Worse than fear or knowledge of what lay below was
16455	the blackness of spirit which seemed to have come into him on the wind,
16456	chilling him and making him want to run screaming toward the hills from
16457	which they had come.
16458	The Consul turned to Sol Weintraub. 'What's that tune you're singing to
16459	Rachel?"
16460	The scholar forced a grin and scratched his short beard. 'It's from an
16461	ancient flat film. Pre-Hegira. Hell, it's pre-everything."
16462	'Let's hear it,' said Brawne Lamia, understand ing what the Consul was
16463	doing. Her face was very pale.
16464	Weintraub sang it, his voice thin and barely audible at first. But the
16465	tune was forceful and oddly compelling.
16466	Father Hoyt uncradled the balalaika and played along, the notes gaining
16467	confidence.
16468	Brawne Lamia laughed. Martin Silenus said in awe, 'My God, I used to
16469	sing this in my childhood. It's ancient."
16470	'But who is the wizard?" asked Colonel Kassad, the amplified voice
16471	through his helmet oddly amusing in this context.
16472	'And what is Oz?" asked Lamia.
16473	'And just who is off to see this wizard?" asked the Consul, feeling the
16474	black panic in him fade ever so slightly.
16475	Sol Weintraub paused and tried to answer their questions, explaining the
16476	plot of a flat film which had been dust for centuries.
16477	'Never mind,' said Brawne Lamia. 'You can tell us later. Just sing it
16478	again."
16479	Behind them, the darkness had engulfed the mountains as the storm swept
16480	down and across the moors toward them. The sky continued to bleed light
16481	but now the eastern horizon had paled slightly more than the rest. The
16482	dead city glowed to their left like stone teeth.
16483	Brawne Lamia took the lead again. Sol Weintraub sang more loudly,
16484	Rachel wiggling in delight. Lenar Hoyt threw back his cape so as to
16485	better play the balalaika. Martin Silenus threw an empty bottle far out
16486	onto the sands and sang along, his deep voice surprisingly strong and
16487	pleasant above the wind.
16488	Fedmahn Kassad pushed up his visor, shouldered his weapon, and joined in
16489	the chorus. The Consul started to sing, thought about the absurd
16490	lyrics, laughed aloud, and started again.
16491	Just where the darkness began, the trail broadened.
16492	The Consul moved to his right, Kassad joining him, Sol Weintraub filling
16493	the gap, so that instead of a single-file
16494	procession, the six adults were walking abreast. Brawne Lamia took
16495	Silenus's hand in hers, joined hands with Sol on the other side.
16496	Still singing loudly, not looking back, matching stride for stride, they
16497	descended into the valley.
